Ainsi, nous souhaitons que c es travaux aboutissent à un Traité juridiquement  contraignant pe rmettant de donner aux générations futures  un monde meilleur  débarrassé de toutes les formes de pollutions plastiques et des conséquences  liées , tenant compte des atteintes croissantes que font peser certains plastiques  sur la santé humaine et notre environnement.   Monsieur le Président, Abidjan,  lors d e la 15ème Conférence des Parties (COP15)  de la Convention des Nations Unies sur la Lutte contre la Désertification et la  Sècheresse (CNULC) tenue en mai 2022  à Abidjan , il a été démontré le rôle des  plastiques dans la dégradation  des sols , notamment en milieu ur bain. Le s  plast ique s abandonné s sur les sols réduise nt la perméabilité des sols et  augmente les inondation s dans nos villes en cas de fortes pluies. Cette  préoccupation vient s ’ajouter à toutes les situations d ésastreuses déjà  énumérées  au cours de cette re ncontre internationale .  C’est pourquoi, n ous pensons , Monsieur le Président  que ce nouvel  instrument ,  s’il doit être contraignant , devra instaurer des objectifs concrets de résult ats aux  différentes étapes du cycle de vie des produits plastiques . Il devra  établir les  conditions d ’une économie circulaire pour le plastique permett ant de protéger  plus efficacement la santé humaine et l’environnement .  Monsieur le Président,  je terminerai en saluant le travail du Secrétariat qui a  rassemblé les documents  d’étude et d’information demandés pour  nous  permettre de suivre en ligne cette discu ssion avec plus d ’aisance.     Je vous remercie de votre attention.     Par Professeur YAPO Ossey Bernard   Point Focal Côte d ’Ivoire

Title: Democratic Republic of the Congo
file_content: DECLARATION DE LA REPUBLIQUE  DEMOCRATIQUE DU CONGO  A L’INC 1 PUNTA  DEL ESTE 28 NOVEMBRE 2022     Monsieur le Président  félicitations pour votre élection  !  Mesdames et Messieurs,     Les plastiques dans l’environnement n’affectent pas  seulement la santé humaine et le milieu, mais aussi les  infrastructures et l’électricité  : c’est le cas dans mon pays où  les plastiques impactent le grand barrage d’Inga situé en  aval sur le grand fleuve Congo.   Ayant tous pris conscience du danger que présente les  plastiques sur la vie humaine, mais aussi de services qu’ils  nous rendent depuis des années, nous décidons  ce jour de le  bannir dans nos usages quotidiens pour sauvegarder nos  vies présentes et futures.   Tout en soutenant la déclaration de l’ Afrique notre  continent,  la RDC nous demande de nous engager à élaborer  des mesures globalement harmonisées et juridiquement  contraignantes pour l’ensemble du cycle de vie des  plastiques dans l’accord mondial,  y compris des mesures  visant à éliminer les plastiques problématiques ( par  l’interdiction  ou restriction). La mise en place des normes et  critères de conception des produits dans la transparence de  composition chimique et matérielle tout au long de la cha ine  de valeur doit être impérativement assurée.    La RDC, souhaite que le chemin qui doit nous conduire vers  cet Accord ne soit pas entaché des compromis, ni des  solutions prêtes à porter, mais qu’on privilégie l’engagement  de tous, l’équité en tenant compt e des réalités de chaque  pays, chaque continent.     Nous insisterons sur le fait que les sanctions en la matière,  puissent être imposables à tous  ; et que l’on ne s’éloigne pas  du principe pollueur – payeur.   En réitérant la demande des Etats en voie de développement  sur le renforcement des capacités, le transfert de technologie  et le financement.     Je vous remercie  !!    Pour la RDCongo   BOPE BOPE LAPWONG Jean Marie

Title: Egypt
file_content: KINDLY CHECK AGAINST DELIVERY     Draft statement for the opening of INC 1 – Punta del Este:     Excellencies, dear colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, all protocols observed,     Egypt aligns itself with the statement delivered by Ghana on behalf of the African Group.     I wish to begin by extending our sincere appreciation to the Government and the  people of  Uruguay for hosting this inaugural INC meeting and for the hospitality they have afforded us  here in beautiful Punta del Este. May the stunning coast line a few minutes away from here   serve  as an inspiration to us all to make meaningful progress at this meeting.     I also wish to thank the secretariat for the very rich tapestry of documents they have  prepared for us this session. They offer plenty of guida nce, inspiration and food for thought  and I have no doubt they will greatly assist us to hit the ground running during our  negotiations and deliberations here in Uruguay, and also at subsequent sessions.     Before I broadly address a few of the main substant ive issues before us at this session, being  guided by the secretariat’s scenario note, I wish to underline a number of key principles that  should guide us during our work this week – and indeed throughout this INC process:   1- First and foremost,  this process must exhibit the highest levels of  transparency  and  inclusivity  and be member states  owned and  driven .  2- Secondly, w e must balance  between ambition and pragmatism , to this end it is  necessary to identify and prioritize  low-hanging fruits  and avoid overloading  ourselves each  session .  3- Thirdly, a s far as the structure of this  agreement is concerned : form should follow   function .  4- Fourthly , a balanced and inclusive outcome should be our ultimate priority –  ensuring that  the voices of developing  countries are heard , our efforts are in line  with efforts to achieve sustainable development and eradicate poverty,  and that the  fundamental principles of CBDR and equity are upheld .  5- Fifth, the element of national ownership is of paramount importance. Nat ional  efforts must be the basis of this new agreement and follow a bottom -up approach  that is nationally determined. There is no one -size-fits-all approach.   6- Sixth, we must ensure that all voices are heard throughout this process to secure  a  just transition , bearing in mind the specificities of all countries and in particular the  needs of informal sectors and SMEs  in developing countries .   7- And finally, and perhaps most importantly, an ambitious global agreement must be  underpinned by e qually ambitious means of implementation  in order for it to be  implemented meaningfully.     I wish to further elaborate on this last point. Action and support are inextricably linked, and  the provision of adequate, predictable and at -scale finance will be a critical enabler  for the  action we all aspire to . The quality of this finance  provided from developed to developing  countries  – and supplemented by finance mobilized through all sources – is a key aspect  of  this. We need to ensure that it does not further contribute to th e debt crisis of many of our  developing countries.      This public finance certainly needs to be supplemented by mobilized private finance.  In this  regard, we must also ensure that there is adequate s upport from the private sector as well as to the private s ector in developing countries  to implement what we agree upon and  achieve a just transition .     A dedicated multilateral fund is an important step towards realizing this objective.  We  should learn from past experiences and success stories, including the establishment of a   multilateral fund and its instrumental role in helping to  phas e out harmful ozone depleting  substances .    Technology transfer  on a concessional basis for all develo ping countries  will also be a  prerequisite for any concrete progress and provisions must be made to provide the  necessary technological advancements needed to make the necessary transition , as well as  of course the need for adequate capacity development  – including institutional capacity –  for developing countries .    In this vein, it is also vital for us to explore the option of launching a dedicated  process to  assess  the needs of developing countries to phase out  plastics  in a matter which  assesses   the whole life cycle  of plastics.     Excellencies,     As far as the overall structure  for the instrument is concerned, it is imperative to draw on  the 4th principle I outlined earlier. Form should follow the intended function of this  agreement. With this in mind,  the secretariat document on broad options for structure,   rightly highlights that the step -by-step nature of the framework convention option may  provide the international community with the ideal way forward by setting out the broad   overarching  and ambitio us objectives already set out by the enabling UNEA resolution  in the  convention itself  and give us the time and space required to adopt subsequent protocols  which would serve the ultimate objectives of this convention  at a later stage .     The ambitious time frame of 2024 also lends itself better to the framework convention route  because it would not require us to already have all the complexities and specificities of  required control measures worked out , bearing in mind that plastic pollution is an  immensely complex, multi -faceted  and multi -sectoral challenge .     Excellencies, before I conclude,     I wish to note that s takeholder participation and action as well as cooperation and  coordination  will be a crucial piece of the puzzle. To this end, we must ensure that the best  available science is at the forefront, guiding our efforts.     We look forward to working with all parties this week to secure a successful first session of  the INC.     I thank y ou.

Title: Eritrea
file_content: Statement of the State of Eritrea at the First Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee to Develop International Legally Binding  Instrument  on plastic pollution , including in the Marine  Environment   28 November 2022   Punta del Este, Uruguay     Excellencies,   Ladies and Gentlemen,   All protocol observed     Please allow me to thank the people and government of the Oriental  Republic of Uruguay for hosting this meeting.   I also would  like to thank INC Secretariat for the assiduous  work it has done  to make this session happen.    Let me also congratulate the government s of Peru and E cuador for their  election  as subsequent chairs of the Intergovernmental Negotiating  Committee .   Excellencies,   Eritrea alig ns itself with the  statement delivered on be half of the  Africa  Group .   As we commence negotiations to forge a n international legally bindi ng  instrument  that governs our pattern s of production, consumption  and management of plastic waste , I feel p roud to inform you that this year  marks the twentieth year of official banning of single -use plastics  in Eritrea.    In th e last twenty years, Eritrea has achieved commendable results in  greatly reducing single -use plastics. In the process, we learned that w ithout  coordinated  and concerted global action s, national efforts to tackle plastic  pollution are incomplete, if not im possible. Therefore, this gap has  effectively necessitat ed our gathering here in Punta del Este to find a way  to curb plastic pollution  at global level .   Excellencies,   Eritrea will remain committed to fight plastic polluti on. Nevertheless , all  measures related to plastic reduction  and circulation as well as  management  of plastic waste requires readily available financ e, technology  transfer  and capacity building . This entails that  all rounds of  INC  negotiations need  to give particular  attention  to the issue of means of   implementation so that we can hav e a successful transition from plastic  polluted  world  to a c lean and sustainable environ ment.    I thank you!    Closing remarks of the State of Eritrea at the First Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee to Develop an International Legally Binding  Instrument on plastic pollution, including in the Marine Environment   02 December  2022  Punta del Este, Uruguay     Thank you , Mr. Chair for giving me the opportunity.   I congratulate you for ably chairing this meeting.     Mr. Cha ir,    The first session of the INC has contributed much in giving us a wider view  of the complex nature of plastic pollution and the various interests  embedded in it.   My delegation appreciates the session for giving equal importance  to plastic  pollution  that occur at different levels of the plastic chain ; namely  upstream, midstream and downstream. However, we feel that some are  more important than others.   Actions taken at midstream and downstream level cannot be achieved  without creating anothe r pollution and further contribution to carbon  emission which may even lead us to vicious cycle.   We understand that plastic is a readily available product, which is  convenient to use and unpainful to our pocket. This  implies that unless the  volume  of virgi n plastic entering the market is not strictly controlled, the availability of ch eap plastic s and unnecessary consumption will continue  to  grow.   Technical issues that are related with product design, identifying and  banning of plastics that have pollutant el ements , and recycling and treating  of good plastics have also the potential of being beyond the means and  capability of developing countries.   Therefore, Mr. Chair, the plastic menace that we are experiencing today  can quickly and meaningfully  be reduced w hen effective measures are  taken in controlling the  volume  of virgin plastics that are entering into the  market. Indeed, the world needs to create artificial scarcity so that the  value of plastic is increased , unnecessary consumptions are discouraged   and r eusing and recycling of plastic products are made economically  feasible.    Mr. Chair,   As we wait for INC -2, we kindly request the secretariat to make relevant  documents available during the intersession period, including a general  overview of the socio -economic impact of ending plastic pollution at a global  level.   I thank you!

Title: Ethiopia
file_content: General Statement of Ethiopia 1st Session of the Intergovernmental negotiating committee  (INC -1) to develop a legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine  environment. 28th November 2022, Punta Del E sta – Uruguay   Opening Plenary – Statement by Ethiopia   Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I also thank the government and people s of Ur uguay on behalf of the  government of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia for hosting this beautiful and  important conference on the solution to end plastic pollution (INC -1).  Mr. Chairman , excellences and delegates Plastics manufacturing is increas ing dramatically on a  national and international scale, and the use of plastic is expanding significantly in many sectors  of the economy.  The production and use of plastic continue to rise in tandem with the economy.  The lack of domestic resources and tech nology leads Ethiopia largest importer of plastic raw   materials and packaging machines .  Mr. Chairman , The use of plastic materials, such as PET, for packaging materials and shopping  bags, as well as its manufacturing and use, has increased significantly.  Around 95% of these  plastic materials are destroyed through burning, dispose in open spaces, and waste  dump sites.  However the  collection and recycling of plastic shows significant progress in recent years.   Plastic endangers human and ecosystem health due to poor management, occupational and  health hazards in its manufacturing, and environmental pollution;  it contributes to climate  change and depletes the ozone layer throughout its life cycle. Furthermore, the informal plastic  waste collection for recycling exposes the socioeconomic impacts on the poor community,  particularly women and children.   Beside thi s with  poor waste management, plastic shortens the  life of engineered sanitary landfills into waste disposal areas and also harms the economy of the  country.   The national recycling rate is still in its infancy and follows the manufacturing, use, and dispos al  cycle. There is a lack of sophisticated technologies for plastic waste recycling, a lack of data  management on recyclable and non -recyclable plastic materials, a lack of awareness  and waste  management are the core . Mr. Chairman  Excellences and delegates  A comprehensive and integrated approach to managing  plastic through its life cycle with a circular economy, technology transfer, awareness creation,  education, and dissemination; and with research and knowledge development, compliance,  revise existing and  develop new tolls to follow the circular approach to plastic pollution and to  end the use of single -use plastic are required for environmental sound management.   Mr. Chairman Excellences and delegates , the government of Ethiopia recognizes the  development of intern ationally legally binding tools to combat plastic pollution, including in the  marine environment, at the national level.    Thank  you.

Title: Ghana
file_content: Mr. Chair:   The Ghanaian  delegation  is grateful  for the opportunity  to address  this session.   The Government of Ghana fully align with all the statements of the African Group so far and   wish to refer to the Multistakeholder Dialogue session which took place on Tuesday. In this   regard, we  wish  to request  for the Secretariat  to have  the synthesis  report made  available  under   in-session  documents.   All stakeholders including industry, the scientific community, the informal sector such as  plastic  waste pickers, youth groups and civil society organizations should be recognized and  empowered   as essen tial stakeholders in the INC process.   Ghana wishes to call for the establishment of a robust monitoring and evaluation system which is   evidence based and  makes use of well -established indicators for the monitoring of targets,   ambitions,  and compliance at t he global and  national  levels.   We call for the establishment of a Legacy Fund, a voluntary fund with generous contributions   from industry players to manage legacy plastic, which is the outcome of decades of waste   resulting from irresponsible patterns of pr oduction and consumption of plastics. This Legacy   fund must  be established  and operationalized  in the interim  whilst  the INC process  is  underway.   We call on UNEP to establish and manage this fund which should be made accessible to all   Member States especially for countries in the global south.  We also suggest that part of the   financial instrument that would be established under the legally binding instrument, should be   applied  towards the  support and sustenance  of the Legacy  Fund.   Ghana calls on the High Ambition Business Coalition and other like -minded Coalitions to make   ambitious commitments during INC2 towards the establishment and operation of t he financial   instrument.   Mr. Chairman  I thank you  for the opportunity.

Title: Kenya
file_content: 1 | P a g e        Kenya’s statement during INC -1 on Ending Plastic Pollution: Towards a  legally binding instrument held  in Uruguay  from 28th November  to 2nd  December  2022 .  Kenya wishes to thank Uruguay for hosting this 1st INC m eeting to negotiate the  Global legally  binding Agreement to eliminate Plastic Pollution including in the  marine environment. The hospitality  showed  by Uruguay including simplifying  Visa procedures to enable negotiators to attend this meeting is highly  commendable.   During UNEA 5.2 members agreed to commence these negotiations to provide a  tool for addressing plastic pollution informed by the full life cycle of plastics.  Since then, we met during the OEWG meeting in Dak ar Senegal where we guided  the S ecretariat on the level of preparedness needed to ensure negotiators  engaged more effectively.  Kenya thanks the Secretariat for developing a number  of doc uments that have been a good guide to wards  these negotiations.   Plastics pollution presents a threat to human health, climate and biodiversity.  This meeting has a rich agenda to deliver. During the  informal stakeholders  forum convened on 26th November, par ticipants acknowledged that addressing  plastic pollution remained a major priority whose effective response requires  inclusive participation of all stakeholders including plastic producers, scientists,  waste service providers, learning institutions, recycl ers, landfill operators,  artists, waste pickers , civil society organizations  among others in order to  leverage on existing local knowledge and practices.   An all-inclusive , participatory and consultative approach needs  to be adopted  and sustained throughout  the negotiations  process  in the spirit of leaving no one  behind. Kenya supports the methodology adopted by the secretariat to  mainstream stakeholder forums to harness rich knowledge and experiences from  all stakeholders.    The plastic  pollution  issue still remains complex and there is need to harness  the rich knowledge of science while negotiating the agreement. Kenya cautions  that we need to choose our options carefully and to keep all options open to  ensure that innovation and creativity on pl astics is al lowed to thrive. Let’s  harness all opportunities while minimizing harm to  human health and the  environment.    2 | P a g e    Kenya stresses the need to discuss and develop control measures across the full  lifecycle of plastics with international standards  to bring transparency and  accountability, supported by a robust institutional structure, including a  dedicated multilateral fund and scientific body.  In addition , the issue of producer  responsibility, legacy plastics and downstream waste management should be  given special attention for developing countries.   Kenya expects this meeting to sets a good fou ndation to enable delivery of an  effective global plastics agreement. We look forward to reaching consensus  quickly on preliminary matters and embark on substant ive issues swiftly. The  timeline given by the resolution of two years is just adequate if we focus on the  real substance of the negotiations with minimal  distractions.   Finally, Kenya reiterates that all considerations for  institutional establishments  including hosting of the Secretariat should build on the intention to strengthen  UNEP headquarters in Nairobi.     Mr Chair, Kenya wishes you all the best as  you steer this team into  effective  negotiations.        Kenya’s Statement for the for the Agenda 4 of the INC -1 in Punta Del Este Uruguay.   I thank you Chair,   At the onset, Kenya would like to align itself with the Statement made by Ghana on behalf of the African  Group.   The Kenyan Delegation would like to thank the Secretariat thus far for the guidance availed to the  Committee. At this crucial stage of establishing the scope of the Instrument, Kenya considers two main  factors that should guide the arrival and distinction of the scope of the instrument, the TIME  allocated for  the Negotiations and the SEVERITY of the global challenge of Plastic Pollution.   Excellencies   Kenya calls for the prioritization of the objectives  focusing on protecting human health, biodiversity and  the climate from the impacts of plastic pollution.   Evidence shows that harmful substances such as chemical additives have n egative impact on human  health and therefore  a special focus on the upstream phase of the plastics life cycle (where plastic  producti on takes place) should be implemented.  However, this should not come at the expense of the  focus on the entire life cycle of plastics in the mid -stream and downstream phases.   Kenya, as country in the Global south, fully appreciates and is cognizant of the role that is played by the  small and informal stakeholders such as waste pickers in waste management process currently existing at  the domestic level and as such calls for the inclusion of a just transition aspect in the development of the  legally binding instrument.    Further, Kenya seeks to have an inclusive instrument that shall also address the needs of all stakeholders  including the private sector so as to foster ownership of the instrument and enhance a bottom -up  approach in the implementation processe s and procedures.  The need to have a n international based   standardization of product design and transboundary policy standardization to ensure a favorable policy  environment for the private sector should also be highlighted.   Excellencies, a robust and eff ective monitoring and evaluation framework is another element that the  Kenyan Delegation deems imperative for inclusion in the scope of the instrument that shall ensure that  the collective responsibility and inclusive interventions from all stakeholders ar e documented, tracked  and evaluated to ensure harmony in implementation of the instrument.   Kenya supports negotiating a plastics treaty in the form of either a  specific  or framework  convention based  on the two factors of consideration mentioned earlier  of Time allocated and Severity of the specific  phase  of the plastic life cycle in pollution . The structure  that should  also reflect  specific articles and annexes that  are binding to all stakeholde rs in the entire value chain and life cycle of plastics.   I thank you chair

Title: Libya
file_content: شكراًسيد ي الرئيس  اسمحوا لي أن أبدأ مداخلتي بتقديم التهنئة للسيد الرئيس على انتخابه رئيساً للجنة التفاوض الحكومية الدولية INC   وبتقديم الشكر الجزيل لدولة األوروغواي حكومةً وشعباً على حفاوة االستقبال وكرم الضيافة   وبتقديم التهنئة ألمانة الـ UNEP  ، وأمانةINC  علىهذا النج اح الباهر في التنظيم وعلى الجهود المبذولة طيلة األشهر  الماضية.  سيداتي سادتي  ال يخفى عليكم أن البالستيك أصبح من أهم الملوثات التي تهدد جميع الكائنات الحية على حد سواء، فهو موجود في   كل مكان في البر والبحر والجو، وبأشكال وألوان وأحجام مختلفة، ورغم ذلك نجد أنفسنا مضطرين للتعامل معه فهو  أصبح موجوداً  في كل مكان حولنا، فأينما ذهبت تجد البالستيك متداخل في حياتك، في األسواق، في عبوات التغليف،  واألكياس البالستيكية، وفي البيت موجود في معظم األجهزة المنزلية، في أقالمنا وأجهزة الهواتف والكمبيوتر وفي   كل مكان من حولنا. لذلك لدينا قولٌ نستخدمه في اللغة العربية بخصوص البالستيك، فنحن نقول أن "البالستيك صديقنا   اللدود" وهي جملة تحتوي على مفارقة طريفة، فكلمة اللدود ال تطلق إال  على العدو، وهنا تكمن المفارقة فهو صديقنا  ألننا مضطرين للتعامل معه في مختلف نواحي الحياة لكنه لدود ألنه من أخطر الملوثات وأكثرها انتشاراً.   سيداتي سادتي  نحن في ليبيا رغم كل الظروف التي تمر بها البالد من مشاكل متنوعة أدت إلى عدم االستقرار، إال أننا كنا دائماً  نحاول المضي قدماً في مختلف البرامج البيئية والسيما في جانب الحفاظ على الكائنات الحية البرية والبحرية، وفيما  يخص التلوث بالبالستيك، فقد  ركزنا على جانب التوعي ة ونجحنا إلى حد كبير خاصة في توعية صغار الس ن  والمراهقين، فمنذ سنوات نقوم سنوياً بأنشطة توعية مختلفة وغير تقليدية لتسليط الضوء على مشكلة البالستيك التي  أصبحت ككرة الثلج تكبر بمرور الوقت، كنا في كل عام نجمع عدد كبير من التالميذ وننظم مسابقات لجمع مخلفات   البالستيك المتناثرة على الشواطئ ثم نقوم بتوزيع الجوائز والهدايا عليهم مع التذكير بالتأثيرات السلبية للبالس تيك على  النظم البيئية البرية والبحرية. هذا األمر نجح إلى حد كبير في تشبيع عقول األطفال بخطورة البالستيك وأهمية مكافحته  والتقليل من استخدامه وإعادة استخدام المتاح منه. لقد أصبحنا نرى نتائج هذه التوعية بوضوح من خالل تزايد عدد  المتطوعين سنوياً في برامج حفظ الكائنات البحرية مثل السلحفاة البحرية ضخمة الرأس، والحوتيات  وغيرها. وكذلك   تزايد عدد المتطوعين سنوياً في الحمالت التطوعية التي ننظمها لتنظيف الشواطئ البعيدة عن التجمعات ا لسكانية من  البالستيك. فليبيا دولة تقع في جنوب البحر المتوسط وعدد سكانها قليل نسبياً وتتمتع بشاطئ طويل يبلغ حوالي  0222   كم وهي في معظمها شواطئ رملية، وأجزاء كبيرة منها ال يوجد بها أي تجمعات سكانية أو أي أنشطة بشرية، ومع ذلك في كل عام نجدها مليئة بأشكال وأنواع من البالستيك التي ترميها أمواج البحر على الشواطئ.    سيداتي سادتي  أخير فإنني اً نتهز هذه الفرصة ألنقل لكم تحيات الحكومة الليبية وباألخص تحيات معالي وزير البيئة في ليبيا إبراهيم   العربي منير الذي كلفني كنقطة اتصال لليبيا في لجنة التفاوض الحكومية الدولية . ومن هذا المنطلق أود أن أوكد أن  ليبيا تؤيد بيان المجموعة األفريقية وتأمل أن يؤخذ في االعتبار الوضع االقتصادي واالجتماعي واألمني لمختلف الدول   بحيث يتم التوصل التفاق قابل للتطبيق في مختلف الدول على حد سواء، فال يخفى عليكم أن التلوث ال يعت رف بالحدود  لذلك نأمل أن يؤخذ في االعتبار  األوضاع والظروف االقتصادية واالجتماعية واألمنية بحيث يكون االتفاق لمكافحة   التلوث البالستيكي بما في ذلك البيئة البحرية قابل للتطبيق في جميع الدول بدون استثناء.  وشكراً لكم على االستماع

Title: Malawi
file_content: Malawi Government     Opening statement       Thank you Chair ,  The Malawi delegation would like to join the other delegates in congratulating you on  your election as Chairperson .    We wish to extend, our sincere thanks to the Government of Uruguay for your  wonderful hospitality and offering to host this important meeting in Uruguay . We would  also like to thank the UNEP secretariate for their tireless work in organizing this  meeting and producing important working documents to support the INC1.     Malawi looks forward to actively engaging in this important global dialogue that aims  at providing sustainable solutions to minimize harmful effects caused by plastics . As  a country we  fully concur with the  aspirati ons expressed in African group  statement   and take cognizant of decisions made collectively by African governments in calling   for a global instrument focus ing on the most problematic, harmful and high -risk  categories of plastics.     Despite facing unique challenges with the plastic pollution, Malawi remains committed  to addressing issues relating to the full cycle of plastic of waste through  various   national interventions  such as ban on single use plastics and promoting a circular  economy .    Although  we recognize the arduous task ahead of us  on our journey to 202 4, we urge  the member states to reflect on the progress  made since  UNEA  resolution   5/14 and   to recall our mutual resolve to create an agreement that will address  the harmful effects  of plast ics pollution and foster the creation of sustainable livelihoods and practices.     Therefore, as we forge towards developing a legally binding instrument, we support  modalities that aim to  first resolve issues that that can addressed easily in order create  more time for matters that need to be visited more frequently in subsequent INCs .    In addition to  the other important elements and principals that have already been  mentioned we would lik e to highlight the significance of technology transfer  as a critical  means of implementation and support for strategic research that can assist developing  countries in developing much needed baseline information on plastic waste and to  spark  innovation for  solution s in plastics pollution.  With that said , we conclude by  reiterating the  call  for enhanced support for developing countries who often lack the  resources to support an adequate delegation to participate effectively in the INC  process.     We look forward to a constructive INC     Thank you Chair

Title: Mali
file_content: DECLARATION DU MALI RELATIVE AU MONITORING,L’EVALUATION ET L’EFFECTIVITE DE LA MISE EN  ŒUVRE.   En soutien à la déclaration du Groupe africain sur la thématique, ma délégation  soutient qu’il faille  d’abord que les parties, notamment les pays en voie de développement et à économie en transition  comme les nôtres soient aidés à développer des capacités de mise en œuvre. Voyez vous dès lors  Monsieur le Président que les différentes  dispositions du futur traité sont intimement lié es.  Ainsi les capacités développées aideront à la génération de l’information requise pour le monitoring  et l’évaluation.   Aussi pour la génération de données fiables et comparables, il est impérieux de dével opper des  projets sous -régionaux et régionaux. Tout cela, Monsieur le Président est lié à un mécanisme  financier assurant des ressources nouvelles, additionnelles, prévisibles et facilement accessibles  assurant la mise en œuvre effective tant souhaitée.   Enfin pour les besoins du monitoring il est impérieux d’élaborer des outils simples et dont la mise en  place est inclusivement partagée par les parties , en tenant compte des facteurs d’éche cs du  monitoring des autres traités.     Je vous remercie de votre bien aimable attention  ! DECLARATION DU MALI SUR LE RESUME DES TRAVAUX   Monsieur le Président, ma délégation salue votre conduite des débats et l’excellent travail abattu par  le Secrétariat.   Je voudrais soutenir le délégué du Pakistan qui a souligné le manque ou la non mention de la portée  du futur traité. Cela nous semble très important pour être exhaustif et pour ne pas se focaliser sur la  pollution plastique générale et celle en milieu mari n.  Nous voudrions une clarté sur la pollution terrestre et dans les fleuves, rivières et lacs dont nous  disposons comme pays continental.     Je vous remarcie.

Title: Morocco
file_content: D.P.C.C/ D.C.I/S .C.M                                                                                        .م.ش.ت.ت/ ق.ت.د/ م.ت.م.أ                        Déclaration du Maroc à la première réunion du Comité  Intergouvernemental des Négociations (CNI),   du 27 novembre au 02 décembre 2022       Merci Monsieur le Président,   • Le Maroc s'associe à la déclaration faite par le Groupe africain.   • Permettez -moi en premier lieu de remercier le Gouvernement de l’Uruguay et  le Bureau de l’INC, le Secrétariat du PNUE  pour les efforts déployés pour  l’organisation de cette 1ère réunion du Comité Intergouvernemental de  Négociations sur la Pollution par le Plastique et de vous féliciter Monsieur le  Président de votre élection en tant que Président du Bureau de ce Comité.   Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs,   • Face à ce défi majeur de la pollution par le plastique qui nous réunit  aujourd’hui, le Maroc  a mis en place d’importantes mesures pour faire face à  la pollution par le plastique  dans le cadre de sa mise en œuvre de sa stratégie  nationale de développement durable qui ambitionne d’assurer une transition  de notre pays vers une économie verte et inclusive à l’horizon 2030.   • Ces mesures concernent notamment le renforcement du cadre ju ridique, des  mesures fiscales ainsi qu’opérationnel les tel que l’amendement en cours de la  loi sur la gestion des déchets pour l’intégration de la responsabilité élargie du  producteur, ainsi que la mise en œuvre actuellement du Plan d’Action national  « Littoral sans plastique  » pour la réduction de la pollution marine par les  déchets plastiques et la promotion des modèles d’économie circulaire.   • Néanmoins, l’ impact des mesures nationales sur ce type de pollution reste en  deçà des objectifs escomptés d’où la nécessité d’un instrument global sur la  pollution plastique, objectif ultime qui nous réunit aujourd’hui , sur lequel nous  devrons travailler pendant les deux années à venir qui devrait non seulement  définir les mesures globales pour faire face à cette prob lématique mais  également orienter les  actions nationales .   • Le Maroc  voudrai t souligner la nécessité que cet instrument soit basé  sur les  principes de l’équité, la responsabilité commune et différenciée en prenant en  considération les circonstances nationales des pays en développement.  Un  mécanisme de mise en œuvre de l’instrument basé sur la définition de  contribution nationale déterminée pourrait être envisagé  .  • Il devra se focaliser sur les moyens de mise en œuvre notamment la promot ion  du transfert de technologie, le renforcement des capacités ainsi que  l’accès à   l’appui  financier et technique adéquat.      Excellences   • Le secteur informel et les prix compétitifs du plastique vierge en comparaison  avec celui recyclé ou les alternatives c onstituent des défis majeurs pour faire  face à cette problématique.   • Nous devons donc capitaliser notre expérience à travers la promotion de  l’engagement de l’ensemble des parties prenantes notamment le Secteur Privé,  la société civile et le monde académiq ue, l’encouragement des partenariats  public privé, tout en répondant à leurs besoins en matière de renforcement de  capacités .  • Le Maroc  souhaite également faire l’accent sur la nécessité d’assurer une  participation inclusive et transparente au processus INC  au fin de l’élaboration  d’un document à la mesure de notre ambition mais qui soit aussi réaliste et  réalisable, fondé sur un Plan d’Action Global décliné aux niveaux régional et  national privilégiant des solutions basées sur des approches intégrées et  intersectorielles abordant l'ensemble du cycle de vie du plastique et la  disponibilité d'alternatives, visant à la circularité.   • Enfin, je voudrais noter qu’une coopération solidaire multilatérale (Nord - Sud/Sud -Sud et Tripartite), et multi -acteurs est nécessai re pour faire face à ce  défi environnemental et contribuer à la lutte contre la triple crise planétaire. Je  voudrais dans ce cadre réitérer l’engagement du Maroc à continuer de joindre  ses efforts aux efforts internationaux entrepris dans la lutte contre la pollution  par le plastique.   Merci de votre attention

Title: Nigeria
file_content: Nigeria’s Statement  1 at INC 1 Plenary 29th November, 2022   Standing on all existing protocols   1. Mr Chair,  I bring you greetings from the great and well meaning people of  Nigeria, particularly the Minister of the Environment, Nigeria   2. Mr Chair, plastic is an integral part of our existence but its menace can not be  overlooked.  Nigeria is very much committed like never before in ensuring that our  environment is free of plastic pollution, beginning this giant stride from the land  base.   3. Mr Chair,  the development of protocols to address the menace of plastic  pollution including in the marine environment can not be overemphasized. Therefore  Mr Chair, we urge that the issue at hand be dealt with equitably, putting into account,  regional, regional and  subregional approach in tackling the proble ms of plastic  pollution including in the marine environment.   4. Thank you Mr Chair     Nigeria’s Statement  2 at INC1 plenary  30th November, 2022   1. Mr chair,  In addressing the challenges of plastic pollution, Nigeria aligns  her self with the African Group submission presented by the Ghanian Delegation  on behalf of the Arican group.   2. Nigeria is indeed committed to the actualization of this binding agreement  on plastic pollution including in the mari ne environment.   3. Nigeria affirms her commitment towards eradicating the plastic waste  streams posing global and regional challenges. We strongly, support the idea of  recycling and circular economy approach and promoting technological innovations  in the A frica region.  A robust monitoring and evaluation mechanism must not be  isolated in other to achieve National, regional and international goals.     4. Thank you  NIGERIAN INTERVENTION ON SEQUENCING AT THE INC 1 2ND DECEMBER, 2022   Mr Chair,   Nigeria aligns  with the statement of the African group presented by the Senegal  delegate . My delegation has outlined the following for consideration;   • On plastic life circle, in line with UNEA Resolution 5/4, an appropriate  delineation   of plastic be done to address the stages of plastic life circle   • Stakeholders discussion be engaged on transpa rency including knowledge  and ingredients in plastic materials and its sustainable product design   through global standards   • The need to pririotize the issue of means of implementation at the INC 2   • WE Also stress the need for active participation, involvemen t and  engagement in line with UNEA resolution1/5 on integrated and sustainable  financial consideration   • Mr Chair, the partnership initiative should be sustainable to adequately  address the needs of developing countries.   • Finally Mr Chair, My delegation stro ngly suggest that the INC Secreteriat  should extend funding to at least two (2) delegates.     Thank you Mr Chair

Title: Republic of Congo
file_content: MINISTERE DE L’ENVIRONNEMENT   REPUBLIQUE DU CONGO     DU DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE     Unité – Travail – Progrès         ET DU BASSIN DU CONGO        -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-                                                                                                                                                                                    -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-            DIRECTION GENERALE             DE L’ENVIRONNEMENT              -=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-    DECLARATION DE LA REOUBLIQUE DU CONGO A LA PREMIERE REUNION  DU COMITE DE NEGOCIATIONS INTERGOUVERNEMENTALES (CNI)  CHARGE D'ELABORER UN INSTRUMENT INTERNATIONAL JURIDIQUEMENT  CONTRAIGNANT SUR LA POLLUTION PLASTIQUE, Y COMPRIS EN MILIEU  MARIN   Monsieur le Président, la République du Congo vous félicite pour votre  élection a la présidence de l’INC   Madame la  Secrétaire Exécutive du Comite de Négociation  Intergouvernementales   Je remercie les Autorités de ce pays pour avoir accepter d’abriter cette  réunion et pour leur hospitalité   Mes remerciements vont également a l’endroit du PNUE et de tous ceux  qui de prêt ou de loin ont contribue ou contribuent encore a la réussite  de la présente réunion.   La République du Congo est un p ays situe dans le Bassin du Congo,  caractérisé, non seulement des grandes entendues de forets danses -  poumon écologique de l’humanité, mais aussi des réseaux  hydrographiques d’envergure internationale à l’instar du majestueux  fleuve Congo et de l’Océan pacifique. Tous ces réseaux hydrographiques  bordent les agglomérations du pays et sont vulnérables à la pollution  plastique, provoquée par l’ac tion humaine.   La pollution plastique constitue un fléau ; on la retrouve dans les mers,  les océans et tous les cours d'eau, ce qui en fait un danger global et le  premier ennemi de la planète en matière de biodiversité. Contre cette  pollution, le combat est  loin d'être gagné, ce qui rend nécessaires les  temps de mobilisation tels que celui de cette première réunion du Comite de Négociations intergouvernementales, chargé de créer un instrument  juridique international contraignant contre la pollution plastique  y  compris dans l’environnement marin.   Cet accord devrait permettre aux Etats de mettre en œuvre des plans  d'action pour prévenir, réduire et éliminer la pollution plastique, selon  une vision claire et commune, avec des objectifs ambitieux et  mesurables et  des indicateurs appropriés. E t-ce avec l ’implication de tous  les acteurs de secteurs informels et formels, tant économiques que  politiques et sociaux , privés ou publics .  Ces plans d’actions devront constituer la priorité pour la mise en œuvre  de ce procha in accord. Nous souhaitons qu’ils soient recommandés à   tous les membres au lancement de cet accord.   Le CNI -1 devra donner le ton aux négociations à venir, en mettant  l'accent sur les questions de procédure, de définition  des concepts et les  discussions sur la portée qui pourraient fournir une boussole directrice  pour la conception d'un accord ambitieux et efficace  qui devra comporter  des dispositions facilitant sa mise en œuvre, tels que  :  • Le renforcement des capacités technique, scientifique  et  financières des états en développements  ;  • Le suivi de la gestion des plastiques à toutes les étapes de leur  cycle de vie  ;  • Des mesures contraignantes envers toutes les initiatives contraires  aux objectifs de cet accord, qui devront être réprimées non  seulement par des législations locales, mais aussi par la mise en  pratique des principes de pollueurs -payeurs et de responsabilité  élargie du producteur.   • Le contrôle et la surveillance des mouvements transfrontières en  coopération avec les conventions de B ale et de Bamako  ;  • Une échéance respectable par toutes les parties de l’élimination  des plastiques a usage unique  ;  • Un système de rapporting sur un cycle bisannuel par les Etats  parties sur l’état d’avancement de la gestion Ecologiquement  rationnelle des d échets plastiques . La République  du Congo informe la communauté  ici présente  de  l’existence  au niveau des Etats du Bassin du Congo un instrument de  gestion de l’ économie  Bleue, appelé  Fonds Bleu du Bassin du Congo. Il  est crée pour participer à l’améliorat ion des voies de navigation et de  transport et a l’appui de l’installation de projets hydroélectriques, au  développement de la pêche et de la pisciculture et  au renforcera  l’irrigation en vue d’accroitre la productivité sur les terres arables dans  les sava nes. Toutes ses activités sont aujourd’hui vulnérables à la  pollution plastique. Dans le cadre de cet accord que nous sommes  entrain de négocier, il pourra servir de source des financements de  contrepartie pour la réalisation des projets relatifs au plasti que. Mas il  faut pour cela que ce fond soit soutenu, renforcé par des institutions de  développement  et les pourvoyeurs  des ressources. Cette information  vise a rechercher les partenaires pour le fonctionnement de cet outil  nécessaire pour la lutte contre  la pollution plastique en milieux  aquatiques.   Monsieur le Président , la République  du Congo salu e la création de ce   nouvel accord en négociation.   Nous vous remercions pour votre attention a notre declaration.    Au sujet du mécanisme financier de l’instrument juridiquement  contraignant sur la pollution plastique.   Merci Monsieur le Président  pour la parole   La République  du Congo se  rallie à la déclaration  lue par le Ghana au  nom du groupe Afrique.   La pollution plastique est déjà reconnu comme un grand défis global, et  comme l’on dit généralement , ‘’aux grands maux, de grands remèdes ’’, la  république  du Congo souhaite que le mécanisme  financier pour la mise   en œuvre de ce nouvel outil soit spécifique,  durable et fort.   Le fond devra fournir une assistance financière  et technique, pour a ider  les pays en développement  a respecter les mesures de contrôle de  production et de consommation des plastiques.   Il devra apporter des couts supplémentaires ,  comporter une approche  de conduite de la conformité  des pays et un partenariat égal.  Base sur la préservation  du milieu aquatique et toutes ses économies , ce  mécanisme  doit soutenir le développement  des projets relatifs  à ces  économies .  Il doit renforcer les les mécanismes  locaux pour leur permettre  d’atteindre leurs objectifs, en conformité  avec ceux de l’instrument en  création .  La république  du Congo dispose pour les Etats du Bassin du Congo un  instrument de gestion des économies Bleues, appelé Fonds Bleu du  Bassin du Congo . Il est crée pour participer à l’amélioration des voies  de navigation et de transport, à l’appui de l’installation de projets  hydroélectri ques, au développement de la pêche et de la pisciculture  ainsi qu’au renforcement de l’irrigation en vue d’accroitre la productivité  sur les terres arables dans les savanes. Toutes ses activités sont  aujourd’hui vulnérables à la pollution plastique.   Il est recherche des partenaires, certains peuvent être ici dans la salle,  qui renforceront le fonctionnement du fond Bleu du Bassin du Congo, car il devra devenir un moyen de financer les fonds de contrepartie, souvent  recommandés pour financer les projet s dans le cadre des conventions.   Je vous remercie.

Title: Rwanda
file_content: Rwanda value engagement with stakeholders and we need their expertise to enrich our discussion  and understanding to elaborate an ambitious treaty.     • We have taken good note that the INC will not organize another Multi - Stakeholder Forum,  but rather seek ways to improve stakeholder engagement, in particular during the inter -sessional  period.     • We have heard from many stakeholder and delegations that it is key to get more targeted  written inputs in due time before the INC -meetings to absorb this informatio n.     • Also, we think it is useful to set up two working  streams for INC -2 to progress our  discussions.     o Group 1 could be focused on objective, core obligations, control measures and  implementation measures.   o Group 2 could focus on means of implementation, including financial assistance and  capacity building as well as institutional arrangement

Title: Seychelles
file_content: First meeting of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop an international  legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine  Environment   28th  November - 2nd December 2022   Punta del Este, Uruguay   Republic of Seychelles o pening Statement    Thank You  Chair,   Distinguished Delegates ladies and gentlemen,   Since our delegation takes the floor for the first time, on behalf of the Government of  Seychelles I would like to express our gratitude towards the Government of  Uruguay and the  UNEP secretariat for their warm welcome  and hospitality .  The Republic of Seychelles being a Small Island Development State is in favour of the  development and adoption of legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including the  marine  environment   Seychelles being a small island states continue to face challenges and impacts as a result of  trans  boundary movement of waste, importation of goods which then turns into waste, lack  of environmentally sound management solutions including lack  of important resources to  implement strategies towards elimination of waste and the prevention of  plastic  pollution.   In view of our strategic location  in the Indian Ocean we continue to face continues threats,  our environment especially the outer islands which are most often difficult to access tons  and tons of  plastic  wastes are washed up on our shores.  We are severely affected and  Seychelles is the receiving end of plastic wastes and marine litter.   We acknowledge the  efforts being done at the National L evel from the executive to the community at large in an  effort to maintain the health of our natural environment leading to a healthier nation.,  Seychelles economic pillar remains the Tourism industry. Thus the pressure is on us to  ensure that  the necessar y measures are in place to protect and preserve the quality of our   Environment by reducing and eliminating plastic pollution.   During recent years we have, taken strategic actions aimed at early achievement of global  targets. Noticeable actions include the  ban on single use plastic bags, cutleries and  polystyrene take away boxes in 2017.  Restriction on single use plastic straws in 2019. We  also promote the use and distribution of biodegradable alternatives.  Just last year , we   banned the importation, use as  well as commercial distribution of balloons.  This marks yet  another landmark action towards waste management in our Country. These bold decisions,  portrays our commitment and dedication including political support to advocate for bold  actions towards sou nd management of plastic  wastes. We recognize the fact  that it will take  a global effort to tackle plastic pollution. Hence, a intergovernmental negotiating committee  is the way forward. We stress that to meet the obligations under the instrument, financia l  assistance will be required and capacity building programs as well.   Today I take this opportunity to call upon small islands states especially those of the  Western Indian Ocean for us to come together, shoulder to shoulder so that a louder and  stronger v oice is heard for actions to be committed  under the legally binding instruments  Seychelles believes in multilateralism, and urge others to come together in a collective  manner so that a momentum is created for our respective countries build on and catalyze   the impacts through initiatives.   We look forward to engaging on the development of global agreement to prevent new  plastic pollution and manage existing plastic pollution.   Thank you .

Title: South Africa
file_content: Statement by South Africa during the First Inter -Governmental Negotiating  Committee (INC -1), Punt a del Este, 28 November 2022     Chairperson   Distinguished delegates     The South African delegation is grateful for the excellent organisation by the Government  of Uruguay, UNEP and the INC Secretariat.     South Africa aligns itself with the Statement made by Ghana on behalf of the 54 member  states of the Africa  Group.     South Africa appreciates the efforts  that ha ve been done voluntarily by member states  and stakeholders on curbing plastic pollution  however  these voluntary initiatives have   limitations . Legally binding measures throughout the lifecycle of plastics  are a necessary  policy mix in addressing plastic pollution .    South Africa supports  the inclusion of  both legally binding  and voluntary measures  in the   full lifecycle  stages  of plastic s. As qualified by respective circumstances, South Africa calls  on the INC to prioriti se control measures for problematic and unnecessary  plastic  product s.  Elimination  measures  and restrictions have been applied to plastic products in  our national legislatio n. Circularity measures including product design  have also been  introduced to plastic products including setting recycled content targets.  Voluntary   Extended Producer Responsibility  schemes  were not adequate and South Africa has  passed legislation on Extended Producer Responsibility  for plastic products.     South Africa supports an evidence -based approach informed  by prioritisation based on  processes  and plastic products that are prone to cause environmental pollution.     Polluter pays principle applied to the full lifecycle of plastics is key. South Africa is  in  support of the immediate establishmen t of a contact group on the means of  implementation. As we embark on this journey , critical to any success would be the means  of implementation required by developing countries.  This element of the instrument should  be a key feature for each stage of the plastic lifecycle , each control measure  and a key  feature of each INC  meeting . It is of utmost importance that the Rio Principle, in particular  the principle of Common but Differentiated Responsibilities (CBDR) and Respective  Capabilities is put at the centre of the means of implementation.     It is appreciated that all stakeholders are on  the table in the  sharing of  knowledge and best  practices to ensure that negotiations are well informed. To this extent, South Africa urges  the INC to recognise the role that waste pickers play  in curbing plastic pollution . South  Africa call s on the INC to consider m easures that are  inclusive of informal waste pickers  and further  support waste picker integration , and also ensure  a just transition . The  livelihoods sustained by waste picking should be protected by the instrument measures .     Whilst the model of a framework convention has its advantages, my delegation is of the  view that the international community does not have the luxury of time to ne gotiate the  substantive aspects of the international instrument incrementally and over prolonged time.  South Africa cautions that with framework conventions, important decisions and  substantive matters may be deferred to a later time which is relatively no t the case with  Specific Conventions. Further  delays would not be desirable given the ambitious work and  timelines aligned to the INC mandate to finalise this Instrument.     I thank you .

Title: Tunisia
file_content: REPUBLIQUE TUNISIENNE     Ministère de L’Environnement                               Merci monsieur  le président  de me donner le parole et permet moi de  remercier le président et le peuple de l’Uruguay pour leur  l'accueil chaleureux .  Et de remercier  tous les membres de Comité de négociation intergouvernemental  (INC) (Punta del  Este -Uruguay, chargée de développer un instrument  juridiquement contraignant sur la pollution plastique, notamment en milieu  marin .         Le gouvernement Tunisien est associé  au groupe de l’Afrique .   La pollution plastique est une crise environnementale , sociale et économique de  plus en plus grave au niveau mondial           Ce pour cela la Tunisie appuie la Comité de négociation  intergouvernemental (INC) pour l'établissement d'accords et de réglementations  mondiales communes qui sont essentielles pour réduire au maximum la menace  de la pollution plastique au niveau global jusqu'à son élimination.    La Tunisie s’est engagée dans des stratégies d’économie verte, économie bleue  et économie circulaire à travers plusieurs programmes et initi atives. Parmi les  projets, citons celui de la Responsabilité Elargie du Producteur (REP)  et  l’encouragement des initiatives d’entrepreneuriat dans le secteur.            La Tunisie a bien adhéré aux efforts internationaux de lutte contre la  pollution marine par le plastique, en vue de contribuer à la protection et à la  préservation du bon état écologique des écosystèmes et des ressources naturelles  constituant le capital naturel des générations actuelles et futures.           Ceci aura des retombées positives s ur de nombreux secteurs au niveau  national, notamment la santé, le tourisme, la pêche, l’environnement, etc.   Citons quelques initiatives nationales  :    En réponse aux défis internationaux et nationaux vis à vis la lutte contre la  pollution marine par les déchets plastiques, le gouvernement tunisien, en collaboration avec la BM, se penchent actuellement sur l’élaboration  d’une stratégie « Littoral sans pla stique ou LISP – Tunisie ».     L'objectif global  étant de parvenir à un littoral sans plastique.     L'objectif spécifique  est de réduire la pollution marine par les déchets  plastiques et assurer une gestion dans une perspective de l’économie  circulaire. La vis ion est un littoral tunisien sans plastique adoptant des  modèles circulaires inclusifs et durables.    Stratégie nationale de gestion intégrée des déchets ménagers et  assimilés 2020 – 2035 , dont la vision est de  « Promouvoir une gestion  intégrée des déchets m énagers et assimilés, dans le cadre d’une économie  circulaire en s’appuyant sur des communes performantes en vue de  protéger l’environnement et de rehausser le cadre de vie ». A travers  ;  ✓ La promotion d’une gestion intégrée mettant fin aux pratiques  sector ielles et appuyée sur une approche multisectorielle,   ✓ L’intégration de la gestion des déchets ménagers dans le processus  de l’économie circulaire (En se basant sur la REP),   ✓ Le renforcement des capacités et le développement des moyens  humains, techniques et  financiers des municipalités.    Interdiction des sacs en plastiques à usages unique (Décret n°32 du 16  janvier 2020)    Processus de mise en place de la Responsabilité Elargie du Producteur.    Une forte implication des associations et du Secteur Privé    Campagne s de propreté dans tout le pays basées sur l’appui du volontariat  et le changement des comportements.           Ce p our cela,  nous espère nt que  le nouveau traité   doit inclure des mesures  globales sur l'ensemble du cycle de vie du plastique, sous la forme de règles  mondiales spécifiques, ciblant les catégories prioritaires de pollution plastique à  haut risque. Un soutien opportun, prévisible, accessible et suffisan t, comprenant  à la fois des ressources financières et techniques, un transfert de technologie et  un renforcement des capacités, doit également être fourni pour une mise en  œuvre efficace de ces mesures au niveau mondial.   Et je vous remercie pour votre atte ntion monsieur le président .   شكرا سيدي الرئيس   يعتبر بالدي تونس رغم مساحته الصغيرة المستهلك الرابع فيما يخص استعمال الزجاجات البالستيكية في منطقة البحر   األبيض المتوسط و نطمح من خالل هذا الصك الى وضع حد من االستعمال الغير مبرر للكميات الكبيرة من البالستيك  التي تحمل مواد كيميائية و إضافات سامة تلوث اوساطنا و تضر بصحتنا و في هذا االطار فنحن  ال نقلل من أهمية حوار   أصحاب المصلحة المتعدد الذي تم اعتماده و دعمه خالل هذا المؤتمر و لكن نظرا لضيق الوقت الذي يداهمنا و كل العالم   الذي وضعنا تحت المجهر و الذي يتابع مخرجات هذه اللقاء و اللقاءات القادمة  لوضع صكا يستجيب لطموحات مليارات  من المواطنين للحد من مخاطر التلوث البالستيكي و نوصي بشدة بعدم تخصيص المساحات المخصصة لنقاش الصك و   بنوده على أصحاب المصلحة  Multis SF  في  INCs ولكن التركيز على:  -1 احداث قاعدة  لتبادل المعلومات ، مثل المشاورات واالجتماعات العامة الوطنية ، واالجتماعات التحضيرية اإلقليمية  لمناقشة بنود االجتماعات المقبلة  2. عوض على تدعيم النقاش ألصحاب المصلحة نطلب, فتح جميع االجتماعات اإلقليمية لهم ، و  هي الفرصة األنفع  إلجراء مناقشات هادفة بين جميع أصحاب المصلحة .  3.  تم دعم9  مشاركين من أصحاب المصلحةو هو يعتبر عددا ال يمثل مشاركة كل شرائح المجتمع المتؤثرة بالتلوث   البالستيكي من أصوات النساء والشباب والحكومات المحلية والمزارعين والمجتمعات األصلية من مختلف مناطق العالم و  نتمنى ان يؤخذ بعين االعتبار لدعم واسعة  لمشاركة كل أصحاب االطراف

Title: Uganda
file_content: Uganda Delegation on Sequencing   Thank you Mr. Chair   The Ugandan delegation aligns itself to the statement delivered by Senegal on  behalf of the African Group.   In order to make progress in the negotiations, our delegation suggests that the  work can be organized along two tracts, that is, the substantive mat ters such as  the scope, core objectives, core measures,  and the other  on means of  implementation  and other  general  provisions . However, in order not to strain   particularly small delegations, we suggest that there should not be more than  two contact groups running at time.   To ensure inclusiveness during the negotiations, we emphazise that t here is  need to support participation of at least two delegates per member state,  particularly from developing countries.   We believe that progress can be further enriched by intersessional work,  including regional consultative meetings , where possible .  Considering the time and resource constraints, we emphasize that the  stakeholder consultations should not encroach on valuable time for the  negotiations.   I thank you Mr. Cha ir

Title: United Republic of Tanzania
file_content: Honorable Chair,    Fellow delegates,     1. The United Republic of Tanzania  wishes to congratulate you  for assuming the chairmanship of Inter -governmental  Negotiation Committee .  2. The United Republic of Tanzania is advancing our  appreciation to the Government of Uruguay for hosting this  first Inter -governmental Negotiation Committee Meeting  and  hospitality accorded to our delegation.   3. The United Republic of Tanzania aligns itself to the statement  issued by the Distinguished Deleg ate from Ghana on behalf  of the African Group   4. United Republic of Tanzania  also send s sincer e  congratulation s to UNEP for organizing this first Inter - governmental  Negotiation Committee Meeting to develop  international legally binding Instrument to end plastic  pollution.   5. Our delegation  and the rest of the members are aware of    the  effects  of plastics from production, distribution , use and   disposal to  the environment include  marine .     6. Hence there is a need to have necessary measures to reduce   or eventual elimination of their effects . In this regard in 2019  United Republic of Tanzania prepared the regulation to  prohibit  single use plastic carrier bags . The implementation of  the regulation has been successfully.   7. United Republic of Tanzania  recogni zes the  global efforts   through INC to end Plastic pollution which have impacts  to the  environment including terrestrial and marine : In achieving this,  we recommend the process toward this agreement to be  transp arent and inclusive, involving all key stakeholders in all  stages  of plastic  lifecycle without forgetting  informal sector  such as waste pickers . Inclusivity of the stakeholders will also  allow  flexibility and easy inclusion of technological changes  required  during implementation.       8. The importance of plastic in our daily life and our economy  cannot denied, Hence through scientific proven research  the  instrument that is going to be developed should   highlight  the  plastic products, hazardous additives that could  be identified  as potentia l hazards to the  environmental pollution .    9. Our delegation  reaffirms its commitment to participate  effectively in INC, so as to reach an agreement by 2024. We will continue to take part in global efforts towards ensuring that  the objectives agreed upon in UNEA's resolution no. 5/14 are  realized.       Honorable Chair, D elegates , thank  you.

Title: Zambia
file_content: ZAMBIAN STATEMENT   THANK YOU CHAIR,     AS WE ARE TAKING THE FLOOR FOR THE FIRST TIME, ZAMBIA  WOULD LIKE TO CONGRATULATE YOU ON YOUR APPOINTMENT  TO CHAIR THIS COMMITTEE. I WISH TO THANK THE GOVERNMENT  OF URUGUAY FOR HOSTING US AND TO THE SECRETARIAT FOR  TAKING TIME TO ARRANGE THIS IMPORTANT MEET ING AND THE  PREPARATION OF THE DOCUMENTS WE HAVE BEEN CONSIDERING  IN OUR DISCUSSIONS. ZAMBIA ALIGNS ITSELF  WITH THE  STATEMENT OF THE AFRICAN GROUP.     ZAMBIA ALSO RECOGNIZES THE IMPORTANCE OF NEGOTIATING A  LEGALLY BINDING INSTRUMENT ON PLASTIC THAT WILL AIM AT  ELIMINATING PLASTIC POLLUTION AND THE IMPACTS TO HUMAN  HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT INCLUDING IN THE MARINE  ENVIRONMENT.  WITH REGARDS TO THE SEQUENCING, MY  COUNTRY HOPES TO SEE TEXT WILL ADDRESS THE LIFECYCLE OF  PLASTICS IN LINE WITH THE UPSTREAM, MIDSTRE AM AND  DOWNSTREAM.     WE PROPOSE THAT THE INTERSESSIONAL WORK SHOULD INCLUDE  THE UPSTREAM, MIDSTREAM AND DOWNSTREAM BEFORE INC 2   TO COMPREHENSIVELY ADDRESS EACH STAGE OF THE LIFECYCLE,   IN LINE WITH UNEA RESOLUTION 5/14. ON THIS, A REASONABLE  DELINEATION O F THE LIFECYCLE OF PLASTIC MAY INCLUDE: (I)  SOURCING OF RAW MATERIALS; (II) VIRGIN POLYMER  PRODUCTION AND CONSUMPTION; (III) PRODUCT DESIGN AND USE;  (IV) WASTE MANAGEMENT AND TREATMENT; AND (V) PLASTIC IN  THE ENVIRONMENT.   REGARDING NATIONAL REPORTING, STA KEHOLDERS INCLUDING  PRODUCERS OF PLASTIC, WASTE PICKERS AND RECYCLERS WILL BE CRITICAL IN PROVISION OF DATA THAT WILL BE PART OF THE  NATIONAL REPORTS. THE INFORMATION SHOULD BE BASED ON  TRANSPARENCY, INCLUDING “FULL KNOWLEDGE OF THE  INGREDIENTS IN PLASTIC MATERIALS” AND “SUSTAINABLE  PRODUCT DESIGN THROUGH GLOBAL SUSTAINABILITY CRITERIA  AND STANDARDS AND ELIMINATING HARMFUL CHEMICALS IN  PLASTICS, ENSURING TRANSPARENCY ACROSS THE VALUE  CHAIN.”      THE ZAMBIAN DELEGATION IN ATTENDANCE BOTH IN PERSON  AND ONLINE, REMAINS COMMITTED TO SEEING THE WORK OF  THIS INTERGOVERNMENTAL NEGOTIATING COMMITTEE  PROGRESS TO THE DRAFTING AND CONCLUSION OF THE  INTERNATIONAL LEGALLY BINDING INSTRUMENT ON PLASTIC  POLLUTION.     THANK YOU! ☺

Title: Bahrain
file_content: Thank you, Mr Chair,     First, I would like to take this opportunity to thank Uruguay for their  tremendous hospitality and for the hosting of INC -1 for an  international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, include  in marine environment. Kingdom of Bahrain fully supports the INC  process for establishment of the instrument, and we are highly  committed to the success of the negotiations ahead of us.     We emphasize the importance of supporting the active participation  of all membe r states of the United Nations in the INC process as  this is a party driven process in order to share their vision, priorities  and barriers for the instruments. We look forward to have adequate  time for discussion on substantive issues.     We cannot deny the  importance of plastic products globally for  various applications, Plastics play an essential role in our society,  and we see the importance of plastics for sustainable development  and the need to focus on addressing pollution through a circular  economy ap proach. Therefore, we should take circularity as an  overarching approach to ensure sustainability.     Furthermore, as we are one of the small islands developing states  which need very special attention, we believe that discussions on  the mechanism and the arrangements for financial and technical  assistance especially for the developing countries and small island  developing states are key to ensure the effectiveness of the  instrument.     In closing the statement, Kingdom of Bahrain look forward to the  negotiat ion process and we are honor to be part of this historical  moment.     Thank you.

Title: China
file_content: 中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的一般性发言 中国代表团感谢东道主乌拉圭和联合国环境署为本次会议 顺利召开作出的努力，同时祝贺GustavoMeza-CuadraVelasquez 大使当选主席。 塑料污染是当前国际社会共同面临的重大环境挑战，制定具 有法律约束力的塑料污染国际文书，对世界各国共同采取行动解 决塑料污染问题、推动可持续发展具有重要意义。 中国政府高度重视塑料污染治理工作，不断完善法规制度， 全面禁止进口塑料废物；针对容易造成环境泄漏的塑料制品实施 全链条管理，取得积极成效。此外，中国与国际竹藤组织共同发 起“以竹代塑”倡议，与其他国家共同牵头修订巴塞尔公约塑料 废物环境无害化管理技术导则，为推动全球减少塑料污染做出积 极贡献。 主席先生， 中国代表团希望塑料污染国际文书的谈判坚持问题导向，聚 焦易向环境泄漏的塑料制品，针对不同种类塑料制品采取分类管 控措施，加强回收利用和安全处置。 我们认为，在国际文书的谈判进程中，必须充分考虑不同国 家的国情和能力，特别是发展中国家的需求，坚持公平、共同但 有区别的责任原则。发达国家在解决本国塑料污染问题的同时， 应加强对发展中国家在技术、资金、能力建设等方面的支持。中 国愿与各方一起不断凝聚共识，推动文书尽快达成。中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的发言 原则（Principles） 中国代表团注意到目前的会议文件中尚未对新文书原则给 出初步建议，会议的区域和成员国及相关团体声明中均提到了不 同的原则，例如多次提到的“全生命周期管控原则”“生产者责 任延伸原则”“污染者付费原则”等，我们认为新文书的原则与 法律术语解释密切相关，应在各方对法律术语达成共识的基础上 进行制定。另外，管控塑料污染的同时不应忽视塑料对人类社会 经济的重要作用和贡献，新文书的原则还应将塑料置于整个社会 经济中统筹考虑经济、社会发展与环境的协同促进关系。 范围（Scope） 中国代表团认为文书的涵盖范围至关重要。塑料种类繁多， 广泛应用于农业、工业和建筑等各个领域，为人类衣、食、住、 行和医疗等提供了基础保障。我们建议新文书坚持问题导向，从 导致塑料污染的根源入手，确定新文书管控的塑料类别和行为。 会议文件UNEP/PP/INC.1/7塑料科学中多次提到导致塑料污染 的主要因素，例如“废物管理不善是造成塑料污染的最大原因”， “塑料废物的管理不善导致了从海岸到海洋最深处的沉积物的 整个海洋环境受到污染”。因此我们建议新文书应聚焦易向环境 泄露的塑料制品，聚焦易向环境泄露的环节即塑料废物收集、利 用和处置环节，并着眼于加强塑料废物向海洋环境排放的管控。 核心义务(Coreobligations） 在讨论核心义务的时候，我们注意到关键术语的重要性，关中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的发言 键术语与文书的范围和目标均高度关联，各方对关键术语达成共 识是我们开展后续实质性谈判的基础。我们认为应根据新文书的 目标和范围确定关键术语的具体内涵和外延。 关于新文书核心义务、控制措施和自愿办法，如UNEA5/14 决议指出，塑料污染治理方法是多种多样的，没有一刀切的做法， 靠一种或几种普适性的做法也难以有效推动全球塑料污染治理。 塑料全生命周期管控涉及的各链条各环节的治理措施根据各国 实际情况均会进行调整，全球塑料污染治理工作应尊重和依赖于 各国的努力，应在共同目标的指引下强化各国主动性和自主性。 文书结构（Structureoftheinstrument） 中国代表团感谢秘书处提供的不同结构文书的会议文件，我 们注意到不同文书结构相互包含、各有利弊。我们认为文书形式 应服务于内容，此文书虽然是新文书，但塑料污染治理涉及的工 作却不是全新的，目前多个国际公约和框架已针对塑料全链条治 理的一个或多个环节进行了管控。新文书应加强与其他国际公约 和文书的合作、协调和互补。因此我们认为以特定公约的形式将 有助于形成更有针对性的条款，有助于与其他国际公约和文书形 成合力，也有助于全球塑料污染治理的进程。 最后条款的标准条款（Standardarticlesonfinalprovisions） 最后条款非常重要，应结合实质内容进一步考虑。中方愿意 参考此前环境条约的经验，并就此进行谈判。中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的发言 多利益方参与（Multi-stakeholderEngagement） 中国代表团赞赏多利益相关方对全球环境治理发挥的作用。 考虑新塑料公约需要大量的磋商工作，时间非常紧迫，尤其是在 会议期间获取利益相关者的大量的信息需要消化、吸收。如果利 益相关方在闭会期间准备提交文件（submissions），我们将会非 常感谢。利益相关者也可以召开线上线下会议进行充分交流，提 前提交会议成果文件，给予各方充分的时间进行参考。在全会召 开期间，我国代表团认为大会应聚焦文书的核心义务及控制措施 进行充分讨论，以便加快推进相关进程。 对INC组织和未来工作的建议（Sequencingandrecommended futureworktobetaken） 中国代表团感谢各成员国和主要团体在会前提交的关于会 议组织的建设性意见。我们认为，塑料全生命周期是一个有机整 体，应从全局出发统筹考虑各阶段管控措施，应对全生命周期各 阶段给予同等对待，因此针对塑料全生命周期管控措施，应在一 个工作组下统筹考虑。另外由于部分国家参会成员较少，将塑料 全生命周期管控再行分组也不利于各国的广泛参与。 议事规则（RulesofProcedures） 谢谢主席。感谢您的领导和秘书处的工作，也赞赏所有线上 线下参会者所展现的合作、包容和灵活的态度。中方想再次强调， 中国在11月28日大会开幕式上就议事规则所提观点应被完整记 录在大会报告中。现在我将重申中国就议事规则的立场，我将以中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的发言 英文表达：Chinaproposedthatweshouldkeepthepossibilityofthe hybridformatinordertofacilitatetheprocessforward,and emphasizedthatonlythenon-governmentalorganizationsinvitedor accreditedcanbetheobserversoftheINCsessions.请将上述内容 完整记录进报告！ 在大会上关于非正式小组的发言（StatementonthePlenary meetingabouttheInformalGroup） 谢谢主席先生。中国代表团感谢主席、共同协调员、秘书处 和各方在非正式工作组期间开始的工作和取得的成果。我们认为 公开透明的程序对文书谈判进程至关重要，确保各成员国充分表 达意见是达成有效、包容的文书的重要前提。中国代表团想再次 强调谈判成果应是各方经充分沟通之后，达成共识的结果。在此 基础上，中方支持主席和秘书处工作，愿与各方一同努力，共同 推进整体进程有效开展。此外，各位代表从世界各地汇集于此， 很多代表不远万里前来，克服路程的重重困难，我们希望各国在 会议期间表达的观点能够充分反映在最后的会议报告中。中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会第一次会议的发言 能力建设、技术和资金援助（Capacity-building,technicaland financialassistance） 谢谢主席。发展中国家和经济转型国家普遍面临应对气候变 化、环境污染、实现可持续发展等严峻挑战。此文书能否顺利达 成并得到全面有效实施，在很大程度上取决于各方能否在资金、 技术和能力建设等发展中国家和经济转型国家普遍关心的问题 上达成共识。我们呼吁发达国家拿出政治意愿、承担应有责任， 为发展中国家和经济转型国家提供充足的资金支持。 成效评估和遵约机制（Evaluationandcompliance） 成效评估机制应根据各国国情，体现灵活性，避免对发展中 国家造成额外负担，且该机制应包括对资金、技术、能力建设支 持的全要素评估。 建立遵约机制的根本目的应是帮助存在履约障碍的缔约方解 决困难，因此，中国代表团建议遵约机制应具有非对抗性、促进 性和非惩罚性的特点，充分考虑发展中国家和经济转型国家履约 能力和履约资源需求，建立公正、公平和有效的遵约机制。

Title: Cook's Island
file_content: NATIONAL STATEMENT – COOK ISLANDS   UNEP INC1 MONDAY 28TH NOVEMBER 2022     E uu no te akau roa ka oki rai ki te akau roa . – The fish will always return to the reef it came from.       I am Tohoa Puna  a proud Cook Islander.  The Cook Islands have 15 islands scattered across 2  million  square kilometers of ocean.      Most of you are familiar with Small Island Developing States or SIDS, but not so familiar with our remote  outer islands far from the busy main  island, which is where  I come from. I hail from the outer islands in  the Cook Islands called  Aitutaki, Atiu, Penrhyn and Manihiki. Just 200 years ago, my ancestors lived off  the land and sea  sustainably , regenerating nature every day, where we give back more to nature than  what we take.     Today, we are taking more and more from nature  – a direction my ancestors would have never imag ined  for me - their tupuna, their generations . Today, my islands are overwhelmed with a plastic crisis that we   cannot manage. We have overflowing waste management facilities, full of toxic waste like plastics that  we bury, burn or live with. The shores of our remote islands are full of washed -up plastic waste from all  over the world – we are  the new co lonies of others waste.     At the same time, we co ntinue to receive plastics in almost every product, toxic or non -toxic, harming  our environment, our ecosystems, our food security  and our health and wellbeing .     I am here today because I believe in this global treaty  as our last hope to end plastic pollution . I believe  that you will do the right thing and do what is right. I am here to ask that we all work together to:     1. Develop a legally binding instrument that addresses the full life cycle of plastics – starting from   sourcing, upstreaming, mid -streaming and down -streaming ;  2. Support the development of a specific convention where core obligations and some control  measures appear in the body of the instrument , giving the governing body the possibility to be  adapted in the  future throughout adjustment, amendments and protocols;   3. Promote a non -toxic circular economy approaches to addressing plastics ;  Ensur e equitable, adequate means  to participate in the design of the instrument and  its  implementation , including support for capacity building and technology transfer.  This should be  a priority for Pacific SIDS who are on the front line of the plastics pollution cris is.  In conclusion, I stand  not only as  a Cook Isla nder I do so as represent, but as  youth, an indigenous  person,  and a woman,  fighting for our remote communities . We must not wait until we have killed off all  our mar ine life, replaced by plastic.  We must act now and make the bold steps to end plastic pollution.   E uu no te akau roa ka oki rai ki te akau roa . – The fish will always return to the reef it came from.  What  will the fish return t o reef or plastic?  Meitaki Atupaka , Thank you.

Title: India
file_content: Statement of India     1st Session of the i ntergovernmental negotiating committee (INC) to develop a legally binding  instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment.     Punta del Est e – Uruguay     India wants to intervene on the issue of ROP.  As was pointed out by many delegates  and the chair,  we had an informal group meeting on this while discussing rule 37. Many clarifications were  requested from the legal advisor of UNEP. During that interaction, the linkage between voting rights  and adoption of decisions was made clearer; exa mples were given with respect to UNFCCC and how  the voting rights have been used and the adoption of decisions has been done in different MEAs.  India has always been a strong advocate of decisions based upon consensus. While hearing those  deliberations in the informal group, the linkage between the two rules became evident. Also, the  implication between this linkage was not very clear at that time. Our delegation put forward that  rule 38.1 which talks about decision -making on substantive items by 2/3 majori ty may be considered  and bracketed and considered as decisions to be taken by consensus.

Title: Indonesia
file_content: 1       .  Indonesia’s Draft Statement  for Intergovernm ental Negotiating  Committee (INC)-1 on Plastic Pollution Period 2022 – 2024  Punta Del Este, Uruguay, Nov 28 to Dec 3, 2022       1. At the UN Environment  Assemb ly (UNEA-5), Leaders, Ministers, and other representatives  from UN Member  States endorsed a historic resolution that will address the full lifecycle of  plastic, including its production, design and disposal. The resolution establishes an  Intergovernment al Negotiating Committee (INC)-1, which will begin at Punta Del Este,  Uruguay, Nov 28 -Dec 3  2022, with great responsibility to draft a global legally binding  agreement  by the end of 2024.    2. The instrument  will cover alternatives to address the full lifecycle of plastics, the design of  reusable and recyclable products and materials, and the need for enhanced international  collaboration to facilitate access to technology, capacity building and scientific and technical  cooperation.    3. This is indeed a timely undertaking. UNEP reports that plastic production has soared from  2 million tons in 1950 to 348 million tons in 2017, becoming a global industry valued at   US$522.6 billion. By 2040, the number is expected to double in capacity. Plastic production  and pollution will impact climate change, nature loss, and pollution. The future of our earth.    4. Bearing in mind the mission it carries and the task ahead, the Government  of Indonesia  attaches great importance to the establishment  of INC. This will be our collective effort to  address the issue in a long-term approach, as well as to strengthen multilateral cooperation  in environment al and climate actions.    5. Indonesia has a national policy to address marine litter and plastic pollution, which has  been seriously implemented. For instance, within 2 years, Indonesia has succeeded to  reduce marine plastic litter by 28.50% - from 615,675 tons in 2018 to 440,200  tons in 2021.    6. From a regulatory framework, Indonesia has a National Plan of Action on Marine Plastic  Debris 2017-2025 and Indonesian Ocean Policy which serves as a legal a nd policy  framework to eradicate marine plastic pollution. We have regulated producers to reduce  the waste that comes from their products, packaging, and container as well as from plastic  bags. The action provides a roadmap  of waste reduction by Producer in the period of 2020-  2029 by implementing waste limitations through a re-design programme  and take back2  scheme for recycling and reusing with a target of 30% of the total production of goods and  packaging in 2029.    7. As a vast archipelagic country, we have also established several programme  actions to  combat marine litter and plastic pollution including building plastic waste facility on  Islands, building plastic waste treatment  facilities and applying ISO 14000 at  National  Fishery Ports, and providing SOP of sustainable fishery.    8. We also realize that there are opportunities that arise from sound management of plastic  waste. Indonesia produces around 68.5 million tons of waste every year, of which 17% are  plastic waste. They are potential for reuse and recycling process, including as materials in  industry or other economic activities. Indonesia, therefore, continues to innovate and  invent, to create an integrated circular economy process. This also includes initiatives in  financing or incentives, that enable contribution from everyone.    9. Such positive direction nonetheless, we understand that we still need to work even harder  and advance effective global collaboration, to achieve our target of reducing plastic litter.  Inviting other parties such as local authorities, businesses, NPO/NGO, and academia to join  the effort is a must.    10.
