In the interest of moving directly towards substantive negotiations, we have decided as a group to keep our national interventions brief and we will send the full texts in written.  Finally, GRULAC looks forward to working constructively with all stakeholders to advance substantially in the development of an instrument to end plastic pollution; safeguarding our environment and protecting human health for present and future generations.  I thank you.

Title: Oman on behalf of Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)
Solomon on behalf of High Ambition Coalition (HAC)
file_content: HAC Member States   Ministerial Joint Statement for INC -3    As the newest member of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution, the Solomon  Islands have the honor to deliver remarks on behalf  of the Coalition.    The High Ambition Coalition believe the Zero Draft, prepared by the Chair with support from  the Secretariat, provides a good basis to engage in negotiations  as outlined in our Ministerial  Joint Statement, which is supported by 61 Ministers  of the Coalition.    We reiterate  our call for binding  provisions  in the treaty  to restrain and reduce the  consumption and production of primary plastic polymers to sustainable levels;  eliminate and  restrict unnecessary, avoidable, or problematic plastics, as well as the plastic polymers,  chemical constituents and plastic products that are of particular concern due to their adverse  effects on the environment and human health ; increase the safe circularity of plastics in the  economy, guided by the waste hierarchy; manage plastic waste in an environmentally sound  and safe manner, and eliminate the release of plast ics, including microplastics, to air, water  and land.   The Coalition  continue s to call for binding provisions in the treaty to ensure reporting  and  transparency across the value chain of plastics  as well as for the mobilization of the means  of implementation from all sources that are necessary to deliver action on the ground to end  plastic pollution.   To enable timely and sufficient progress in the upcoming rounds of negotiations :  We Encourage  all INC Member  States  to immediate ly and constructively engage at INC -3 on  the basis of the Zero Draft, with the goal of making substantial progress on the text.   Call for  decisions at INC -3 to:     - Request the Chair, with support of the Secretariat, to prepare a first draft of the treaty  for consideration at INC -4, ba sed on discussions at INC -3;  - Launch  technical work in the intersessional period to assemble  the best available  science , data  and knowledge to inform the INC  in its delibera tions of the draft treaty  text.  We reiterate  our share d commitment to working with all INC M ember States , to build trust  and common understanding  in order  to deliver the ambitious , legally binding instrument  needed to achie ve our common goal of ending plastic pollution by 2040.   Thank you.

Title: Palau on behalf of Pacific Small Island Developing States (PSIDS)
file_content: PACIFIC SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES   UNITED NATIONS MEMBER STATES     Permanent Mission of Palau to the United Nations   880 Third Avenue, 12th Floor   New York, New York 10022  Phone no.: +1 (201) 523 – 6206   Email address: psidschair@gmail.com          Statement by the Pacific Small Island Developing States (PSIDS) at INC -3  Agenda Item 4     Nairobi, Kenya – 13 November 2023   [Check Against Delivery]     Final     Delivered by : Palau on behalf of the Pacific Small Island States     Mr. Chair,   Palau has the honor to speak on behalf of the 14 Pacific Small Island Developing States. We  align with the statement delivered by Samoa on behalf of AOSIS, and that of the Philippines   on behalf of the Asia Pacific group.     We express our gratitude to the people and government of Kenya for their hospitality. We are  also thankful to UNEP for welcoming us to the place where our process was initiated. We  commend your leadership and the continued outstanding support provided by t he INC  Secretariat, including in the intersession.     Mr. Chair,   We recognize the achievement of compiling the rich submissions provided by Members and  observers during the intersessional period. As the discussions on Saturday highlighted, and as  captured by the summary of the co -facilitators of contact group 3, there a re many elements that  need further discussions and unpacking. We look forward to further engaging on these matters  in the contact group under the modalities suggested by the chair.     The Pacific SIDS journeyed from the other side of the world to engage in INC 3, with some of  us traveling over 50 hours. This is a testament of our commitment to this process, reaffirmed  last week by our leaders at their annual Pacific Islands Forum Leader s meeting. We traveled  far because, as highlighted by the President of Kenya, 23 million tonnes of plastic are released  to the environment with more than half or 14 million tons of plastics ending up in our ocean  every year, and this is expected to double by 20301 under a business -as-usual scenario. We  cannot let this happen. Plastics entering the region are polluting our life support systems and    1 according to the report From Pollution to Solution: a global assessment of marine litter and  plastic pollution, released by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) in  October 2021    impacting our peoples’ cultural, economic and social ties to the environment and ocean,  including threatening our peoples’ food security and human health.  Plastic pollution also  undermines critical economic sectors of our societies, including tourism and fisheries.   Moreover, this problem, which starts in many cases far from our shores, generates tremendous  public costs, including for waste management. This is why we have prioritized our limited  resources to robustly engage here.     While we agree that the invention of plastic has helped improve lives around the world, this  cannot be an argument to lessen the ambition of the future treaty.     The modern world is addicted to plastic. This is a fact. The first step to stop addiction is to  admit there is a problem. We did that with UNEA 5/14. Now is the time to set the plan: quit  the addiction, change our habits, and clean up.     This is why this instrument must address the full lifecycle of plastic: with measures applicable  to upstream, midstream and downstream stages, including legacy plastics. And to ensure that  even the smallest States can fully engage and meet the strict oblig ations we are hoping to set,  by taking full account of the special circumstances of SIDS, including, among others, through  the provision of adequate means of implementation. This planetary crisis, which is  compounded by climate change and biodiversity loss , can lead to the demise of our human  race, and requires nothing less than a revolution. A revolution in how we produce, in how we  consume, and in what we tolerate. And the revolution must start now.     For the sake of time, I will refrain from detailed text on our priorities and positions. My group  is eager to start work on the substance tonight in the contact groups you have established, and  to use the 0 -draft as the basis for our discussions. I take th e opportunity to thank you and the  secretariat for producing this document well in advance to enable us to prepare. We look  forward to a constructive week which will inform the development of a first draft well in  advance of INC 4.     I thank you.

Title: African Group (AG)
file_content: 1   AFRICAN GROUP  CLOSING STATEMENT FOR THE   THIRD INTERGOVERNMENTAL NEGOTIATING COMMITTEE   19TH NOVEMBER  2023     Mr. Chair   1. It is a great honour for me to deliver this statement on behalf of the African  Group .     2. We wish to appreciate  and congratulate the  INC Chair,  the Co-facilitat ors,  Secretariat and members of the Committee  for the progress made during  this INC3 meeting.      Mr. Chair,   3. The Africa n group appreciates the contribution of Member States during  this INC meeting to ensure that we are on -track to deliver the much - needed objective of ending plastic pollution. We welcome all efforts to  ensure that the different views are taken into account . However,  the task  ahead is still enormous and therefore, there  is need to consider innovative  ways of moving forward without compromising the process and desired  outcomes.     4. African Group was looking forward to discussing  key areas that are critical  for furthering this work in INC4, including , among others, workstreams on   primary plastic polymers , chemicals and polymers of concern  in plastics   and problematic and avoidable plastic  product s, product design and  performance , transparency, tracking, monitoring and labelling, Extended  Producer Responsibility, existing plastic pollution and the financial  mechanism necessary  for successful implementation of the instrument.     5. We underscore the relevance of the science -policy interface and the need  to ensure balanced reflection of such information , and Member State   2   participation in this  process . We were looking forward to participating in a  face-to-face intersessional process through an Open -Ended Working  Group with at least one representative from each Member State.     6. We were expect ing the outcomes from the intersessional process to inform  further  negotiations on the ‘draft text  from INC 3 ’, with the understanding   that Member States will have an opportunity to add or remove text  during  the consideration of the draft at INC4 .    7. The Africa n Group reiterates the importance of addressing plastic pollution  across the lifecycle of plastics as mandated by UNEA resolution 5/14 and  ensuring that the relevant principles are operationalized in the respective  articles of the instrument.     8. The Africa n Group  reiterates the need for  a new, dedicated and standalone  financing mechanism  for the instrument , taking into account the  internationally agreed principles of common but differentiated  responsibilities ( CBDR ), equity, and respective capabilities, and would like  to underscore the importance of adequate, easy to access, sustainable  financial resources.     9. We look forward to further consideration of  mechanisms for cooperation  between parties and other relevant agencies for the provision of timely,  sustainable, comprehensive and adequate capacity -building and technical  assistance, to developing countries, in particular, to African countries, to  facilitate implementation of obligations under the new instrument.     10. The African Group also reite rates the need to ensure a just and fair  transition and clear linkages with the means of implementation. We  welcome the proposal to develop a multi stakeholder engagement plan  which takes care of regional economic integration, and pe ople in  vulnerable situations  including waste pickers, for building collective and  innovative solutions to combat plastic pollution .    3     11. The Africa n Group appreciates the location of the UNEP Headquarters on  African soil and would like to reiterate paragraph 88 of Rio+20 declaration  on "the future we want " that calls for the strengthening of UNEP  Headquarters . As such, we reiterate our support and ask other Member  States to also support  the idea of locating the Secretariat of the legally  binding instrument at UNEP headquarters .     12. In conclusion,  we welcome the i n-coming Chairperson  of the INC ,  Ambassador Luis Vayas  from Ecuador, and congratulate him upon your  election . We look forward to working with him to deliver the mandate of  this INC in line with UNEA resolution 5/14 .  I thank you .

Title: Latin American and Caribbean Group (GRULAC)
file_content: 65, Rue de Lausanne 1202 Genève   –   Tel. +41 (0) 22 577 63 44 urunugi@mrree.gub.uy     PERMANENT MISSION OF URUGUAY TO THE UNITED NATIONS OFFICE AND OTHER INTERNATIONAL  ORGANIZATIONS IN GENEVA    Closing Statement  Group of Latin America and the Caribbean Countries (GRULAC)  Third Session of the Intergovernmental Negotiation Committee (INC-3)  November 19, 2023 Nairobi, Kenya   Mr. Chair,   I am honored to deliver this statement on behalf of the Group of Latin America and the Caribbean Countries (GRULAC).  We wish to thank the Government and people of the Republic of Kenya for their warm hospitality and to express our heartfelt gratitude to Chair Amb. Gustavo Meza Cuadra, for the progress achieved during three sessions under his guidance. We also thank his team for their leadership, which greatly contributed to the significant progress at this session; and to the INC Secretariat and our Co-facilitators for tackling the arduous task of getting us to this juncture today.   We welcome the substantive discussions we had throughout the week as well as the agreement that the revised draft from the INC-3 will be the basis for our work at the INC-4.   The region also takes this opportunity to re-emphasize that we fully recognize that plastic pollution is a global and multifaceted problem, with environmental, socioeconomic and health dimensions. Therefore, we are happy that there is broad convergence within the Committee to advocate for a just and inclusive transition for all affected populations and groups in vulnerable situations, especially women, children, Indigenous Peoples, workers, waste pickers and other workers in informal and cooperative settings. We are especially grateful with their constructive engagement and contributions to this process.   Additionally, our region remains committed to the promotion and protection of Human Rights as a cross-cutting guiding principle for the interpretation and implementation of the instrument; together with a gender perspective; inter- and intra-generational equity; non-discrimination; access to Information, transparency and accountability; coherence among existing MEAs and the use of the best available science, traditional knowledge, knowledge of Indigenous Peoples and local knowledge systems.      65, Rue de Lausanne 1202 Genève   –   Tel. +41 (0) 22 577 63 44 urunugi@mrree.gub.uy   GRULAC is firmly of the view that intersessional work in this process is critical and as such, we regret not arriving at agreement, but we will continue working for its achievement on critical areas of interest, including Means of implementation. We are confident that intersessional work will deliver knowledge and information that would benefit the Committee throughout the negotiation to make the best decisions, while also helping to tackle the necessities of developing countries, taking into account the specific needs and special circumstances of Small Island Developing States (SIDS), which are disproportionately affected by the plastic pollution crisis in spite of contributing very little to its creation.   GRULAC would like to reiterate our dedication to developing an ambitious and effective International Legally Binding Instrument to end plastic pollution, including in the marine environment, with the view to protect human health and the environment.   Furthermore, we would like to welcome the incoming Chair who is also from our region, Amb. Luis Vayas Valdivieso, we pledge our support to you in your stewardship of this important process, as we endeavor to end plastic pollution. Ambassador, we wish you every success in this task.  Colleagues, GRULAC stands ready to continue our active and constructive engagement in this process, so that we can realize our collective goal as set out in the UN Resolution 5/14.    I thank you.

Title: Pacific Small Island Developing States (PSIDS)
file_content: PACIFIC SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES UNITED NATIONS MEMBER STATES Permanent Mission of Palau to the United Nations  880 Third Avenue, 12th Floor  New York, New York 10022 Phone no.: +1 (201) 523 – 6206  Email address: psidschair@gmail.com Closing Statement by the Pacific Small Island Developing States (PSIDS) Nair obi, Kenya - 19 November 2023 Delivered by: Palau [Check against Delivery] Thank you Chair , I have the honor to deliver these remarks on behalf of the 14 Pacific Small Island Developing  States and we align with the statement delivered by Samoa on behalf of the AOSIS. First, the PSIDS congratulate Ambassador Luis Vayas Valdivieso on his election. We are  confident that he will skillfully steer this process to achieve an outcome that we are all working  towards. We take this opportunity to express our gratitude to you, Ambassador Gustavo  Meza-Cuadra Velasquez, and your team, for your leadership and hard work in the first three INC  sessions. We also express our sincere thanks to the secretariat for their tireless efforts to accommodate  Members’ requests. We also express our appreciation to all staff of the UNON building, for all  their hard work in supporting our efforts over the last two weeks. We express our gratitude to all Members and observers for the constructive and enriching  discussions. While there are still many areas needing further deliberations, we are inspired by the  Nairobi spirit as it provides the impetus to take this to the end and fulfill the mandate given by  UNEA 5/14 . Chair ,  We have made significant progress since the inaugural INC-1 session in Punta del Este one year  ago, and we should commend all delegates for reaching the halfway mark. INC-3 gave us the  opportunity to share robust discussions on progressing the zero-draft and mobilizing our efforts  to secure a binding instrument that appropriately responds to the global plastic crisis, as it  continues to threaten human health and the environment. In that regard, we agree with the way  forward as you outlined: we fully support using the merged texts with relevant formatting, as the  starting point and basis for textual negotiations at INC4.On Monday , we shared our group’ s strong commitment to this important process, which has  strengthened with this week’ s engagements. We look forward to more constructive discussions in  Ottawa. In the meantime, we wish you good rest, a safe journey home, and happy holidays. Asante sana.

Title: India
file_content: Intervention of India Rules of Procedure - Third Meeting of Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee   Thank you Chair At the outset, we would like to thank the Government of Kenya for their warm hospitality in welcoming the delegates for the third meeting of INC.  We would also like to thank the INC Chair, INC Secretariat and UNEP for organization of this meeting.  India has always been committed to the principle of consensus in decision making in respect of substantive matters under multilateral environmental agreements as this reiterates collective decision-making and reflects shared responsibilities and commitment.      At the outset, our delegation would like to reiterate that all the decisions on substantive issues shall be taken by consensus and that Rule 38 (1) shall not be invoked till the final adoption of Rules of procedure by INC. We may recall that INC 2 had spent a substantial time on adopting the interpretative statement, in this regard. In this regard, our delegation, would like to seek assurance from INC Chair that the Rule 38.1 shall not be invoked during the INC 3 meeting, in the spirit of moving ahead with the deliberations on substantive issues.  We would like to reiterate that consensus based decision making is indispensable to ensure the fairness, equity, inclusiveness, shared responsibility and collective commitments and actions, in all multilateral processes. Thank you Mr Chair.

Title: Republic of Korea
file_content: Check against delivery   Intervention by Amb. H.E. Cho Hong Sik,   Head of Delegation of the Republic of Korea,   On Agenda item “Future Meetings” at INC -3 Plenary     Thank you, Chair,     First of all, t he Republic of Korea  would like to extend deep appreciation  for your excellent leadership  in advancing this negotiation process as  the  Chair of the INC. We would  also like to express  our sincere  gratitude to the  government of Kenya  for their warm hospitality and to th e Secretariat for  their preparation for the meeting.     Tackling plastic pollution is a high priority  for President Yoon Suk Yeul .  President Yoon has expressed his strong commitment to address plastic  pollution at G7 Hiroshima Summit and provide strong support for this  process by hosting INC -5.    As such, the  Republic of Korea  is delighted to announce that the INC -5 will  take place in the beautiful city of B usan,  the second largest city in Korea,  from 25 November to First of December , 2024.      Korea takes pride in Busan ’s extensive experience in hosting various  international events and the city’s capacity to provide large -scale  accommodation facilities,  convenient transportation  and exceptional  conference infrastructure. Busan has  also transformed itself into a green  smart city by establishing a plastic resources circulation cluster to foster  technological innovation and enhance network infrastructure  among other Check against delivery   things .    Furthermore, Busan is a candidate city to  host the World Expo 2030 with a  strong commitment to  making it a single -use-plastic -free E xpo - another  aspect that highlights Busan’s uniqueness as a host city for  the INC-5.     Busan, as the venue of INC -5 and, hopefully, the venue for the World Expo  2030, will make history by successfully concluding this important process  and raising awareness of the plastic pollution.       The Republic of Korea is fully committed to ensur ing the success of the  INC-5 and pleased to play a conducive  role in shaping an international  environmental treaty to end plastic pollution and promote the circular  economy.     We look forward to welcoming  all delegations in Busan  next year .        Thank you.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Angola
file_content: Mr. PRESIDENT;   AS THIS IS THE FIRST TIME THAT THE REPUBLIC OF  ANGOLA TAKES  THE FLOOR AT THE  INC-3, WE WOULD LIKE  TO THANK THE GOVERNMENT OF KENYA AND ITS PEOPLE  FOR CREATING THE CONDITIONS FOR THIS MEETING AND  THE WARM WELCOME, AS USUAL  IN AFRICA.     WE ALSO WANT TO THANK THE SECRETARIAT AND THE  DONORS FOR THEIR  EFFORTS TO MAKE AVAILABLE  THE  GOOD WORKING CONDITIONS  WE HAVE.       Mr. PRESIDENT   THE CONFERENCE OF AFRICAN ENVIRONMENT MINISTERS  (AMCEN) THAT MET IN ADDIS ABABA, ETHIOPIA, BETWEEN   14th  AND 18 th OF AUGUST THIS YEAR, DECIDED :    “TO CALL ON THE MEMBER STATES TO STEP UP MEASURES  TO TACKLE PLASTIC POLLUTION, INCLUDING IN THE  MARINE ENVIRONMENT, THAT ADDRESS THE FULL  LIFECYCLE APPROACH OF PLASTICS, INCLUDING THE  DEVELOPMENT OF NATIONAL ACTION PLANS, WHILE  ENSURING A JUST AND INCLUSIVE TRANSITION ”;   THEREFORE, IT IS OUR COMMITMENT , AS AN AFRICAN  COUNTRY TO DO EVERYTHING SO THAT THE INTERESTS OF  AFRICA AND ITS PEOPLE ARE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT IN  THIS NEW INSTRUMENT THAT AIMS TO ELIMINATE THE  IMPACTS OF PLASTIC POLLUTION ON HEALTH, SOCIO - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND THE ENVIRONMENT,  TAKING I NTO ACCOUNT NATIONAL CAPACITIES AND  PRIORITIES;   ANGOLA, AS A COASTAL COUNTRY  IS ALREADY FAC ING  THE NEGATIVE IMPACTS OF PLASTIC, BOTH MARINE AND  TERRESTRIAL POLUTION.   AS STATED BY THE AFRICA GROUP , WE CALL FOR THIS  INSTRUMENT TO TAKE INTO ACCOUNT THE NATIONAL CIRCUMSTANCES AND ENSURE A FAIR, EQUITABLE, AND  INCLUSIVE TRANSITION, FOR AFFECTED POPULATIONS,  WITH SPECIAL CONSIDERATION  FOR PEOPLE IN  VULNERABLE SITUATIONS, ESPECIALLY WOMEN,  CHILDREN, Y OUTH AND WASTE PICKERS.   WE ADD OUR VOICE TO THE CALL MADE BY AFRICAN  ENVIRONMENT MINISTERS , ASKING MEMBER STATES TO  SUPPORT THE HOSTING OF THE SECRETARIAT  OF THE  INSTRUMENT ON PLASTIC POLLUTION  AT THE  HEADQUARTERS OF THE UNITED NATIONS ENVIRONMENT  PROGRAMME , HERE IN NAIROBI;     WE ARE CONVINCED OF THE SUCCE SS OF THIS MEETING,  WITH THE SCIENTIFIC CAPACITY AND WISDOM OF OUR  LEADERS AROUND THE SAME TABLE, FOR THE WELL - BEING OF OUR PEOPLES, WITHOUT PLASTIC POLLUTION.     THANK YOU VERY MUCH

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Argentina
file_content: Tercer Período de Sesiones - Comité intergubernamental de negociación para elaborar  un instrumento internacional jurídicamente vinculante en materia de contaminación  por plásticos, incluso en el medio marino     INTERVENCION DELEGACION ARGENTINA     Tema 4 - Preparación de un instrumento internacional jurídicamente vinculante sobre  la contaminación por plásticos, incluso en el medio marino     Sr. Presidente,     En primer lugar, la Delegación argentina agradece al Gobierno de Kenya por acoger esta  tercera reunión del Comité Intergubernamental de Negociación para elaborar un  instrumento internacional sobre la contaminación por plásticos, incluida en el medio  marino .    La Delegación argentina se asocia a la intervención del GRULAC, pronunciada por la  distinguida Delegación de Uruguay.     Sr. Presidente,     La Argentina estima que el proyecto preliminar de instrumento internacional elaborado   sobre la base de las consideraciones presentadas por las Delegaciones y puesto a  consideración constituye una buena base para las negociaciones.     Desde la perspectiva argentina, el proceso de negociación de un futuro instrumento para  atender la contaminación por plásticos debe ser guiado por un enfoque de derechos  humanos consistente con la Agenda 2030 y la prioridad de poner fin a la pobreza y el  hambre.     En esta línea, el futuro instrumento debería velar también por la protección de la salud  humana y el medio ambiente de los efectos adversos de la contaminación por plásticos  a lo largo de todo su ciclo de vida jerarquizando las opciones de gestión de resid uos.    En vista de ello, la naturaleza técnica  de estas negociaciones hace imprescindible recurrir  a la mejor ciencia disponible para que los compromisos que se asuman puedan luego  cumplirse.     La Argentina también está convencida que a los fines de garantizar la coherencia y  consistencia con el conjunto de normas internacionales, el futuro instrumento debe  guardar conformidad con las reglas de la Organización Mundial del Comercio y con la  Conven ción sobre el Derecho del Mar.     En este sentido, la Argentina reafirma la vigencia del principio de responsabilidades  comunes pero diferenciadas dadas las desigualdades notorias en el desarrollo de los  países.    El instrumento que se acuerde debe recoger también el principio de responsabilidad  extendida del productor por la gestión  de los residuos y/o el financiamiento de la misma.     La Argentina también estima relevante que el instrumento que se acuerde incluya el  concepto de transición justa valorando la importante labor de los recicladores de base y  de las cooperativas, actores fundamentales para dar respuesta a la problemática de l a  contaminación por plásticos.     Para asegurar el éxito en la implementación del instrumento que se debe contar recursos  financieros nuevos y adicionales provistos principalmente por los países desarrollados,  que sean canalizados a través de un fondo específico establecido al efecto, a fi n de  volverlos predecibles y accesibles.     Sr. Presidente,     Urge iniciar las negociaciones sobre un instrumento a la mayor brevedad y por ello, la  Argentina apoya la creación de los 3 grupos de contacto propuestos, sin dilaciones.     La Argentina espera que en esta tercera reunión se concluya la primera lectura del  proyecto de instrumento y que el próximo Presidente cuente con mandato para  presentar una versión revisada que incorpore los resultados de las deliberaciones de esta  semana.     Finalmente, desde la perspectiva argentina también resulta perentorio acordar un  trabajo intersesional para avanzar en la determinación de los principios que serán la base  operativa del instrumento, las definiciones que proveerán el entendimiento común, y los  medios de implementación imprescindibles para hacer realidad lo acordado y poner fin  a la contaminación por plásticos.     Muchas gracias
