Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Australia
file_content: Australian Government written intervention – Agenda item 4     Australia thank s the Government of Kenya for hosting the third Intergovernmental Negotiating  Committee meeting.       Australia remains firmly committed to negotiating an ambitious legally binding instrument by the  end 2024 to end plastic pollution. We are at the mid -way point in our negotiations, and we are  mindful of the need to make considerable progress this week if we are to complete our work by the  end of 2024.        We strongly support focusing our efforts this week on substantive discussions to progress the  development of the draft instrument. The Zero Draft  represents a sound outline for us to commence   our discussions on a legally binding instrument, building  on our discussions in previous INCs. We  thank the Chair and the Secretariat for their work and look forward to hearing and discussing views  from Members on the text, including where it might benefit from amendment, additions and  expansions.        This delegation remains committed to the mandate of UNEA resolution 5/14, that is, to develop an  international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment,  based on a comprehensive approach that addresses the full l ife cycle of plastic.        We are pleased to see that the Zero Draft  includes global legally binding options to enable us to  develop provisions across the full life cycle of plastics. We consider this necessary to facilitate our  shift from the current linear plastic economy to a safe circular economy where plastic is consi dered a  valued resource that continues to circulate safely through the economy. The Zero Draft also provides  a good basis to develop:    1. A clear objective in line with the UNEA resolution, to end plastic pollution, to protect human  health and the environment, based on a comprehensive approach that addresses the full life  cycle of plastics.            2. Binding provisions to provide certainty and global harmonisation in our transition to a safe  circular economy for plastics.    3. Robust implementation mechanisms, which  will be essential to achieve the instruments’  objective, assess its effectiveness, and fund and build capacity.       Australia looks forward to further discussions to develop provisions in contact groups  this week.  We  seek to:   • ensure actions are targeted on those products and activities that contribute the most to  plastic pollution;   • bolster provisions relating to monitoring of plastic pollution, so the governing body can  assess whether the objectives of the treaty are being achieved;   • ensure our actions are based on the best available science  and take into account Indigenous  Peoples ’ knowledge, science and practices  on the basis of prior informed consent ; and   • ensure complementarity with other multilateral environmental agreements and avoid   duplication.      We consider that intersessional work will be needed so we can arrive at INC -4 in Ottawa having  made significant progress. Australia strongly advocates for INC -3 to deliver a clear and detailed  mandate to commence intersessional work on priority areas prior to INC -4, which we look forward  to discussing with colleagues this week.      We have come prepared to discuss these important issues, and to work towards preparation of a  comprehensive and enhanced draft of the instrument in time for INC -4.      We look forward to working with all INC Members over the coming days towards our goal of  developing an ambitious legally binding instrument to end plastic pollution.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Bahrain
file_content: السيدات والسادة .. السالم عليكم ورحمة هللا وبركاته    أود في البداية باسم حكومة بالدي أن أتقدم بالشكر الجزيل جمهورية كينيا على االستضافة، والسكرتارية على   الجهود التي بذلت لإلعداد لهذا االجتماع عالوة على االجتماعات السابقة.     وتود مملكة البحرين أن تعبر عن  اعتزازها بالجهود التي بذلتها كافة الدول لتنفيذ قرار جمعية األمم المتحدة   للبيئة (5  -  14   ) لوضع صك قانوني ملزم لمنع التلوث البالستيكي بما في ذلك البيئة البحرية من خالل اجتماعات لجنة التفاوض الحكومية.     وتؤكد مملكة البحرين دعمها لهذا القرار وأهميته لمنع التلوث البالستيكي الذي بات يمثل تحديا كبيرا أمام كل   الدول في العالم، ولذلك بدأت المملكة باتخاذ عددا من اإلجراءات على المستوى الوطني منذ العام  2019    انسجاما مع أهداف القرار.    إننا في مملكة البحرين ندعم كل ما ورد في كلمة دول مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية من خالل ممثل   سلطنة عمان ... باإلضافة إلى كلمة المملكة العربية السعودية وخصوصا ما يتعلق بالمسودة الصفرية .....  ونؤكد الحاجة لهذا الصك القانوني األخذ بعين االعتبار حتى يكون قابال للتنفيذ عبر كافة الدول في العام اآلتي:    1-  .تفادي فرض سياسات يصعب تنفيذها على المستوى الوطني وتؤدي لتبعات اقتصادية واجتماعية  2-  .تركيز نطاق الصك على اإلدارة السليمة للمخلفات البالستيكية  3-  .ضمان تحقيق االنتقال العادل، وهو أهم مرتكزات قرار جمعية األمم المتحدة للبيئة  4-   توفير الظروف الموائمة للدول النامية لتمكينها من التقنيات الحديثة والمعرفة للوفاء بالتزاماتها تجاه االتفاقية.   5-   اعتبار نهج االقتصاد الدائري كركيزة أساسية لمعالجة التلوث البالستيكي كأداة فعالة لإلدارة السليمة للمخلفات البالستيكية.   وختاما، فإننا نتفق مع مداخالت  الوفود األخرى التي تؤكد على أهمية إصدار توجيه واضح لفرق االتصال  إلنتاج مسودة محدثة بناءً على المداخالت والمناقشات التي سيتم تقديمها خالل الجلسة، دون تعديالت أو  تفسيرات.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Bangladesh
file_content: Member country 3 minutes only     Respected Chair   Excellency    Distinguished Delegates   Ladies and Gentlemen   At the  outset, Bangladesh would like to thank the Kenyan government for hosting the event and   also acknowledges the hard work of secretariat for this beautiful arrangement.   Bangladesh appreciates the  options and formations that have  been provided in the zero draft. We  firmly believe that it would be fine -tuned through the active participation of the delegates in the  coming seven days.   Dear colleagues   As a member of the Asia Pacific group, Bangladesh fully agree  with the points raised by our  regional  group. At the same time we would lik e to draw your attention to the  most important   necessity of the downstream countries .   Dear Friends ,  As you all know that Plastic can easily cross the administrative boundary without any intervention.  It has been observed  that plastics  coming from  upstream countries to downstream countries  through international rivers  causing the devastating impact to the human health and ecosystems   including the adjacent marine environment .   Since downstream countries have been suffering a lot and compelled  to allocate a significant  amount of money from its annual budget to manage this pollution, so, they deserve more attention  compared to other countries with general needs. I repeat, as usual support may not be sufficient.   Dear Delegates ,  It is easily  understandable that High income  or upper middle income  countries  may have the  technical and financial competency to solve the issue whereas lower and lower middle income   downstream countries are in serious problem of intercepting those plastic load. Thus,  resulting the   pollution of  adjacent marine environment.     Mr. Chair   Since contact group III is assig ned to solve the undiscussed issue s of INC -2. Therefore,  Bangladesh urges to consider this  very important  issue to be discussed in that group.   That’s all from our side. Thank you.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Brazil
file_content: BRAZIL – ITEM 4     Thank you very much, Mr. Chair.   As it is the first time my delegation takes the floor, I would like to thank the Government of  Kenya and UNEP for hosting us this week in Nairobi for such an important meeting.   Brazil reaffirms its commitment to an ambitious legally binding instrument to end plastic  pollution, including in the marine environment, with a view to protecting the environment and  human health. This reflects the commitment of our government to the environment , to public  health , to the protection and promotion of human rights and, from a broader perspective, to  sustainable development in its social, economic and environmental dimensions .    In that spirit, we thank you, Mr. Chair, for providing a zero draft for our agreement. W e will  engage in the negotiations at this session with a view to achieving effective solutions to address  plastic pollution th roughout  the life cycle of plastics , always bearing in mind the needs and  realities of developing countries. We want to contribute, as much as possible, to solutions that  effectively lead us to sustainable waste management accessible to all developing countries, EPR  schemes  and activities that promote reuse, recycling and repair of plastics and plastic products ;  legacy plastic, including i n the marine environment; just trans ition; and the variety of issues that  are already included in the zero draft.   Still bearing in mind the conditions of developing countries, we particularly thank you for your  sensibility to the size of our delegations and your proposal to avoid more than two contact group  meeting or more than two informal consultation meetings acros s INC at the same time.   Mr. Chair,   We firmly believe that the implementation of the instrument will be successful if implemented  through the lens of sustainable development. The broad issues we are dealing with in these  negotiations should be  interconnected  with all Agenda 2030 Sustainable Development Goals.   This takes me to the need to recognize the essential environmental services waste pickers  provide in many countries and to economically value that as such, so they are  empowered as an  active actor in the recycle chain of materials , including plastics . If waste pickers are di scouraged  to perform their jobs because they don’t have access to economically viable recyclable  materials, the environment suffers; when we ensure their income and their jobs, they contribute  to the protection of the environment. We nee d to work to put in place policies with incentives  for them and that duly recognize the ir contribution to a plastic pollution -free economy . Let’s  achieve not only a clean and healthy environment, but also prosperity for all.    To have an effective  instrumen t, we will need to consider  how we can really implement it. That  is why Brazil again underlines the crucial need for this INC to mandate intersessional work on  financing, given the fact that without robust means of implementation the final outcome of our  negotiations will only be a dream . The financial mechanism will also need to consider a  cooperation mechanism through which capacity -building, technical and scientific cooperation  and technology transfer are provided  to developing countries, which can be facilitated by a  clearing -house platform.   Countries will depart from very different starting -points, with developing countries way behind   developed countries . When thinking of creative  solutions to attend the needs of developing  countries, we need to  count on the lead of developed nations who command larger financial  and technological resources. We have common but differentiated responsibilities for the  environmental problems we are trying to solve and we count on international cooperation to be  able to effectively deal with them.   We also understand th at intersessional work on technical issues will be needed. But we have to  be clear that we cannot support any intersessional work on technical issues if not accompanied  by intersessional work on financing. We cannot restrict ourselves to build ing the “what” of our  regime if we don’t dedicate ourselves to planning the “how” we are going to implement it.   Mr. Chair,   Still on the effectiveness  of the instrument , Brazil reaffirms that all State Members need to be  onboard. We need global action and global solutions to a global problem and of a transboundary  nature. For that we need the political commitment of all countries. That is why this instrument  can only be adopted on the basis of consensus.    Regarding the way forward at this INC session, we welcome the  efforts  by the Secretariat to  produce the Synthesis Report, which has been very useful to kickstart discussions . Given the  broad debate we conduct back home with government and stakeholder s across  all our society,  and the fact that the Report was distributed only around two weeks ago, we need to reserve our  position , at this point,  on any text that may be reflected in a new draft  stemming from the Report  at this point.   We also need to refer to the options on possible provisions on trade -related measures because  any rules we might consider must be aligned with Principle 12 of the Rio Declaration, which  states that trade policy measures for environmental purposes should not constitute a means of  arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination or a disguised restriction on international trade. Such  discriminatory measures tend to lead to undesired economic effects that  are, in turn, conducive  to undesired environmental effects as well.  These are only general and initial points on the work we will engage on under item 4. We will  manifest our positions in more detail, as suggested by you in your Reflection Note, in the contact  groups which will be established in this meeting.   Thank you.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Cambodia
file_content: Remarks by Delegation from Cambodia   at  Third Session  of the Intergovernmental  Negotiating  Committee to  Develop  an  International  Legally  Binding  Instrument  on Plastic Pollution , Including  in the  Marine  Environment  (INC -3)  14 November 2023     -Chair, Distinguished Delegates and Colleagues.     -Since this is the first time that Cambodia takes the floor, please allow me to start by  expressing our sincere thank s to the Government of Kenya for their kind hospitality  and  excellent arrangement of the INC -3 Meeting . We would also like to thank the INC Secretariat  for their support and extensive preparations to make the INC -3 Meeting  possible.     -INC-3 is considered to be a very important platform in the negotiations. After INC -3, we  will be meeting together again in the upcoming INC -4 and INC -5 to be held next year in  Canada and Republic of Korea (ROK) respectively to conclude this instrument. As one of  the Member States that has been involved in this negotiation from the beginning, Cambodia  looks forward to fruitful discussions over the course of the week on the substance of the  instrument .     -To ensure the effective discussion with our limited time, the INC -3 should focus on  discussing the zero -draft and work towards scaling  down the options, proposing  improvements, and addressing gaps in the text. We are going to meet  at contact group  meetings and we h ope to see Member States to provide  comments/inputs to the zero draft  with the purpose to address the plastic pollution effectively. Anyway, we know that it is easy  to come to a conclusion  on the proposed options but it would be possible with our  collaborative spirit.     -It is well understood that developed countries may have both the technical and financial  competency to solve the plastic pollution issue whereas the developing countries are still  facing challenges in addressing this serious issue of plastic pollution so capacity building,  financial support, and technology transfer mechanisms must be ready to provide any  necessary support from the developed to developing countries.      -Furthermore , Cambodia is committed to work closely with all Member States as we progress  our efforts in this negotiation to build an effective implementation of instrument when it is  concluded. We also wish to express our alignment with the statements delivered by the Asia  Pacific Group (APG) and the Coordinating Body of the Seas of East Asia (COBSEA).     -Thank you very much Mr. Chair

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Cameroon
file_content: Thank you Mr. Chair for giving me the floor.   My delegation aligns itself with the statement delivered by the distinguished  representative of Ghana on behalf to the African Group.   A titre national, qu’il me soit permis de saluer l’hospitalité légendaire du peuple  kenyan et de son Gouvernement, qui ont bien voulu accueillir cette troisième  session de fond du Comité Intergouvernemental de Négociation.   Permettez -moi également de vous adresser, Monsieur le Président, nos  félicitations pour la conduite éclairée du processus. Sous votre supervision  avisée, les délégations ont reçu du Secrétariat une ébauche du projet de traité  sur la pollution plastique, no tamment dans le milieu marin. Ce document  constitue une bonne base de travail. Le rapport de synthèse y compris son  résumé constitue des ressources d’une précieuse utilité pour nos discussions.  Comme par le passé, ma délégation est prête à s’engager de man ière  constructive dans les négociations avec toutes les parties.   Monsieur, le Président la pollution plastique constitue un fléau pour les sociétés  contemporaines. Mon pays le Cameroun est frappé de plein fouet par ce  phénomène. Afin de provoquer des changements transformatifs pour inverser  la tendance, le Cameroun a ét é parmi les pionniers pour mettre en place une  réglementation ambitieuse en matière de lutte contre la pollution plastique.  Seulement, ce dispositif est confronté à de redoutables défis parmi lesquels le  déficit des moyens financiers mais aussi les mouveme nts transfrontaliers des  produits plastiques.   Le Cameroun adhère pleinement à la Résolution 5/14. Dans cette  perspective, nous souhaitons que l’instrument à adopter cible la pollution  plastique dans la pluralité de ses dimensions et consacre des dispositions  spécifiques au milieu marin. Il doit mettre  l’accent sur  le cycle de vie complet du  plastique, le problème des additifs et autres substances chimiques utilisées dans  le processus, la gestion des stocks de plastiques existant dans l’environnement  et dans le milieu marin, les dispositions relatives a ux plastiques problématiques  ou non nécessaires, les aspects spécifiques à la pollution de l’environnement  marin par les plastiques, la prise en compte des besoins spécifiques des pays en  développement, la question des incitations et du développement des  alternatives, la promotion de l’économie circulaire non toxique… A ceci il faut  ajouter les financements conséquents, prévisibles et accessibles, le transfert de  la technologie du plastique et le renforcement des capacités.  Cet instrument devrait s’adosser sur Les principes de Rio, le principe  pollueur -payeur, le principe des responsabilités communes mais différenciées,  le principe de la responsabilité élargie du producteur, les principes qui  gouvernent la pollution marine, l es principes garantissant la transparence,  l’accès à l‘information en matière d’environnement y compris les informations  sur les produits chimiques entrant dans la composition de chaque plastique.   Nombre de ces points ont été abordés dans les documents de travail mais  beaucoup reste à faire.   Pour terminer, je salue une fois de plus l’esprit qui a présidé à l’élaboration de  l’ébauche du projet de traité sur la pollution plastique, notamment dans le milieu  marin et suis convaincu que dans le cadre des échanges inclusifs, constructifs et  volontar istes, des améliorations lui seront apportées dans le respect du mandat  assigné aux délégués par la Résolution 5/14.     Je vous remercie

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Canada
file_content: Mr. Chair, Distinguished Delegates, Excellencies, Colleagues,     Canada appreciate s the collaborative spirit that permeates this gathering,  building from  the spirit of Nairobi,  and extend gratitude to the Chair, the INC Secretariat, and the  Republic  of Kenya for their dedicated efforts in plann ing INC -3.    Canada eagerly supports transitioning into contact groups  this evening  to delve into our  crucial negotiations. Our commitment to the United Nations Environment Assembly  resolution  propels us to urgently address this crisis through inclusive, sustainable, and  effective solutions.     INC-3 marks a pivotal juncture, reaching the halfway mark of planned sessions and  navigating the zero draft. Canada views the zero draft as a strong  foundation for mutual  exchange as we progress in shaping this instrument.     Canada looks forward to an instrument that will facilitate a systems change and support  concrete and complementary actions across the full lifecycle of plastics – by enabling  sustainable production, consumption and circularity, strengthening plastic waste  management, and addressing the causes and sources of plastic pollution. An effective  instrument should also emphasize common legally binding provisions and control  measures as well as set the framework for achieving a shared objective  to end plastic  pollut ion. In order to set the path for conclusion of negotiations by the end of 2024,  Canada supports the Chair’s scenario note and aligns itself with the high ambition  coalition statement from over 60 countries from all regions, notably for the Chair to  develop  a complete first draft text for consideration at the fourth  negotiation  session  in  Ottawa.     Committed to collaboration, inclusivity, and constructive negotiation, we stand ready to  work collectively towards substantive discussions, aiming for significant progress in  developing an ambitious and effective legally binding instrument on plastic pollu tion.    Thank you.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Chile
file_content: Intervención de Apertura   13/11/23   Muchas gracias Señor Presidente,   Al ser esta la primera vez que Chile toma la palabra, quisiera expresar nuestro agradecimiento  al  gobierno de Kenia por acoger esta tercera reunión del INC. También  a la Secretaría, por el trabajo  realizado para la preparación de esta importante reunión. Chile quisiera asociar su intervención  a lo señalado por la delegación de Uruguay a nombre de GRULAC.   Señor Presidente,   Nos encontramos ante una Triple crisis ambiental y planetaria  en materia de  cambio climático,  pérdida de biodiversidad y contaminación -especialmente por plásticos - y que exige acciones  urgentes y mancomunadas  entre todos los actores  internacionales  con la finalidad de poder  hacer frente a esta grave situación internacional.   Chile cree que este tratado  debe  regul ar de forma comprensiva todo el ciclo del plástico,  basándose en una  jerarquía de residuos entre prevenir, reducir, reusar, reciclar y eliminar.  Este  es un enfoque clave para Chile.   Agradecemos, Sr. Presidente, la elaboración de este Borrador Cero que en opinión de Chile  recoge adecuadamente los elementos discutidos durante las rondas de negociación anteriores  y  las visiones presentadas por los Estados.   Entre ellos, Chile quisiera destacar :  - Que u na implementación exitosa requerirá de mecanismos que faciliten la transferencia  tecnológica y apoyo financiero para países en desarrollo , sin distinción,  en consideración  de sus respectivas capacidades.   - El enfoque de derechos humanos y de transición justa debiesen ser transversales en este  Tratado. Los cambios que deriven de éste deben crear  oportunidades de trabajo dignos,  sin dejar a nadie atrás , y con especial consideración de grupos vulnerables, y recicladores  de base .  - La importancia de que los principios de responsabilidad extendida del productor sean  recogidos en las disposiciones del tratado, ya que promueven la innovación para avanzar  en la circularidad de los productos y contribuyen a la reducción de residuos.    - Chile apoya firmemente la toma de decisiones basadas en la ciencia , y que l a investigación  debe informar al proceso y también su implementación para que el instrumento pueda  irse adaptando  al nuevo conocimiento científico.   - Quisiéramos destacar la importancia del componente oceánico de este futuro Acuerdo:  Chile tiene una de las zonas costeras más extensas y diversas del mundo, y al igual que  muchos países, ve directamente cómo la contaminación por plásticos afecta  negativame nte a la biodiversidad marina,  Asimismo, Chile apoya el desarrollo de trabajo intersesional, el que debe ser realizado de manera  inclusiva, con representación regional, balance de género y  contar con un objetivo concreto y  acotado.  En opinión de Chile, es importante que este trabajo  pueda contribuir al  establecimiento  de criterios sobre polímeros y criterios de preocupación, y en medios de implementación , entre  otras materias .  En este sentido, y siguiendo el criterio de inclusividad llevado hasta ahora, Chile reconoce los  importantes aportes de la comunidad científica, la Sociedad Civil, el sector industrial , la  academia, organizaciones no gubernamentales  y los pueblos originarios.  Los derechos de acceso  a la información, participación y justicia sin duda nos apoyarán  ante el  enorme reto que tenemos  por delante, generando un diálogo productivo y constante para beneficio de todos y todas.   Sr. Presidente,   Queda mucho trabajo por hacer. Por ello, Chile agradece y apoya que se mantengan dos grupos  de trabajo y que se cree un tercero, pero reconoce la necesidad de tener claridad con respecto a  cómo van a funcionar los Grupos de trabajo, con miras a que no haya  una duplicación de  esfuerzos, y considerando una participación de todos los Estados Parte en este proceso .  Con ello, estamos agradecidos por su liderazgo en este proceso hasta ahora, y esperamos que  estos días en Nairobi nos permitan avanzar en este importante trabajo .  Muchas gracias,  Señor Presidente.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Colombia
file_content: Nov 1 3th, 2023   INTERVENCIÓN DE APERTURA DE COLOMBIA – INC3 Punto 4 del  Orden del Día   Nairobi, 13 de noviembre de 2023     Gracias, señor Presidente.     Colombia se adhiere a las declaraciones leídas por Uruguay, en nombre del  GRULAC, y por Islas Salomón, en nombre de la Coalición de Alta Ambición  para poner fin a la contaminación por plásticos.     Colombia también se vale de esta ocasión para agradecer la hospitalidad  de la gente y del Gobierno de Kenia, por hospedar la presente sesión del  Comité. Gracias también a usted, señor Presidente, y a la Secretaría, por  responder cabalmente al mandato otorg ado en París de elaborar un  borrador del instrumento que incorporara las diferentes visiones  expresadas por los miembros del Comité.     En el transcurso de esta semana, Colombia participará constructivamente  en el debate de los diferentes grupos de contacto, para concretar en el  texto del instrumento las siguientes prioridades:     En primer lugar, debemos establecer objetivos y estándares comunes a los  que se obliguen todas las partes de manera que los impactos  transfronterizos y regresivos de la contaminación por plásticos puedan ser  prevenidos, mitigados y remediados, al tiempo qu e se garantizan los  medios de implementación necesarios para que nuestros países puedan  emprender los elementos más ambiciosos de este instrumento.     En segundo lugar, debemos poder abordar las fallas en todo el ciclo de vida  de los plásticos que permiten fugas y descargas al ambiente. Ello requerirá  disposiciones que den vida a los principios de prevención y precaución,  actuando tempranamente antes de que se materialicen la contaminación y  sus impactos nocivos en la salud humana y el medio ambiente. Quien  contamina debe asumir los costos de la contaminación y el instrumento  debe prever herramientas para movilizar recursos de los agentes  económicos de la  cadena de valor del plástico y ponerlos a disposición de  la prevención, control, reducción y remediación de la contaminación.     En tercer lugar, debemos garantizar que este instrumento reconozca y  reivindique las voces de quienes por décadas nos han llamado a la  circularidad segura y sostenible.   • De los recicladores de oficio, cuyos aportes, bienestar y  potencialidades deben ser considerados en múltiples disposiciones,  incluyendo aquellas que se refieren al uso de material reciclado en la  producción, la Responsabilidad Extendida del Productor, la i nversión  en infraestructura y tecnología para la gestión de residuos, la  educación e investigación y la asistencia técnica y financiera.             Nov 1 3th, 2023   • De los científicos, que vienen construyendo el acervo probatorio  sobre los polímeros plásticos y las sustancias químicas y aditivos  asociados, el cual debe cimentar la toma de decisiones, incluyendo  las que se puedan adoptar tras la entrada en vigor del in strumento.   • Y de los Pueblos Indígenas y Afrodescendientes, así como de las  comunidades locales, que en Colombia incluyen a comunidades Rom,  comunidades campesinas y otras comunidades locales, que desde sus  respectivos sistemas de conocimiento pueden aportar a la tran sición  hacia patrones de consumo y producción sostenibles.     Muchas gracias.                Nov 1 3th, 2023   OPENING STATEMENT MADE BY COLOMBIA – INC3 Agenda Item 4   Nairobi, November 13, 2023     Thank you, Mr President.     Colombia aligns itself with the statements read out by Uruguay, on behalf  of GRULAC, and by Solomon Islands, on behalf of the High Ambition  Coalition to End Plastic Pollution.     Colombia also avails itself of  this opportunity to thank the people and the  Government of Kenya for their hospitality in hosting this session of the  Committee. Thank you also, Mr. Chair , and the Secretariat, for duly  responding to the mandate given in Paris to  prepare a draft of the  instrument that would incorporate the different views expressed by the  members of the Committee.     In the course of this week, Colombia will participate constructively in the  discussion s of the different contact groups, in order to reflect  the following  priorities in the text of the instrument:     First, we must establish common targets and standards to which all parties  shall  be  bound so that the transboundary and regressive impacts of plastic  pollution can be prevented, mitigated and remedied, while ensuring the  necessary means of implementation so that our countries can undertake  the most ambitious elements of this instrument.     Second, we need to be able to address the failures throughout the life cycle  of plastics that allow leaks and discharges into the environment. This will  require provisions that give life to the principles of prevention and  precaution, acting early before p ollution and its harmful impacts on human  health and the environment materialize. The polluter must bear the costs  of pollution and the instrument must provide tools to mobilise resources  from the economic agents in the plastics value chain and make them  available for the prevention, control, reduction and remediation of pollution.     Third, we must ensure that this instrument recognises and vindicates the  voices of those who for decades have advocated for  safe and sustainable  circularity.   • Of waste pickers, whose contributions, well -being and potential  must  be considered in multiple provisions, including those referring to the  use of recycled material in production, Extended Producer  Responsibility, investment in infrastructure and technology for waste  management, education and research, and technical a nd financial  assistance.   • Of scientists, who have been building the body of evidence on plastic  polymers and the associated chemical substances and additives,            Nov 1 3th, 2023   which should underpin decision -making, including those decisions  that may be adopted after the entry into force of the instrument.   • And of Indigenous Peoples and People  of African Descent , as well as  local communities, which in Colombia include Roma communities,  peasant communities and other local communities, who can  contribute to the transition towards sustainable consumption and  production patterns , from their respective knowledge systems .    Many thanks.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Costa Rica
file_content: Intervención Nacional de la República de Costa Rica durante el inicio de la tercera sesión del Comité Intergubernamental de Negociación para desarrollar un instrumento internacional jurídicamente vinculante sobre la contaminación por plásticos, incluido en el medio marino de 13 de noviembre de 2023  Excelencias, estimados delegados, señoras y señores muy buenas tardes,  Estimado señor Presidente, siendo esta vez la primera que la delegación de CRI toma la palabra, agradecemos al gobierno de Kenia por su gran hospitalidad y compromiso con el proceso de negociaciones del INC. Costa Rica se alinea plenamente con la intervención realizada por la delegación del URUGUAY en nombre del GRULAC y la de las islas Solomon, en nombre de la Coalición de Alta Ambición.  En este sentido, dada la importancia y urgencia que reviste el futuro instrumento jurídicamente vinculante sobre la contaminación por plásticos, incluido en el medio marino, como se delimita en la Resolución 5/14 adoptada en UNEA 5.2, Costa Rica hace un llamado urgente a usted, señor Presidente, para iniciar las negociaciones de los grupos de contacto esta noche, pudiendo así empezar el diálogo entre los estados miembros para abordar sus posiciones con relación al borrador zero. De esta forma se maximizaría el tiempo de cada una de las delegaciones aquí presentes, y evitar la situación que surgió durante la INC2, en la cual perdimos dos días de trabajo antes de iniciar las negociaciones. No tenemos tiempo que perder.  En este sentido, Costa Rica agradece a la Secretaría por la elaboración del borrador cero, el cual ha sido un muy buen punto de partida para las negociaciones.  Costa Rica aboga por la inclusión de la referencia al derecho humano a un ambiente limpio, saludable y sostenible con base en la Resolución 76/300 de la Asamblea General de Naciones Unidas e insta a la Comunidad Internacional, a que unamos esfuerzos para lograr un tratado ambicioso.   El futuro tratado deberá tomar en consideración los impactos de la contaminación por plásticos, en particular para las personas, grupos y comunidades en situaciones de vulnerabilidad, tales como: las niñas y niños, las mujeres, los pueblos indígenas, las comunidades locales, especialmente las costeras, así como a las personas que viven en condiciones de pobreza y las comunidades circundantes expuestas a las diferentes etapas del ciclo de vida de los plásticos, aditivos y emisiones como extracción, procesamiento y gestión, en particular los recicladores y recolectores informales. De igual forma se deberán ser contempladas las respectivas capacidades de cada estado miembro y los medios de implementación requeridos para los países en desarrollo de tal forma que puedan cumplir con los alcances del tratado internacional.   En este sentido, CRI sugiere que el nuevo mecanismo financiero, sea una ventana o instrumento en una entidad financiera ya existente, como podría ser el GEF u otro. Esto evitaría años de espera para la creación de un nuevo mecanismo o instrumento no anclado a una institución ya existente.  La coordinación con las ONGs, el sector privado, incluyendo a las coaliciones globales comprometidas con un tratado ambicioso y eficaz, la academia, gobiernos y comunidades locales y agencias y programas de Naciones Unidas, es fundamental para lograr el objetivo de un mundo libre de contaminación por plásticos.  Costa Rica reitera su compromiso con este proceso tan acuciante, con la esperanza que esta sesión de negociación sea productiva y fructuosa, si deseamos que en este marco multilateral y su debido proceso para el INC, logremos impactar la calidad de vida de todos los habitantes del planeta y sus ecosistemas.  Muchas gracias, señor Presidente.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Côte d'Ivoire
file_content: DECLARATION DE LA COTE D’IVOIRE   A L’INC -3 A NAIROBI AU KENYA   13/11/2023     Monsieur le Président, c’est la première fois que la Côte d’Ivoire prend  la parole. A ce titre, je voudrais à mon tour  remercier le Gouvernement  du Kenya pour son hospitalité  ainsi que le PNUE  qui ne ménage aucun  effort pour faciliter la participation des délégués  aux différentes  sessions de négociation .    Je tiens également à vous féliciter Monsieur le Président pour le  leadership avec lequel vous conduisez les travaux.   Monsieur le Président, la Côte d’Ivoire souscrit à la déclaration du  Ghana au nom d u Groupe africains.   La question de la pollution plasti que est devenu e  un problème mondial .  Ses conséquences sur la santé humaine et l’environnement ne sont plus  à démontrer.   Selon l'Organisation de Coopération et de Développement  Economiques (OCDE), la production mondiale de plastique a doublé  entre  2000 et  2019, passant de 234 à 460 millions de tonnes. Dans le  même temps, la production de déchets plastiques a, elle, plus que  doublé, et a atteint 353  millions de tonnes en  2019. Sur la seule  année  2019, 22  millions de tonnes de plastique ont été rejetées dans  l'environnement, dont 20  millions de tonnes dans les cours d'eau, lacs  et océans, selon l'OCDE. Les plastiques représente nt au moins 85  % du  total des déchets marins , indique l'Assemblée des Nations unies pour  l’environnement.  Ainsi, entre 23 et 37 millions de tonnes de plastique  se déverseraient dans l'océan chaque année d'ici à 2040.     La Côte d’Ivoire n’est pas en marge de cette pollution plastique. Elle  produit plus de 400.000 tonnes de déchets plastiques chaque année. Plus de 50% de ces déchets sont déversés directement dans la rue  tandis que moins de 20% sont triés et recyclés.   Le gouvernement ivoirien , conscient de  l’ampleur  du problème  a  engagé la croisade pour lutter contre la pollution plastique.   Ainsi, au plan  juridique, en  2013   un décret qui interdit la production,  l’importation, la commercialisation, la détention et l’utilisation des  sachets  plastiques  sur l’ensemble du territoire  a été pris .   De plus mon pays dispose d’une stratégie nationale intégrée de  promotion de  l’économie circulaire , un catalogue des métiers et  emplois verts  ainsi qu’une stratégie de promotion des emplois verts.   Au plan institutionnel, le Ministère de l’Environnement et du  Développement Durable, s’est vu renforcé par le volet Transition  Ecologique,  à la faveur du nouveau gouvernement du 17 octobre 2023,  afin d’être plus efficace dans la lutte contre la triple crise , changement  climatique, pollution  et perte de la biodiversité .  Monsieur le Président, l ’avant -projet fournit, constitue  une base solide  sur l aquel le les travaux doivent s’appuyer pour parvenir à un bon  accord.   La Côte d’Ivoire souhaite que ces discussions soient fructueuses et  positive s et cela doit se faire  en adoptant une approche holistique  dans  une synergie d’action qui prend  en compte les besoins spécifiques de  chaque pays.   Je vous remercie.   Délégation de Côte d’Ivoire   Monsieur ONAMOUN Djedji Benjamin

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Spanish) English
file_content: Agenda item 4 – Cuba’s statement     Mr. President:     My delegation thanks the Government of Kenya for hosting this  meeting.     Cuba has been actively participating since the beginning of the  negotiation process of the legally binding instrument on plastic  pollution, as we consider that it is necessary to stop  the increase of  existing pollution at a global level, which represents a serious  environmental problem and it has negative impacts on the economic,  social and environmental dimensions of sustainable development,  especially of small island states.     In that sense, we support resolution 5/14 approved at the UNEA as  the guiding document for the work in the INC and we recognize the  hard task carried out by you, Ambassador Meza -Cuadra s as  President of the INC, of preparing the Zero Draft.     However, with complete transparency we express our concern that  the Zero Draft  does not include all the diversity of positions and criteria  expressed by the delegations in sessions 1 and 2 of the INC.     Several of the provisions and options presented exceed the mandate  established in operative paragraph 3 of Resolution 5/14.     Cuba reiterates that the instrument is about plastic pollution and not  about the elimination of these products themselves or the control of  their international trade .    It is striking that one of the most important provisions for the objective  of the instrument, which is the one related to Current Pollution (article  11 of the Zero Draft), is voluntary in nature, since it refers only to  “cooperation” between the Parties, w hich is completely insufficient.     The options contained do not take into account the national  circumstances of each country and the existing differences in the  economic, social and environmental order, even when the levels and  sources of plastic pollution differ from one country to another .   Nor is there any differentiated treatment for developing countries, in  accordance with the Principle of Common but Differentiated  Responsibilities.     Mr. P resident,     Taking into account the above and the interest in advancing the  negotiation of the Instrument, we consider that at the end of this  meeting it is necessary to have a text that contains all the positions of  the States and groups of countries, with specific language proposals.  We want to start working with a text that is the result of input s from  the States and not the interpretation of a third party . Otherwise, we  will be facing the same situation in INC 4.     For this reason, we share the concern expressed by Iran, on behalf  of the Group of Like -Minded Countries, about the need to have a clear  mandate for the work of the Contact Groups, which allows for the  incorporation of all existing positions.     We also consider that, once we have an initial negotiation text, we  should begin to negotiate the provisions in which we could move more  quickly towards a consensus, that is, those that do not contain the  Zero option, which means not including any regulati on on the topic in  question within the Instrument.     My delegation considers that this is the way to guarantee the success  of our work and reiterates the commitment to contribute in a  constructive and transparent manner to the efforts to achieve a  balanced instrument that can be ratified by the vast majority of States.     Thank you so much.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Spanish) Spanish
file_content: Punto 4 de la agenda - Intervención de Cuba     Señor Presidente:   Mi delegación agradece al Gobierno de Kenya por la acogida de esta  reunión.   Cuba ha venido participando de manera activa desde el inicio del  proceso de negociación del instrumento jurídicamente vinculante  sobre la contaminación por plasticos, en tanto considera que es  necesario enfrentar el aumento de los niveles de conta minación  existentes a nivel global , lo cual representa un serio problema  ambiental y tiene impactos negativos en las dimensiones económica,  social y ambiental del desarrollo sostenible , en especial de los  pequennos estados insulares .   En ese sentido, respaldamos la resolución 5/14 aprobada en la UNEA  5 como documento rector del trabajo en el INC  y reconocemos la dura  tarea realizada por usted, Embajador Meza -Cuadra como Presidente  del INC, de elaborar el Borrador cero.   Sin embargo, con total transparencia expresamos nuestra  preocupación porque el Texto no recoge toda la diversidad de  posiciones y criterios expresados por las delegaciones en las  sesiones 1 y 2 del INC.   En varias de las dispocisiones y opciones  presentadas , se excede el  mandato establecido en el párrafo operativo 3  de la Resolución  5/14,  como es el caso del comercio internacional y la restricción a la  producción de polímeros primarios .   Cuba reitera que e l instrumento es sobre la contaminación por  plásticos  y no sobre la eliminación de esos productos en sí mismos  ni el control de su comercialización.   Es contradictorio que una de las disposiciones más importantes para  el obj etivo del instrumento que es la relacionada con la  Contaminación Actual (artículo 11) y  sin embargo,  tiene un carácter  voluntario, pues se refiere solo a la “cooperación” entre las Partes, lo  cual es completamente insuficiente.   En las opciones contenidas no se tiene n en cuenta las circunstancias  nacionales de cada país y las diferencias existentes en el orden  económico, social  y ambiental, incluso cuando los niveles y fuentes  de la contaminación por plásticos difieren de un país a otro.   Tampoco hay ningún tratamiento diferenciado a los países en  desarrollo, en correspondencia con el Principio de  Responsabilidades Comunes pero Diferenciadas.    Señor Presidente,   Teniendo en cuenta lo anterior y el interés de avanza r en la  negociación del Instrumento, consideramos que al término de esta  reunión es necesario co ntar con un texto  que contenga todas las  posiciones de los Estados y grupos de países, con propuestas  concretas de lenguaje. De lo contrario, estaremos enfrentando la  misma situación en el INC 4.   Por tal motivo, compartimos la preocupación expresada por Irán, a  nombre del Grupo de Países de Ideas Afines, sobre la necesidad de  tener un mandato claro para el trabajo de los Grupos de Contacto,  que permita la incorporación de todas las posiciones  existentes.    También consideramos que, una vez se tenga un texto de  negociación inicial, deberíamos comenzar a negociar las  disposiciones en las que podría avanzarse  más rápido  hacia un  consenso , o sea, por aquellas que no contengan la opción Cero que  significa no incluir ninguna regulación sobre el tema en cuestión  dentro del Instrumento.    Mi delegación considera que este es el camino para garantizar el  éxito de nuestro trabajo y reitera el compromiso de contribuir de  manera constructiva y transparente en los esfuerzos para lograr un  instrumento balanceado , que pueda ser ratificado por la inmensa  mayoría de los Estados.     Muchas gracias.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Dominican Republic
file_content: Palabras de apertura INC3   Estimados miembros del Comité de Negociación Intergubernamental,   Es un honor dirigirme a ustedes en esta tercera ronda de negociaciones, la  República  Dominicana reconoce  la urgente necesidad de tomar medidas concretas para poner fin  a la contaminación por plásticos, que supone una  amenaza cada vez mayor para nuestro  medio ambiente y para la salud de las personas , y reafirma su compromiso de abordar   este desafío de manera efectiva y colaborativa.   Consideramos que el borrador cero elaborado por le secretaría , documento de referencia  utilizado por la República Dominicana para su consulta nacional,  recoge a modo general  las discusiones que se desarrollaron en el anterior período de sesiones, de manera  particular lo referente a los planes nacionales.  Estos planes son el mecanismo por  excelencia para llevar a cabo las disposiciones del instrumento propuesto. Permitirán  recopilar en un solo documento las obligaciones de cumplimiento obligatorio y establec er  enfoques de cumplimiento voluntario en función de las circunstancias y capacidades  nacionales. Además, estos planes facilitarán la presentación de informes y serán el  vehículo ideal para evaluar periódicamente los avances y la eficacia en la aplicación del  instrumento.  Destacamos beneficiosa la posibilidad y flexibilidad de continuar ajustando  el documento a lo largo de la negociaciones.   Es fundamental que en los enfoques vinculantes se incluyan anexos que contemplen un  listado de químicos no permitidos y un control de comercialización similar al que se  realiza en otros convenios. Asimismo, es importante promover enfoques voluntarios que  aborden de manera integral todo el ciclo de vida del plástico. Esto implica impulsar la  producción y el consumo sostenibles, fomentar medidas de cooperación nacional e  internacional para reducir la contaminación por plástico en el medio marino, incluida la  existente, y desarrollar, aplicar y actualizar planes de acción nacionales que reflejen los  enfoques impulsados por los países.   Además, estamos convencidos de que la educación,  sensibilización, y el intercambio de  información jugarán un rol protagónico, sobre todo en la difusión de datos científicos y  socioeconómicos. Estos datos servirán como base para informar las políticas  relacionadas con la contaminación por plástico. También es crucial que la cooperación y  el acceso a financiamiento se realice con la menor burocracia posible, es por esto que   apoyamos la creación de un fondo multilateral específico para apoyar las acciones del  instrumento y facilitar la transferencia de tecnología en condiciones mutuamente  convenidas . Reconocemos la importancia de la flexibilidad en algunas disposiciones, teniendo en  cuenta las distintas circunstancias nacionales. Sin embargo, siempre debemos basarnos  en la mejor información científica disponible, así como en la experiencia adquirida y las  mejores prácticas, incluso las provenientes de entornos informales y cooperativos.   En conclusión, para poner fin a la contaminación por plástico debemos actuar de manera  decisiva y coordinada. Los planes nacionales, los enfoques vinculantes y voluntarios, la  promoción de la cooperación nacional e internacional, la generación de concienci a y la  especificación de acuerdos para la creación de capacidad, asistencia técnica,  transferencia de tecnología y asistencia financiera son elementos clave para alcanzar  nuestros objetivos. Confío en que, trabajando juntos, tendremos avances significativo s  en esta ronda de negociaciones que permitan acercarnos a un instrumento jurídicamente  vinculante a través del cual se pueda visualizar  un futuro más sostenible para las  generaciones venideras.   Desde la Republica Dominicana esperamos que esta reunión sea enriquecedora y  podamos avanzar significativamente en aras de una exitosa conclusión de agenda.    Gracias por su atención y compromiso en esta importante labor.   José Ramón Reyes López   Viceministr o de Recursos Costeros y Marinos   Jefe de Delegación de la República Dominicana

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Egypt
file_content: Mr. Chair man,   ladies and gentlemen ,       It gives me pleasure at the outset  to express appreciation to the INC  President and secretariat for the ir support to efforts aimed at achiev ing the Legally  Binding Instrument ON Plastic Pollution, including in Marine Environment, as   mandated by UNEA resolution 5/14. I would also like to commend  UNEP  and the  People  and Government of Kenya for hosting the third Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee (INC -3) meeting , where all environment -related meetings  and negotiations should be held.      Mr. Chair man,   When incepted  last century , plastic was considered a massive breakthrough  innovation originally support ing the environment and biodiversity protection , as an  alternative to the use of ivory in many industries at that time . Yet, with the passage  of time , and the piling up  of plastic waste due to  lack of adequate measure s to  dispose of and recycle it , plastic pollution  has become a major world environmental  problem .   In this spirit , it is importan t to focus our efforts on devis ing an instrument  that will end P lastic Pollution , as mandated . In doing so , we need to main tain a  State -driven comprehensive approach that takes into account the common but  differentiated responsibilities , and the varying circumstances worldwide , as well as   the developmental goals and needs , uphold ing the right to development so as to  ensure  that no one is left behind.          Mr. Chairman ,     Egypt shares some of the concerns expressed by a number of previous  speakers. We believes that for the successful conclusion of our collective efforts, we  need to embark  on solid ground s, within the scope of the existing mandate . Egypt  is of the opinion that ideas to be incorporated in the text should not  deviate  from  that mandate, and should aim at striking the balance needed to reach a consensual  and comprehensive mechanism in order for it to be applicable . It should be in line  with the modalities of M ultilateral Environmental Agreements  (MEAs), resting  on  two balanced pillars , namely pledges and means of implementation . Egypt  calls in  this regard  for striking a sufficient equilibrium between obligations and means of implementation , and for a negotiation process that is equitable, inclusive and  transparent , which recognizes the important contributions  of plastic in society,  promoting its sustainable production and consumption     On the other hand, it is crucial to ensure effective implementation based on  an incremental bottom -up approach, which provides sufficient flexibilit y to  developing countries , along with fair and equitable access to finance, new and  affordable technolog ies, technical and human capacitation ,  with a vision to promote  a just transition while bearing into consideration the relevant socio -economic  implications . It should be  guided by the internationally -agreed and well -established  principles  in UNEA Resolution 5/14 , such as Equity, Common but Differentiated  Responsibilities and Respective Capabilities . Varying particularities and   circumstances of  State s should be taken into consideration . allowing them  to tailor  their national plans according to  their specific needs, priorities, and capabilities .     In parallel , efforts should be made to promote the development and adoption  of safe alternatives to hazardous chemicals , with a view to ensur ing technology  transfer and the provision of additional, adequate, predictable, and sustainable finance to such alternatives , as well as  promoting sustainable practices within  relevant industries.  Any substitutes or alternatives to plastic polymers should be  made available to developing countries , at fair and affordable prices.     Equally important is the  need to establish a socio -economic -scientific body  to bolster  implementation of the outcome , and assist in estimating the funding   requir ed for the developing countries  in this regard . Modalities for its composition  should m eet Member States ’ consensus , and based on  balanced representation of  both developed and developing countries. Finally, Egypt would like to echo the call  made by His Excellency President Ruto during the opening session to base the  Secretariat in Nairobi . In fact , Egypt is of the view that, for the sake of efficien cy,  coordination  and rationalization of resources , the secretariat of any new  environment -related  international agreement should  be based in Nairobi, the only  United Nations headquarters in the Global South.      I THANK YOU .

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: El Salvador
file_content: MISIÓN PERMANENTE DE EL SALVADOR ANTE LAS NACIONES UNIDAS  Y OTROS ORGANISMOS INTERNACIONALES  GINEBRA, SUIZA Discurso de Apertura para la Tercera Sesión del Comité Intergubernamental de Negociación sobre la Contaminación por Plásticos (INC-3) Señor Presidente, Es un honor dirigirme a ustedes en nombre de El Salvador en esta tercera sesión del Comité de Negociación Intergubernamental (INC-3). Agradecemos a la República de Kenia y al Programa de las Naciones Unidas para el Medio Ambiente (PNUMA) por ser anfitriones de este significativo encuentro. Es fundamental reconocer que la contaminación por plásticos es un desafío que requiere de una respuesta integral y colaborativa. En consecuencia, El Salvador destaca la importancia de la cooperación internacional y las responsabilidades comunes pero diferenciadas en estos esfuerzos. En ese sentido, nuestro país considera indispensable contar con mecanismos de financiamiento a largo plazo, predecible, sostenible y accesible, así como contar con programas de asistencia técnica, fortalecimiento de capacidades y transferencia de tecnología para apoyar a los países en desarrollo en sus esfuerzos por abordar este desafío, asegurando que nadie atrás. El Salvador se posiciona a favor de un instrumento que promueva una gestión eficaz y responsable desde la producción hasta la disposición final de los plásticos. Por ello, es esencial establecer un mecanismo de verificación de cumplimiento que actúe como facilitador y no punitivo, ayudando así a los países a alcanzar sus metas nacionales y globales en la reducción gradual de la contaminación por plásticos. Al mismo tiempo, a través del presente instrumento debemos fomentar un enfoque de economía circular e inclusivo. Se debe reconocer y proteger especialmente a los trabajadores de salud y recuperadores de base. Debemos asegurar que la transición sea justa e inclusiva, de esta manera, podamos avanzar hacia niveles sostenibles de producción y consumo de uso de plásticos, fomentando la innovación y fortaleciendo la educación ambiental para aumentar la conciencia entre los productores y consumidores Confiamos en que a través de nuestras deliberaciones, negociaciones y colaboraciones en estos días, lograremos avances significativos en la construcción de un marco jurídico sólido para elaborar un instrumento robusto y efectivo para acabar con la contaminación por plásticos, Muchas gracias.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Eswatini
file_content: STATEMENT BY THE KINGDOM OF ESWATINI AT THE THIRD   MEETING OF THE INTERGOVERNMENTAL NEGOTIATING  COMMITTEE  (INC-3) TO DEVELOP AN INTERNATIONAL  LEGALLY BINDING INSTRUMENT ON PLASTIC POLLUTION,  INCLUDING IN THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT NAIROBI 13TH TO  19TH NOVEMBER 2023     MR. PRESIDENT   Let me start by passing our sincere gratitude to the Government and the people  of Kenya for their warm welcome to this green city of Nairobi.   The Delegation of the Kingdom of Eswatini would like to align itself with the  African position as presented by  Republic of Ghana . In this regard we are  encouraged by the call from the African Ministerial conference (AMCEN) for this  committee to deliver an agreement capable of reduc ing and eventually  eliminat ing all  impacts of plastic pollution on human health, and the  environment  without delay.    The Kingdom of Eswatini express our gratitude to the INC Chair and Secretariat  for developing the zero -draft  text of the instrument . The Chair’s zero draft was  based on all inputs from member states and  reflects the desire of the global  majority for a strong treaty with  binding  global measures , including elimination  of high -risk plastic categories.    The Kingdom of Eswatini, supports the call for dedicated Multilateral Fund to  provide the necessary financial resources to eligible developing countries in  order to meet their commitments under the instrument. We further request the  developed countri es parties to provide adequate and predictable finance and  environmentally sound technology transfer to eligible developing countries.   Our delegation further  expresses the need to move swiftly through the opening  segment, onto substantive discussions to review the provisions of the Chair’s  Zero Draft in the three Contact Groups, as proposed by the Chair.   We call on  the Committee to engage in constructive discussions leading to the first version  of the text of the instrument, to be considered at the fourth session of the  Committee.   We further call upon all our private sector, business, labor,  and civil society  stakeholders to move ahead and prepare for a world and a future economy  devoid of plastic pollution.   We look forward to the adoption of clear mandates and timetables for the  necessary intersessional work at the fourth and fifth sessions where a first list of  chemicals of concern, including monomers and polymers, will be included in the  treaty annexes, bri nging us closer to the ambitious goal of a global legally  binding instrument to stop plastic pollution.   Finally, the Eswatini supports the proposal by the Republic of Kenya for the  hosting of the secretariat of this treaty at the Headquarters of the United  Nations Environment Programme here in  Nairobi .  I Thank you.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Fiji
file_content: Republic of Fiji   Draft Opening Statement by the Fiji at INC -3  Agenda Item 4   Delivered by: Amb. Amena. V. Yauvoli   Nairobi, Kenya – 13 November 2023     Mr Chair,   1. At the outset, Fiji would like to extend its gratitude to the people and Government of  Kenya for their hospitalit y and warm welcome . We also would like to thank you Chair ,  and the Secretariat for the efforts in formulating the Zero Draft (ZD) as the foundation  for the INC3 negotiations .    2. Fiji aligns with the statement delivered by [Samoa on behalf  of the AOSIS] and Palau  on behalf of the PSIDS. We stand  firm in supporting resolution 5/14 to achieve the  ultimate objective of ending plastic pollution, including in the marine environment, in  order to protect human health and the environment .    3. Mr. Chair, in order to achieve this, we need a robust instrument that is  strong,  comprehensive,  specifi c, time-bound and measurable while clearly communicating the  broad scope of the instrument , without re -writing or re -interpreting the legality of  existing principles.     4. The objective  of the instrument should :  a. Cover the full lifespan of plastics from extraction and pr oduction to its end-of- life management , taking into account the disproportionate impacts of plastic  pollution on (SIDS) , the Large Ocean Small Is land Developing States  (LOSIDS) ;  b. The reduction of p rimary plast ic polymer production, polymers and chemicals  of concern and problematic and avoidable plastic polymers and products should  be ambitious and time -bound ;   c. Fiji supports a [dedicated ] multilateral fund as a means to provide adequate and  stable financial and technical assistance {potentially modelled on the  Multilateral Fund for the Implementation of the Montreal Protocol} and existing  financing mechanisms should be leveraged, such as t he GEF – possibly through  a dedicated window .    5. Mr Chair , Fiji like all other PS IDs are net importers of plastics. We are on the receiving  end and so is our ‘moana’, the ocean that we so crucia lly depend on for our survival.  The convenience obtained by util izing plastics does not justify large -scale and nearly  irreparable contamination of the Pacific Ocean, its natural resources , the costs to the   health of  our people now and for generations  to come.      6. Often these costs exceed the market value of plastics and  include the cost of loss of  ecosystem services, greenhouse gas emissions, human health costs and waste  (mis)management costs.     Mr. Chair , Fiji firmly believes that the instrument should recognise and consider  diverse value systems and concepts, including the rights of nature and the  land [Vanua] .  In Fiji, our [Vanua] land r elates to the interconnectedness to the foundations of life on  earth and includes the natural terrain, local flora and fauna, rivers, mountains and much  more. Plastic pollution is strain ing the connection we have to our land [V anua ].    7. Mr. Chair,  like other Pacific Islands Member States, my delegation have travelled a  long way to be here . As I speak there is a category 2 cyclone closing in on our beloved  homeland. Such natural disasters exacerbates the impacts of plastic pollution and  increases the vulnerability of our people and our oceans.   We implore fellow members  to just ‘get on with our discussions  and progress with an ambitious, effective and  equitable Instrument to end plastic pollution once and for all  and ensuring that none is  left behind .    I thank you Chair.

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Gabon
file_content: DÉCLARATION DE LA RÉPUBLIQUE GABONAISE INC -3    Deuxième journée des travaux du Comité  de Négociation Inter gouve rnementale sur la  pollution plastique    14 novembre 2023   Nairobi, KENYA   Merci Monsieur le Pr ésident,   La République Gabonaise félicite le Gouvernement du Kenya , pays hôte , de cette troisième session  des travaux de l’INC.   De m ême, vous congratule  ainsi que le Secrétariat Exécutif de l’INC pour l’organisation technique  de cette réunion et ce, en collaboration avec le Programme des Nations Unies pour  l’environnement.   Monsieur le Président , Distin gués Délégués   Le Gabon, membre de la High Ambition Coalition s’aligne à la position du Groupe Africain lu par la  République du Ghana et réaffirme son plein engagement dans ce processus.   Notre delegation exprime sa satisfaction de passer après le segment d'ouverture, aux discussions  de fond pour examiner , compl éter et améliorer substanciellement de manière inclusive l'avant - projet   au sein des  groupes de contact .  Dans ce contexte, nous form ulons le souhait que les groupes de contact puissent  être le lieu  d’affirmation de nos convergences sur les différentes options  potentielles contenues dans l’avant   projet .  Monsieur le Président   Le  Gabon appelle le Comité à considérer la science pour maintenir le fort niveau d’ambition du  futur traité.   A cet effet, les connaissances scientifiques , techniques et traditionnelles devraient être utilisées  comme une boussole au benefice de nos générations  présentes et futures  ainsi que de notre  environnement . Ces connaissances permettront en cas de divergences de trouver un consensus  juste en faveur des objectifs visés par la résolution 5/14.   La délégation gabonaise reconnaît que parvenir à une solution urgente et  conjoint e face à la  pollution plastique est très complexe du fait des aspects économiques qui y sont liés. Néanmoins,  on peut s’accorder sur le fait que la préservation de l’environnement et la santé humaine voire  animale transcende généralement les enjeux multiformes de n otre société comtemporaine.   Nous souhaitons à l'issue de cette session obtenir l'adoption de mandats et de calendriers clairs  pour les travaux intersessions requis pour l ’INC -4 et 5.  Monsieur le Président , la lutte contre la pollution plastique est un  combat  pour la protection des  droits de l’homme . C’est sans doute le sens de l’assertion du Haut -Commissaire des Nations Unies  aux Droits de l’homme .  << Le respect des droits de l'homme peut garantir que la politique environnementale soit basée  sur des faits et des preuves .>>  Je vous remercie Monsieur le Président  et Distinguées Délégués.    Fait à Nairobi, le 1 4 Novembre 2023    Pour la République Gabonaise   Georges GASSITA, Référent Technique National   Trésor Wassiana AVOMO , Référent Technique National

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Gambia
file_content: NATIONAL STATEMENT – GAMBIA ON THE T HIRD SESSION OF  THE INTERGOVERNMENTAL NEGOTIATING COMMITTEE ON  PLASTIC POLLUTION 13TH – 19TH NOVEMBER 2023, NAIROBI,  KENYA   Mr. Chair, Distinguish delegates Ladies and Gentlemen, The Gambia  delegation would like to thank the Government of the Republic of Kenya for  hosting the INC -3, and the Secretariat for organizing this meeting and the  provision of the ZERO draft  for this negotiations.   Mr. Chair, The Government of Republic of The Gambia attaches high  priority to reducing and eventually eliminating issues related to plastics  pollution and promoting sound management of plastic pollution and wastes  and therefore aligned herself to statement read by distinguished delegate of  Ghana on behalf of the African Region.   Cognizance of  the negative impacts Plastics  pollution poses to the  health and environment of current and future generation , The Gambia is with  the view that  the primary and ultimate goal of every nation is to protect  human h ealth and the environment from  the risks posed by the unsound  use, management and releases of plastics and related waste into the  environment we all depend for our living.   As protection  of the environment is at the highest level of priority, the  Gambia has developed national policies and legislations that are geared  towards the protection of the environment for the present and future  generation. In that, the country in 2007 enacted Anti - Littering Regulation which is meant to limit indiscriminate littering in the country which includes  plastics and related waste.   This was subsequently followed by the ban on Plastic Bag Order 2015  which proh ibits the importation, sales, m anufacture and use of  single use   plastic bags in The Gambia .   This to a higher extent has yielded positive result in reducing the  amount of plastic and related waste generated  over the years,  and no waste  is allowed into in the country thus leading to the use of reusable bags and  recycle material in the country as well as phasing out single use plastic.   In conclusion, Mr. Chair, we strongly reaffirm  to aligning our  commitment in joining global efforts  in addressing environmental challenges  particularly on plastic pollution and related waste which continues to  threaten live and humanity . We strongly believe ending plastic pollution  requires collective responsibilities irrespective of the economic status of our  count ries, taking into consideration our national realities as a developing  country.    We are  ready to p artner with all (member state or organization) in  enhancing  our national efforts in making the planet a better place for us and  generations to come.   Collectively , we can all make a difference in paving solutions  to a  comprehensive life -cycle approach to prevent plastic pollution.                       I THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR KIND ATTENTION

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Georgia
file_content: National statement INC3 – GEORGIA (13 November, 2023)     Distinguished Delegates, Excellencies, Colleagues,     It is my honor to be with you on behalf of the government of Georgia at the INC3 and be part  of the work dedicated to find the solution for the plastic pollution.     On behalf of Georgia I would like to thank UNEP and INC secretariat for the continued efforts  to end plastic pollution by 2040. We would  like to thank the government of Kenya for hosting  Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee (I NC3) on Legally binding document at the  beautiful UN premises in Nairobi.      We believe that legally binding document for us for the  countries with economic  development will create new possibilities, new capacities, improvements in the sound  management of plastic waste. which will contribute to the circular economy development  and to the improvement of environmental standards and approaches.     We believe that zero draft is a good starting document for the  further  negotiation . Thank you  chair for your efforts! We have now opportunity to come up with some of missing parts in  the zero draft and we will move forward to work on that.     We are committed to work towards plastic pollution through  a life cycle approach and sound  management of the waste. We believe that Extended producer responsibility approach is  appropriate and useful to involve private sector accordingly  and find solutions for financing  full life cycle of plastic. We are open to considering EPR schemes and specific details to  national action plans and other means , as we already introduced EPR at  national level .    We took some steps at national level to ban single used plastic bags and propose  alternatives; We developed national strategy for plastic prevention  and also we included  plastic waste management as one of the priority at national waste management strategy  and action plan in the last year and we have already started projects for plastic waste  prevention in the river basin with support of the UNDP, WB a nd Norwegian Ambassy in  Georgia.      We believe that sustainable production and consumption of plastic, sound management of  plastic waste using waste management hierarchy and sound management of chemicals and  waste will give us possibilities moving towards a treaty that can make important changes .   We are requiring strong scientific background and synergies with the legally binding  instrument s, MEAs such as BRS conventions and others;     We are confident that there  is a need to discuss the importance of eligibility and accessibility   to financial support and capacity building for the developing countries and countries with  economies in transition.  We are open to discuss approaches and ideas for the successful  implementation of legally binding document  which will create at national level the useful  backgrounds for the collaboration and development of public private partnership.     We affirm, that we are committed to work towards plastic pollution through a life cycle  approach and improving waste management systems.     As it was mentioned this  spirit  of global  collaboration  and that  we can achieve more by  coming together is something  I strongly believe  in.   I thank you!

Header: Item 4- Preparation of an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment
Title: Guatemala
file_content: Intervención por Estados Miembros, dentro del punto 4 de la agenda  Declaración de la República de Guatemala Sesión Plenaria 13 de noviembre de 2023, Nairobi, Kenya.   Muchas gracias, Señor Presidente, estimados delegados representantes de los diferentes países, deseo expresar el más sincero agradecimiento, en nombre de Guatemala, a la secretaría por su buen trabajo en la redacción y divulgación de los textos y notas pertinentes, también al Gobierno de Kenya y al PNUMA por hospedar está tercera sesión, para la elaboración de un instrumento jurídicamente vinculante a la contaminación por plásticos, inclusive en el medio marino.     En ese sentido, agradecemos también a la delegación del Uruguay por pronunciar la declaración en nombre del GRULAC, al cual nos adherimos.   Cabe mencionar que esta reunión permitirá el diálogo para avanzar en la construcción de un instrumento jurídicamente vinculante que aborde la contaminación por plásticos, incluso en el medio marino, la cual representa un paso significativo hacia un futuro más sostenible y limpio.   Asimismo, Guatemala desea proponer que uno de los objetivos de esta reunión sea identificar los puntos de convergencia que se presenten frente a este ambicioso instrumento, respetando siempre las capacidades y circunstancias nacionales que permita una transición justa, así como las decisiones soberanas de cada Estado aquí presente.  Guatemala desea que se refleje el sentir de los principios identificados dentro del desarrollo del instrumento, destacando la Declaración de Río sobre el Medio Ambiente, la “responsabilidad compartida pero diferenciada” que permita definir las prioridades, objetivos y circunstancias concretos de su desarrollo nacional y regional.         Es importante que, el instrumento contenga la definición de términos y conceptos asociados al mismo, para estandarizar y fortalecer los conocimientos necesarios para la implementación de acciones de forma coherente y consistente para todas las partes involucradas. Destacamos la relevancia de la creación de mecanismos efectivos para la asistencia técnica, la transferencia de tecnología en condiciones mutuamente convenidas y la asistencia financiera, reconociendo que la aplicación del instrumento, en especial para los países en desarrollo, dependerá de esto.  Sin más, espero que tengamos unas jornadas de trabajo muy productivas y exitosas.   Muchas gracias, señor presidente.    Translation into the English language  Declaration of the Republic of Guatemala Plenary Session, November 13, 2023, Nairobi, Kenya.  Thank you very much, Mr. President, esteemed delegates representing the various countries. On behalf of Guatemala, I wish to express our sincerest gratitude to the secretariat for their excellent work in drafting and disseminating the relevant texts and notes, as well as to the Government of Kenya and UNEP for hosting this third session, aimed at developing a legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment.  In this regard, we also thank the delegation from Uruguay for delivering the statement on behalf of GRULAC, which we endorse.  It should be noted that this meeting will allow dialogue to advance in the construction of a legally binding instrument that addresses plastic pollution, even in the marine environment, representing a significant step towards a more sustainable and clean future.       Additionally, Guatemala wishes to propose that one of the objectives of this meeting be to identify points of convergence that arise concerning this ambitious instrument, always respecting national capacities and circumstances that allow for a just transition, as well as the sovereign decisions of each State present here.  Guatemala wishes that the spirit of the principles identified within the development of the instrument be reflected, highlighting the Rio Declaration on the Environment, the "common but differentiated responsibility" that allows defining the priorities, objectives, and concrete circumstances of its national and regional development.  It is important that the instrument contains the definition of terms and concepts associated with it, to standardize and strengthen the knowledge necessary for the implementation of actions in a coherent and consistent manner for all parties involved.
