To support an effective  implementation, we call for a robust financial mechanism that ensures effective  action by developing countries.   6- The instrument should allow flexible timelines for industries in transitioning to safe  and sustainable alternatives, including improved product designs for circularity and  measures.   7- We encourage leveraging existing Multilateral Environment Agreements to  strengthen our implementation strategies, improve capacity -building, and facilitate  technology assistance and technology transfer. Collaborating within established  regional frameworks,  including COBSEA and other Regional Seas programmes, will  ensure a coordinated approach in addressing plastic pollution.   8- We highlight the importance of the Regional Action Plan on Marine Litter (RAP  MALI) , which outlines our regional priorities and capacity needs in preventing and  reducing marine plastic pollution from both land and sea. Guided by the COBSEA  Strategic Directions 2023 -2027 and RAP MALI, COBSEA is prepared to support the  implementation of the future instrument through enhanced capacity -building,  scientific and technical cooperation, and monitoring efforts in the East Asian Seas,  ensuring that national framework s are robust and aligned with regional and  international frameworks.   9- Moving forward, our focus must be on accelerating the implementation and  monitoring of progress while enhancing regional coordination and international  cooperation.   10- We seek further collaboration to strengthen national and regional capacities,  exchange best practices, align policies with global frameworks, and addressing  specific regional challenges through joint initiatives.     I thank you  chair!!

Title: Hungary on behalf of the European Union and its Member States
file_content: Opening Statement by the European Union and its 27 Member States at the 5th session of the  Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop an international legally binding instrument  on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment    25 November –  1 December 2024, Busan, Republic of Korea   Bosnia and Herzegovina, Georgia, Moldova, Serbia, Ukraine align themselves with this statement     Mr Chair, distinguished delegates,   First, the European Union and its 27 Member States thank you, Mr. Chair, for your efforts and  commitment to concluding this process in Busan. We would also like to express our  appreciation to the Republic of Korea for hosting us  for the final and most decisive  round of  negotiations .  The world cannot live with plastic pollution, even though plastic brings benefits to our daily  lives, our societies and economies . It has become a global crisis, threatening our environment,  wildlife, and human health. As we open this session with the ambition to reach a truly historic  agreement , the EU and its Member States consider it worthwhile to recall  how we got here  in the first place.   We have, Mr Chair, as a global community, been dealing with th e plastic pollution plague for  more than 10 years now . We are in dire need of a remedy, of a n agreement , of an effective  plastics treaty . Although differences between countries and perspectives are evident, we   must prove to the global community that multilateralism can deliver and that finding  compromises leads us towards the  concluding  of these negotiations .  The journey to this point has been long and challenging. In March 2022, the world witnessed a landmark moment when Member States , gathered at the United Nations Environment  Assembly , agreed unanimously to create , by 2024,  a legally binding treaty to end plastic  pollution. But the work  did not start here. We have been trying identify a united pathway to  tackle  plastic pollution, resulting in marine litter, since UNEA -1 in 2014 and in every UNEA  since then  until the mandate adoption.  Despite that, despite the increase in national and  voluntary actions to tackle plastic pollution, the problem has continued to worsen, with pollution rates rising. This is because no nation can do it alone, and because the m ere sum of  our individual action has been proven insufficient ti me and over again . And let us be clear:  plastics production is a global issue, not a North/South issue . In that context, the numbers  both in production and consumption shows that responsibility of plastic pollution is much more complex. All of us have to take our share, while taking into account the needs of the  most vulnerables.   Chair, distinguished delegates,   To achieve a successful treaty, compromises will be necessary . It is our task to find a common  ground  on provisions across the whole life cycle of plastics .   A treaty with solid  and truly global upstream measures to complement strong waste  management will be necessary to reduce the endless and increasing flow of global plastic pollution. The EU and its Member States are deeply convinced that we have to start c losing  the tap of plastic p ollution , in order to tackle the problem we are here to solve . Provisions in  the new treaty need to be tailored in a way that balances the need for global rules and a level  playing field, and the need for flexibility for countries to implement and enforce the necessary measures. However,  we emphasize  that a treaty in which each Party would do only  what they  consider is necessary is not something we  are ready to support. This is  because, Mr Chair, it  would mean the continuation of a business -as-usual  scenario in which , as many studies have  shown, we  will collectively fail to save our planet, our health and our future.   As we move forward with the final negotiations  this week, let us not forget that this treaty  represents a once -in-a-generation opportunity to end plastic pollution. In the coming days,  we need to agree on  bold, binding global actions to protect nature and human health,  espec ially of vulnerable communities . And we expect, and rely on you  Mr Chair,  to steer us  towards boldness. Towards the end of plastic pollution.   The EU and its Member States will support you in these efforts.

Title: Fiji on behalf of High Ambition Coalition To End Plastic Pollution
file_content: HAC Member States Ministerial  Joint Statement for INC-5       We, the 67 Ministers of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution, reaffirm  our  common ambition to protect human health and the environment from the severe  effects of  plastic pollution, including in the marine environment, through the development of an  international legally binding instrument (hereafter the treaty) based on a comprehensive  approach that addresses the full life cycle of plastics, as called fo r in UNEA Resolution 5/14.   We reiterate  our strong and united commitment to finalizing negotiations on an ambitious  and effective treaty at the fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee (INC - 5) in Busan in November  2024.   We are heartened  by the constructive contributions of the vast majority of INC members to  the negotiations and urge all members to step up  our collective efforts to meet the world’s  expectations. We reiterate  our commitment to working with all Members to establish and  extend areas of common understanding and convergence , with the understanding that  vested interests should not restrain our collective responsibility to meet the world’s  expectations,  so that we can conclude the effective, ambitious treaty required to achieve our  common goal of ending plastic pollution.   We reaffirm  our common ambition  of ending plastic pollution by 2040 and recall  the common  priorities we have clearly stated in our previous Ministerial Joint Statements, emphasizing  the need for a treaty that is based on a comprehensive approach that  addresses the full life  cycle of plastics, including design, production, consumption, and end of life.   We emphasize  that effective and common legally -binding global rules are essential to  address the negative economic, social, cultural, and environmental impacts of plastic  pollution in all countries, in particular in developing countries and especially in Least  Developed Countries and Small Island Developing States. We underline  that such global  rules are vital to make progress on  the transformation to a sustainable and more circular  economy , support just transitions, provide a global level playing field for  business, and avoid  unnecessary economic costs,  with positive benefits for sustainable development in all  countries, including in regard to health, job creation, innovation and economic  growth.        We highlight  the importance of ambitious and effective means of implementation to tackle  the challenges many developing countries may face in implementing the treaty, including  Least Developed Countries  and Small Island Developing States , recognize  the need for  timely, accessible, predictable and adequate financing for recipient countries, and underline   the need to mobilize the necessary resources from all sources, public and private, domestic  and international.   We emphasize  the principle that polluters should  be held responsible for their activities and  products, recognizing that economic tools appropriate to national circumstances are part of  the solution, including extended producer responsibility schemes and an end to harmful  incentives such as subsidies  that work against efforts to end plastic pollution .  We commit  to forging an agreement with common, legally -binding measures and encourage   all INC members to find agreement on goals as well as on  measurable and time -bound  targets to ensure we are on a clear path to ending plastic pollution, including on reducing  production and consumption of primary plastic polymers to sustainable levels, on sustainable  product design and safe circularity of plast ic products, and on environmentally sound  management of plastic waste as well as, where necessary  and feasible , sustainable  remediation of plastic  pollution.   We welcome the call  from a broad and diverse range  of INC members for global criteria and  measures  including  for phasing out or restricting certain problematic and avoidable plastic  products, polymers and chemicals of concern in plastics and plastic products, as well as for  global product design criteria and requirements,  in order to protect human health and the  environment, increase safe circularity and transparency, and minimize emissions and  releases of plastics, including microplastics.   We underline  the need for mechanisms to thoroughly assess, review, further develop,  amend and strengthen  the treaty over time to ensure that its obligations and measures are  adequate to end plastic pollution by 2040, and that the governing body can swiftly respond  to new evidence and emerging threats to human health, food chains, and the environment  from plastic pollution.  This includes mechanisms for adding, amending and supplementing  annexes; binding transparency and reporting requirements , including on p lastic polymer  production and chemical composition ; mechanisms to assess implementation and progress  achieved toward time -bound targets and other commitments;  and guidance from the  governing body on treaty implementation and technical recommendations based on scientific  evidence, the knowledges, sciences and practices  of Indigenous Peoples, and local  knowledge systems.   We are convinced  that the Committee will be able to agree on all essential aspects and key  provisions by the end of INC -5, and we emphasize  that ensuring that the treaty is effective,  responsive and relevant over time will require a governing body that seeks to make  its  decisions by consensus but is able to adopt decisions by majority based on best practices in  other multilateral environmental agreements and established practice in the United Nations.   We stress the importance of timely  signature and ratification of the treaty with the ambition of   its rapid entry into force. We further underline the importance of taking early measures  consistent with treaty provisions and of swiftly implementing all treaty obligations to meet our  ambition of ending plastic pollution by 2040.   We applaud the extraordinary efforts of  leaders in parliaments, governments  on all levels of  jurisdiction , businesses, civil society, scientists, coastal and local communities, Indigenous  Peoples, women, youth, and workers in formal and informal sectors including waste pickers  who are raising the alarm about plastic pollution and calling on governments to finalize  an      effective and ambitious treaty this year. We encourage  everyone to continue  their efforts,  hold governments to account, and mobilize further action. We take seriously our  responsibility as governments to heed their call for action.   As we approach INC -5, we call on all INC members to seize this historic opportunity to  conclude an ambitious and effective  treaty that demonstrates our collective resolve to end  plastic pollution for the benefit of current and future generations.         Members of the High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution  supporting the  Ministerial Joint Statement  for INC-5    Antigua & Barbuda   Armenia   Australia   Austria     Azerbaijan    Benin   Belgium   Bulgaria   Burkina Faso     Cabo Verde   Canada   Chile   Colombia   Cook Island   Costa Rica   Denmark   Dominican Republic   Ecuador   Estonia  European Union   Finland   Fiji  France   Gabon   Georgia   Germany   Ghana   Greenland   Guinea   Iceland   Ireland   Israel   Kenya   Japan   Jordan   Luxembourg   Malawi   Maldives  Mali  Mauritius   Mexico   Micronesia, Federated  States of   Moldova   Monaco   Montenegro   Netherlands   New Zealand   Nigeria   Norway   Palau   Panama   Peru   Portugal   Republic of Korea   Romania   Rwanda       Senegal   Seychelles   Slovenia   Solomon Island s Spain   Sweden   Switzerland   Togo  Ukraine   United Kingdom of Great  Britain and Northern  Ireland   Uruguay

Title: Kuwait on behalf of Like-Minded Countries
file_content: Restricted -  مقيد Opening Statement for INC -5 on Behalf of Like-Minded Countries   Esteemed Chair, distinguished delegates, on behalf of the Like -Minded  Countries, allow me to express our heartfelt gratitude and our sincere appreciation  goes to the Government of Republic of Korea for their gracious hospitality in hosting  this pivotal gat hering. We reaffirm our commitment to achieving a global and  equitable framework that allows all Parties to effectively contribute to addressing  pressing plastic pollution challenges , in the context of broader sustainable  development, recognizing the share d responsibility of all nations.   At the outset, we underscore the need for a pragmatic and inclusive  approach. Our discussions should be driven by evidence -based solutions that are  both effective and implementable across diverse national contexts . We must  focus on results, building consensus  around  workable  strategies  that foster  cooperation and mutual benefit.   In this spirit, we emphasize the importance of maintaining a constructive  atmosphere that is non -adversarial , non -polarizing,  or detracting from our  shared objectives.  Instead, we should center our efforts on identifying common  ground and joint solutions to address plastic pollution.    We firmly believe that solutions should be framed on sustainable  development and the approaches of circularity . Furthermore, the broad and  diverse national circumstances will require nationally driven approaches  in  tackling plastic pollution. Therefore, the assumption that plastic is problematic  globally is not an inclusive one. In addition, waste management and recovery are  key drivers of circularity and reduction of pollution. We must not forget that these  transformative material s also play a significant  role in society by contributing to  advancements in healthcare, food safety, and technology. From life -saving medical  devices to lightweight materials that reduce emissions in transportation, plastics  enable critical infrastructure and innovation while supporting the globa l transition  to more sustainable energy systems. Therefore, any policies within the ILBI on  plastic pollution  should  be thoroughly discussed on its adverse effects on socio - economic development and progression towards sustainable developme nt.  We also wish to raise our concerns regarding the organization of work.  Efficiency and transparency in our processes are essential to ensuring meaningful  progress, yet inclusiveness is a critical element that cannot be undermined . The  latest non -paper from the Chair does not prioritize the most critical issues such as  principles, definitions, and scope. These issues are essential if we are to have a  Restricted -  مقيد meaningful agreement. As such, we strongly urge for incorporation of articles on  principles, scope, and objective s in the non -paper to give these articles equal  treatment as given to other elements of the non -paper.  This must be followed by  adjustments in the organization of work, along with clearer timelines, and adequate  space for substantive input from all parties on the non -paper.    Also, we must anchor our deliberations in the bedrock of the core principle  of Common but  Differentiated Responsibilities (CBDR)  and sustainable  development. It is imperative that any policy framework acknowledges national  circumstances and disparate capacities and circumstances of developing  countries, particularly ensuring that they are not unduly burdened.   We also must acknowledge that the largest share of historical plastic  pollution was created by and originated in developed countries , and this  necessitates a robust commitment to taking lead by developed country to address  plastic pollution , and support developing countr y on means of implementation,  including financial and technological assistance , and technology transfer on  mutually agreed terms. Such support is indispensable for facilitating the transition  to sustainable practices and equitable waste mana gement solutions.   Let us engage in discussions guided by these principles, focusing on areas of  shared concern while remaining open to constructive dialogue . Inclusivity and  consensus -building are paramount , drawing strength from the diverse  perspectives represented in this forum.    Moreover, as we chart a course towards a new treaty, let us heed the  imperative of complementarity, avoiding duplication , and leveraging existing  international frameworks . By aligning our efforts with relevant conventions and  instruments, we can amplify our impact and deliver tangible outcomes.   Last but not least , efficient procedures  for discussion of substantive  provisions will be key for success. Keeping in mind our unfortunate experience in  Ottawa, we strongly support your instruction to contact groups that they should  start with the most convergent issues . It will help to gradually build up trust  before we move to the most divergent topics.  Chair, we appreciate your efforts in  drafting the third non -paper, with the aim of facilitating  the negotiations , along with  the compilation text as the reference document .   As we move forward, we remain committed to constructive dialogue and  collective action. Our goal is a comprehensive, balanced outcome that reflects the  Restricted -  مقيد diverse perspectives and priorities of all member states , while remaining firmly  anchored in practical, achievable solutions.   Thank you, Chair.

Title: Vanuatu on behalf of Pacific Small Island Developing States
file_content: PSIDS Opening Statement for Plenary   Fifth Session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution   25 November 2024, Busan, Republic of Korea   Mr. Chair, Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates,   Vanuatu is speaking on behalf of the 14 member states of the Pacific Small Island  Developing States. We align this statement with those delivered by Samoa on  behalf of the Alliance of Small Islands States. We extend our deepest appreciation  to the Republic  of Korea for its warm hospitality; to you and your team for your  dedication; and to the INC Secretariat for its diligent preparations for this crucial  session.   Plastic pollution poses a direct and disproportionate threat to our islands,  livelihoods, ecosystems and our health. As stewards of vast ocean spaces, we have  been at the forefront of efforts to combat this global crisis and have traveled far to  make sure our voices and the voices of our people are heard in these negotiations.  While we have put in our utmost efforts at the local level, the scale of the challenge  demands a larger, collective, ambitious, and inclusive response.   We approach this session with steadfast resolve to finalize an effective, inclusive  and legally binding instrument that comprehensively addresses the full lifecycle of  plastics. For the Pacific SIDS, in addition to what AOSIS has outlined, we  emphasize the  following:   1. Recognition of the Special Circumstances of SIDS : Pacific SIDS face  disproportionate impacts from plastic pollution, particularly our waters and  shores (thus undermining our sustainable development aspirations). There is  also the potential for SIDS to shoulder a disproportionate burden of action to  address plastic pollution, especially in the marine and coastal environments.   The treaty should recognize these concerns and ensure that we are given the  support needed to fulfill the commitments we will underta ke.    2. Remediation of Existing Plastic Pollution : Binding commitments to  cleanup legacy plastic waste, particularly in the marine environment.   PACIFIC SMALL ISLAND DEVELOPING STATES     Permanent Mission of Vanuatu to the United  Nations   685 3rd Ave, 11th Floor   New York, NY 10017  Phone no.: +1 (212) 661 3403   Email address: psidschair@gmail.com     3. Inclusion of Abandoned, Lost, or Discarded Fishing Gear (ALDFG) :  This persistent form of marine plastic pollution requires dedicated action,  including a potential future work program in coordination with relevant  bodies.   4. Institutional Framework: to tackle this global challenge, we need  subsidiary bodies to provide objective, evidence -based recommendations  and advice, including on how well the treaty performs over time and while  we value consensus, we also need a COP that can take decisive and effe ctive  action.  We stress the relevance of traditional knowledge, knowledge of  Indigenous Peoples, and local knowledge systems as complements to the  best available science in the work of these subsidiary bodies and the  implementatio n of the overall instrument.   5. Financial and Technical Support : SIDS require new, predictable,  additional, and adequate financial resources, alongside capacity -building and  technology transfer suitable for our special circumstances, to implement  treaty obligations effectively.   6. Trade and Transparency: as net importers and users of plastic, we need to  see clear obligations to restrict trade in banned products and chemicals  combined with mandatory disclosure and harmonized labeling to ensure  transparency and allow for informed decision -making.   7. Ending Plastic Pollution: we know that addressing plastic pollution will  need more than just waste management. We need binding obligations to  create safer and longer lasting products that ultimately result in lower  production levels.     Excellency,   We appreciate the work you’ve done in producing the third non -paper, and like  statements made by the US and others before us to start negotiations on the basis of  your third paper but there is still much to be done. We support your proposal to  move quickly to Contact Groups so we can start the real work to share our ideas  and begin crystallizing an ambitious treaty to realize a safe, cleaner future for  generations to come.   Thank you, Mr. Chair.

Title: South Africa on behalf of African Group
file_content: Article 2: Definitions   South Africa on behalf of 54 member states of the Africa Group of Negotiators  supports  the approach of defining terms based on existing  Multilateral Environmental Agreements   and considering the INF documents from previous INCs for specific terms relevant to  articles in the non -paper.   The terms that need definition include b ut not limited to :   plastics[a][b]” means […];   (..) “plastic product[c]s” means […];   (..) “plastic waste” means […];   (..) “microplastics” means […];]   (..) + “Full life cycle assessment”   (..) + “Full life cycle”   (..) + “Plastic Polymers”   (..) + “Sustainable Consumptio n”   (..) + “Sustainable Production”   (..) + “Problematic Plastic Product”   (..) + “Chemicals of Concern” in plastics   (..)+“Emissions” to a tmosphere   (..)+“Releases” to land or water   (..) + “Plastic Pollution”   (..) + “Just Transition”   (..) + “Waste Pickers” are people who participate individually or collectively in the  collection, separation, sorting, transport, ad sale of recyclable and reusable materials  and products in an informal or semi -formal capacity, as own account workers, or a  cooperative or social and solidarity economy setting, and as workers who  subsequently achieved formal work arrangements th rough their organisations.   (..) + “Legacy Plastic Pollution”

Title: Panama on behalf of Panama and a Group of Countries
file_content: Text Proposal     Cross-regional submission by Panama on behalf of Angola, Antigua and Barbuda, Australia,  Bangladesh, Benin, Botswana, Burkina Faso, Burundi, Cabo Verde, Cameroon, Canada, Central  African Republic, Chad, Chile, Colombia, Comoros, Congo, Cote d’Ivoire, Ecuador, Equatorial Guinea,  Eswatini, Ethiopia, European Union and its 27 Member States (Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia,  Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark,  Democratic Rep ublic of the Congo,  Estonia, Finland, France,  Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands,  Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain and Sweden), Gabon, Gambia, Georgia, Ghana,  Guinea, Guinea -Bissau, Iceland, Israel, Lesotho, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Maldives, Mali,  Mauritania, Mauritius, Mexico, Moldova, Monaco, Mozambique, Namibia, New Zealand, Niger,  Nigeria, Norway, Philippines, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Senegal, Seychelles, Sierra Leone,  South Sudan, Sud an, Switzerland, Togo, Ukraine, United Kingdom  and Zambia .    ARTICLE 6   Sustainable Production   1. The Conference of the Parties shall, at its first session, adopt in an annex a global target to  reduce the production of primary plastic polymers to sustainable levels.   2. Each Party shall take measures across the full lifecycle of plastics to achieve the global target  referred to in paragraph 1.   3. Each Party shall report statistical data on its production , imports and exports  of primary plastic  polymers  and the measures taken to achieve the global target referred to in paragraph 1.   4. The Conference of the Parties shall, at its first session, adopt the format , timing ,  methodologies and guidance for the implementation of this Article.  5. The Conference of the Parties shall, every five years,  based on a scientific and economic  assessment by a subsidiary body, review progress in the implementation of this Article and,  as appropriate, update the global target referred to in paragraph 1.

Title: Uruguay on behalf of Group of Latin America and the Caribbean Countries
file_content: Fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment (INC-5)   GROUP OF LATIN AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN COUNTRIES (GRULAC) OPENING STATEMENT   November 2024 – Busan, Republic of Korea  Mr. Chair, I am honored to deliver this statement on behalf of the Group of Latin America and the  Caribbean (GRULAC) countries.  Firstly, we would like to thank the Government of the Republic of Korea for hosting this important meeting and to congratulate, once again, Ambassador Luis Vayas Valdivieso, Chair of the INC, and commend him and his team for the work accomplished, as well as the INC Secretariat for organizing this session.  We recognize the Chair's dedication guiding this process in a transparent way, taking into consideration the open dialogue with our region and the informal INC Heads of Delegations (HoD) meetings.  The GRULAC supports the Chair´s recommendation on the way forward reflected in the Scenario Note, to use the Non-paper 3 as the basis of the negotiations at the INC-5. Nevertheless, we recognize the need to include some key elements that were not considered, to develop treaty text in some provisions and to improve others.   Moreover, while we make substantial progress, the Legal Drafting Group must ensure that the text is reflected in a legally sound manner. GRULAC recognizes the financial efforts that the negotiation rounds entail but regrets that there has been no financing for legal experts proposed by developing countries.  GRULAC would like to highlight that at INC-5 we should agree on all substantial matters and that only the operational aspects can be left to the interim period.  Mr. Chair,   Plastic pollution is a global concern and an urgent crisis that we must address, cognizant of the need to protect human health and the environment from its adverse effects, with special consideration to the needs of developing countries and persons in vulnerable situations.  As GRULAC, we would like to reiterate, our commitment to develop an ambitious and effective International Legally Binding Instrument to end plastic pollution, including in the marine environment based on a comprehensive approach that addresses the full life cycle of plastics, which shall include obligations, control measures, and voluntary measures and be supported by sufficient and robust Means of implementation.    GRULAC stresses the need of advancing the discussions on the provisions related to polymers and chemicals of concern as well as problematic and avoidable plastic products; also, on the establishment of global criteria for the elaboration of lists.  The Instrument must be guided by the key principles of international environmental law, including the Principles of the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development and just transition. It also must incorporate an inclusive transition for waste-pickers; access to information, transparency and accountability; coherence among existing MEAs and the use of the best available science, among others.   It is equally important that it takes into consideration the rights to health and to a clean, healthy, and sustainable environment; the unique vulnerabilities and special circumstances of Small Island Developing States (SIDS); as well as the national circumstances and differentiated capabilities of developing countries.  Furthermore, we underline that the future Instrument should promote decent work throughout the entire value chain of plastics, especially to protect workers from occupational health hazards in the plastics sector, including waste-pickers and other workers in informal and cooperative settings. Just transition may depend upon adequate means of implementation being provided and we should ensure that the transition is just and inclusive for waste pickers and other workers in informal and cooperative settings.  Environmentally sound waste management and improved infrastructure are crucial for our region, and it has been agreed that this Instrument needs to secure external financial, technical and technological support for the improvement of waste management systems.  Waste management must be linked to and integrated with broader measures to protect human health and the environment, especially for vulnerable groups.   GRULAC advocates that the Instrument should promote sustainable production and consumption, evaluate safe substitutes, and implement strategies like Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) where feasible and restrictions on single-use, avoidable and unnecessary plastic products, all tailored to national circumstances and capacities.  GRULAC further stresses that this Instrument must address the remediation of existing plastic pollution including in the marine environment, through collective efforts, international cooperation, and resource provision and mobilization; whereby enhancing coordination with relevant Multilateral Environmental Agreements (MEAs), is crucial for addressing pollution in areas beyond national jurisdiction, which requires a distinct legal and technical approach.  It is fundamental to use the best available science to make informed decisions and to be able to update the Instrument after each COP with the new scientific findings. In this regard, the establishment of a scientific and technical subsidiary body of a multidisciplinary composition, with equitable geographical and gender representation will be critical.  Once again, we would like to stress that developing countries have multidimensional needs, and that all GRULAC countries are developing countries. A strong dedicated financial mechanism is needed to implement the new Instrument, especially in developing countries, which may include but not be limited to the creation of a new fund, new and additional financial resources, capacity building, technical assistance, technology transfer and international cooperation.  Additionally, we are convinced that this Instrument will contribute to filling the gaps of international environmental law and will strengthen, at the same time, other MEAs like the Basel and Stockholm Conventions, Regional Seas Conventions, among others. Coherence, coordination and cooperation must be fostered. In this line, we call for the use of Regional and Subregional Centres as appropriate, to effectively strengthen regional implementation, delivery of technical assistance and capacity building.    Undoubtedly, this Instrument will contribute to addressing the interlinked environmental crises, such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and pollution, which disproportionately affect developing countries.  Finally, GRULAC will strive to make its utmost effort to achieve an International Legally Binding Instrument to end plastic pollution, including in the marine environment, safeguarding our environment and protecting human health for present and future generations.   I thank you

Title: Saudi Arabia on behalf of Arab Group
file_content: Restricted -  مقيد Intervention on Behalf of the Arab Group  on organization of work    (Under agenda item: mandate of contact groups)   Distinguished Chair, esteemed colleagues,   The Arab Group deeply appreciates the dedication shown in  advancing our collective mission to address plastic pollution and the  Chair’s efforts to streamline the discussions with the ambition of  concluding by this session. We also wish to thank the Chair f or  providing the supplementary note, which we found to be a step  forward in guiding our work and focusing our negotiations.    1. Formal Discussions on Core Elements:   Chair, we emphasize that principles, objectives, and scope are the  cornerstone of this agreement  and must be treated as overarching  provisions guiding the entire framework. These critical elements  provide the vision and structure for the treaty and should receive  equal and fair treatment  through formal discussions in a contact  group, not informal settings, which lack the transparency and  inclusivity needed to address the diverse perspectives of all nations.    To ensure these elements are prioritized, we request replacing  Articles 17, 18, and 19 with objectives, scope, and principles  under the mandate of Contact Group 4 (CG4) . This adjustment will  allow for structured and inclusive debate to reflect their importance  and ensure they are addressed with the seriousness they deserve.    This is not just a procedural request, it is substantive. A strong,  shared understanding of these provisions is essential for the     Restricted -  مقيد success, integrity, and ambition of the agreement. Addressing them  early and formally is crucial to achieving a fair and effective outcome.      2. Non-Paper as a starting point  for negotiation :  Chair, while we acknowledge your efforts and the proposed Chair’s  non-paper, from the Arab group we are in the view that this paper in  its current form cannot serve as basis for our negotiations.  The  reality is that many countries do not see themselves represented in  this paper , we request  to start the process by allowing reflections and  submissions from parties and to include missing  countries positions  and options  then to present more balanced revised version that  could be further considered by the Parties .  Chair, this is a party - driven process, as you often emphasize, and we trust your leadership  and responsibi lity for     ensuring these concerns are addressed. We cannot proceed without  these conditions being met.   we would like to also  seek your clarification of  the mode of work and  how party submissions will be handled. Specifically, we seek  guidance on how submissions will be reviewed, incorporated, and  reflected in a revised version of the non-paper to ensure it evolves  into a text that can potentially serve as the basis for our  negotiations.    Transparency in this process is essential to maintain trust and ensure  all parties feel their positions are accurately captured. We request  clear information on:       Restricted -  مقيد 1. How submissions will be integrated into a new revised version  of the non-paper.    2. When and how a revised version  will be shared with parties for  feedback.    The Arab Group remains committed to a collaborative process  leading to a fair and effective international instrument.   Thank you for your attention.

Title: Hungary on behalf of European Union and it's 27 Member States
file_content: Closing Statement    by the EU and its 27 memberstates at the closing plenary session  of the   INC5 (25 November -25 December,  Busan, Republic of Korea)     Chair, distinguished delegates, colleagues,   I deliver this statement on behalf of t he EU and its 27 Member States  and would ask that this  statement is recorded in the report of this meeting .   We would like to thank you , Chair , and your  team, the INC Secretariat,  and UNEP  as well as  fellow delegates and observers and stakeholders  for your hard work .  Our special thanks  and  appreciation go to the Republic  of Korea , for its commitment and hospitality.  You made sure  that delegates could work in the best possible conditions and that the organization  ran  smoothly. Korea, Busan, Kansammida.   We also align with the statement made by Rwanda on behalf of 85 members  of this  Committee as well as with the statement by Mexico on 95 members of this Committee . We  share the  unhappiness that can be felt i n this room , with the limited amount of progress we  were able to make this week.  When we arrived in Busan, we had a clear purpose: to reach an  agreement on decisive action to end plastic pollution  by addressing the whole life cycle of  plastics, as we were mandated to do by UNEA Resolution 5/14 .  However , Mr Chair,  to the regret of many in th e room,  this did not happen , despite the tireless   efforts of  so many of  us, including the stakeholders,  who worked until the morning hours in  the hopes  of secur ing a successful result.   This said , we are not leaving Busan discouraged. To the contrary. We feel encouraged and  empowered by the overwhelming support that joint initiatives on substantive provisions   have received , some supported by   more than 100 ambitious  countries . And this support  will  continue to grow , as we saw it growing from one  INC session to  the next over the last t wo  years.   Mr C hair,  we stand at a critical juncture. On substance and process.  And we need both  to  work in synerg y if we are to  succeed.   On substanc e, our message in this room has been very clear :   We cannot support  an agreement IF it would  fail to efficiently  address the core problems at  hand . IF it doesn’t have  legally binding global measures .   So, w hat a re those essential global measures , Mr Chair ? A meaningful treaty must contain  concrete measures to reduce  the production levels of  plastic  to sustainable levels ,   It must  address  problematic and avoidable  plastic products, and chemicals of concern in  plastic products – in addition to waste management  and the  implementation of Extended  producer  responsibility schemes.   It needs  to allow the mobilization of resources  at international and domestic levels, including   an efficient  financial  mechanism  to support the parties that need it the most.   It needs to foster consensus, but also allow  for voting when consensus cannot be reached.   This is the bare minimum required for this treaty to  make a real impact.    Rest assured, Mr Chair, t he European Union and its M ember States will continue to strive  for  an effective  agreement.   We will continue to build bridges  and w e pledge to work  in  good faith to make a significant  leap towards ending plastic pollution.    Our vision is for a treaty that brings tangible change to the environment and benefits people   and economies  around the world. This is about right to health , a clean , healthy and  sustainable environment  for younger and future generations . The clear signal from Busan  must therefore be that this chair's text needs to be the starting point and basis for the final  sprint towards an ambitious treaty . We take note of your understanding that additions,  deletions, changes and complements can still be made to the totality of the text, in accordance  with the principle that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed.   To be very clear , Mr Chair, this means we have a lot of homework in all aspects of the draft  you have  put before  us to bring the ambition  back  into the text wherever  it is  currently   missing.     You have  the support of the EU and its Member States moving forward – but we are also  asking you, Mr Chair  - to reflect on how we can better work together , including with  ministerial  involvement  in the final stages of our negotiations at a resumed sessions , which  must see the conclusion of our negotiations .   I thank you.

Title: Uruguay on behalf of Group of Latin America and the Caribbean Countries
file_content: Fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop an international Legally Binding Instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment (INC-5) GROUP OF LATIN AMERICA AND THE CARIBBEAN COUNTRIES (GRULAC) CLOSING STATEMENT 1 December 2024 – Busan, Republic of Korea Mr. Chair , distinguished delegates, I have the honor to deliver this statement on behalf of the Group of Latin America and the Caribbean countries (GRULAC). We kindly request that our intervention is recorded in this meeting’ s report. First, we wish to express our deep appreciation to the Government and people of The Republic of Korea for their gracious hospitality in the hosting of this meeting in the beautiful city of Busan. We also thank the tireless efforts of the Chair , Vice Chairs, the Co-Chairs, the facilitators, the Secretariat and our fellow negotiators throughout this challenging and complex week. The progress achieved reflects the dedication of all Parties involved, and we acknowledge the important advancements made during this session. As GRULAC, we firmly believe that the importance of this issue—ending plastic pollution and its adverse impacts on our planet and future generations—demands that we strive for an agreement of the highest standard. We cannot compromise on ambition or effectiveness for the sake of expediency . GRULAC recognizes that the Chair ’s text, while an improvement from the last version, does not accurately reflect all the proposals submitted during the contact group discussions. Some provisions are reflected as clean text, while remaining highly divergent. There is no clear understanding why some proposals are immediately included and others are set aside. This week, negotiations have highlighted the lack of convergence on critical issues that are essential for achieving the ambitious and effective agreement that the world expects from us. These continued divergences underscore the need for further dialogue and reflection. Nonetheless, GRULAC can support it as a new basis for discussions at the resumed session, with the understanding that the whole text is still open to negotiations underthe principle that nothing is agreed, until everything is agree d. We truly believe that ambition is key for all provisions, including for regulatory obligations, just transition, subsidiary bodies on science, implementation, compliance and cooperation, and equally on means of implementation. We would also like to underline the importance of having a clear organization of work when we meet again. During this week here in Busan we have faced great procedural difficulties that could have been avoided, and we kindly request that these issues are addressed in the future. Our region recognizes that Article 3 will be a crucial element for this Treaty that requires further negotiations, particularly high ambition and clear criteria based on the best available science and recognizing national circumstances and capabilities, in order to fulfill the mandate that was agreed by UNEA Resolution 5/14 Furthermore, we request that we start to discuss Article 11 from day one, as this was not the case at INC-5. We ask that further discussion on the matter be conducted in an inclusive, democratic and constructive way, with no time limits. We really count on your solidarity towards the developing world on that. Our region is fully committed to continue engaging constructively in this process, including through intersessional work. At this stage, we believe that we need to allocate more time to address unresolved issues and build greater convergence among all Parties . This is a reflection of the complexity of the task at hand and our shared commitment to finding durable, inclusive, and impactful solutions, that involve all stakeholders, and ensure a just transition, that leaves no one behind. Mr. Chair , we stand ready to continue our collaboration with all regions and stakeholders to achieve a legally binding instrument that fulfills its mission and upholds the principles we have all agreed upon. Let us move forward with determination, flexibility , and an unwavering sense of purpose. Thank you.

Title: Kuwait on behalf of Like-Minded Countries
file_content: Here’s an expanded version of your statement, reaching approximately 1, 700 words:     Statement for the Plenary – 1st December 2024   Dear Chair,   Kuwait is speaking on behalf of the like minded countries .   We would like to acknowledge the expression of solidarity demonstrated earlier and appreciate the  engagement of those who had the privilege of being present in this room. However, it is important to  note that we speak on behalf of member states representing over 50% of the world’s population.  This collective voice highlights the perspectives and priorities of a significant portion of humanity,  many of whom do not share the same privilege of participation here. This is why the principle of  consensus is so essential —ensuring that all voices, including tho se not physically present, are  equally valued and respected in shaping our collective decisions."   Our collective presence here reaffirms a shared commitment to tackling the global challenge of  plastic pollution —a commitment that is grounded in good faith, mutual respect, and the vision of a  plastic pollution -free future . However, we must also express our growing concern about the  direction and conduct of these negotiations, which at times appear increasingly opaque and  rushed.   Historical Context of the Agreement   This process was born out of a shared understanding that the challenge of plastic pollution is one  of the pressing environmental issues of our time, requiring coordinated, collective, and deliberate  action. At the United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA) 5.2, we reached a historic agreement  to develop an international instrument to address this challenge —a testament to the power of  multilateralism.   That moment of unity demonstrated our collective resolve to find solutions that balance  environmental, economic, and social considerations. However, just two years and five sessions into  these negotiations, we find ourselves alarmed by a troubling trend —a rush to showcase progress at  the expense of achieving the substance and inclusivity required for a robust and effective treaty.   The principles of collaboration, which have guided successful multilateral environmental treaties in  the past, are overshadowed by the pursuit of expediency. Such an approach threatens the integrity  of the treaty, undermines trust among parties, and jeopardizes the very foundation of this critical  process.   As we navigate these negotiations, it is vital to draw lessons from history. The Minamata Convention  on Mercury serves as a prime example of what can be achieved when countries are given the time  and space to engage in a meaningful dialogue.    What made the Minamata process successful was its adherence to the principles of inclusivity,  consensus, and respect for diverse perspectives. Countries were allowed to collaborate in good  faith, build consensus on contentious issues, and ensure that the final treaty was both practical  and actionable. This approach fostered trust among all parties and resulted in a treaty that was  both effective and widely supported.  On Inclusivity and Consensus   Chair, The principles of inclusivity and consensus are the bedrock of international environmental  agreements. They ensure that all voices are heard, all perspectives are considered, and all  concerns are addressed.   Let us be unequivocal: rushing to impose decisions without hearing all voices undermines not only  the trust in this treaty process but also the credibility of the United Nations Environment Program  (UNEP) as a whole. A system built on consensus must respec t the diversity of opinions and ensure  that all parties feel their concerns are valued and addressed.   Misinterpretation of the Mandate   When we embarked on this process, we did so with a clear and shared understanding of the  mandate set forth by UNEA 5.2: to develop an international instrument to end plastic pollution. This  mandate is both specific and ambitious, requiring us to focus on a ddressing the problem of plastic  pollution in a manner that is practical, equitable, and effective.   Chair, however, we have observed attempts to stretch this mandate beyond its original intent,  turning it into a pretext for advancing trade restrictions, economic agendas, and commercial  competition under the guise of environmental action. Such distortions are not  only  counterproductive but also undermine the trust and goodwill that underpin this process.   Let us remind ourselves of the mandate’s language: the goal is to “end plastic pollution,” Any  deviation from this clear directive threatens the integrity of this treaty and the legitimacy of our  collective work.   Economic and Practical Realities   Throughout these discussions, we have listened patiently to the proposals and interventions of  various stakeholders. Yet, we are struck by the lack of focus on actionable solutions grounded in  economic and practical realities. Instead of addressing the cor e issue of plastic pollution —such as  through improved waste management systems, recycling infrastructure, and innovations in  material design —we see a proliferation of unattainable goals and individual agendas.   The absence of diligence in defining the treaty’s scope is deeply concerning. Introducing unrelated  national interests and unrealistic targets undermines our ability to reach a focused and effective  agreement. Moreover, the proposed obligations for develop ing countries often far exceed their  capacities to meet them.   This imbalance is not only unfair but also dangerous. It risks creating a treaty that is neither  implementable nor enforceable, setting a harmful precedent for future multilateral agreements. A  successful treaty must be equitable, taking into account the d iffering circumstances, capabilities,  and priorities of all parties.    Trade measures, such as global lists, are being proposed in the non -papers. A party’s Right to  Reservation remains  missing from the proposed texts received from the Chair  (refer to article 23 of CITES -  Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora | CITES ). The article on Scope was present in non - paper 4 yet has been removed from the new text received today 1 pm. Proposed definitions are  vague and confusing .  Call for Collaboration   Chair, the like -minded countries remain steadfast in their commitment to this process. I must  repeat here what I’ve heard from so many fair participants in Busan – our group of countries are the  only ones who came here to negotiate. However, we firmly reject any attempts to distort the  principles of inclusivity and fairness.   We reiterate that the objective of this treaty is to end plastic pollution —not plastic itself. Plastic has  brought immense benefits to societies worldwide, from advancing healthcare and infrastructure to  supporting modern agriculture and renewable energy s ystems. Attempting to phase out plastic as a  material, rather than addressing the issue of plastic pollution, risks undermining global progress  and exacerbating economic inequalities.   Moreover, we must confront the reality that we haven’t heard any solution offered thus far on what  materials will replace plastic in a variety of applications .   Proposal for the Way Forward   1. To restore trust and ensure a meaningful outcome, we propose allowing the negotiations to  be focused on consensus -building, to allow for deeper engagement and the resolution of  outstanding issues. This should be accompanied by a renewed focus on the principles of  multilateralism , fostering inclusivity, and addressing the legitimate concerns of all parties.   In this context, the new Chair’s Text document received today morning  can be accepted as  a starting point among other options . However, it should start with the entire text and all  proposed articles in brackets . As some of our issues haven’t been reflected including the  articles that have been requested to be bracketed by many and the issue of decision making  that are not reflected in the final provisions   In Conclusion   Together, let us reaffirm our commitment to a fair, balanced, and effective agreement —one that  serves humanity and the environment without compromising the principles of fairness, inclusivity,  and multilateralism.   Thank you.

Title: Bangladesh
file_content: Opening Statements:   Mr Chair , distinguished  guests, delegates, observers, ladies and gentlemen,     First of all, Bangladesh delegates  would like to  thank the host country  Republic of Korea, INC  secretariat,  for arranging thi s fifth meeting of INC .   Although we have non-paper 3.0 as a guiding document, but a matter of fact that, we  are stuck  with more than 70 pages of compilation text. Therefore, our sincere effort, due diligence, and  practical flexibility in this meeting will  determine our success .   We appreciate the sequence of the elements given in the third non -paper but the text should be  derived from revised compil e text.   Peoples Republic of Bangladesh would like to emphasize three issues to be included in the INC  text.   Firstly , controlling  emissions  and releases, considering the transboundary nature of plastic  pollution, secondly , a dedicated program of work to address the legacy plastic pollution and  finally , the improv ement of  the plastic waste management system .    i) Farther more Bangladesh bel ieves that listing and phasing out problematic plastic  especially single -use plastic would be beneficial for promoting circularity.     ii) Bangladesh is in favour of listing and phasing out hazardous chemicals that have been   being  used in plastic manufacturing. We have to be mindful that the listing and phasing  should not overlap with other MEAs.   Last but not least , we expect the INC text to be an inclusive treaty where everyone's voice is heard  and duly reflected.  In this regard,  Bang ladesh welcomes  the orthodox style of  solving  this complex  issue through possible  informal discussion.    Mr, Chair, we believe in your leadership and committed for every possible w ork to finalize the  negotiation process to end plastic pollution.    Thank you  Chair.

Title: Burkina Faso
file_content: DECLARATION DU BURKINA FASO S UR L E DOCUMENT  OFFICIEUX DU PR ESIDENT DE L ’INC    Merci Monsieur le Président,     Le Burkina Faso  tient à remercier le Gouvernement de la République de Corée  de  nous avoir accueillis dans cette somptueuse  ville de Busan . Nous remercions  également  le Secrétariat d e l’INC  pour l’organisation  réussie de cette  session .     Monsieur le Présid ent,  À la suite des travaux des groupes d'experts intersessions à Bangkok, des  consultations informelles et des réunions des chefs de délégation d'août à  novembre 2024, la cinquième session du Comité de négociation  intergouverneme ntal sur la pollution plastique ( INC-5) entame officiellement la  phase finale des négociations ce 25 novembre.     Ainsi en alignement  à la Déclaratio n du Mali, Pays membre de l’Alliance des Etats  du Sahel ( AES ), à la déclaration du Ghana au nom du Groupe Afrique, le Burkina  Faso estime que l e troisième document officieux du Président pourrait être une  base pour les tr avaux de groupe  à venir .    Au cours de la l’INC -5, le niveau global d'ambition du texte proposé dans le  document officieux doit être élevé, et les principales lacunes doivent être  comblées.     Cela dit, le Burkina Faso consid ère qu’il serait important que le processus reste le  plus inclusif possible  et avec toute la transparence  qui sie d. C’est aussi pourquoi ,  le document doit être adopt é sur la base du consensus .     Merci  Monsieur le Président  !    Fait à Busan le 25 novembre 202 4

Title: Chile
file_content: Intervención de Apertura INC 5 - Chile   Señor Presidente, Con el compromiso de avanzar prontamente al trabajo en Grupos de Contacto, la delegación de Chile no hará uso de la palabra en Plenario.   Chile reitera su compromiso con este proceso negociador, que tiene como objetivo elaborar un Acuerdo que nos permita terminar con la contaminación por plásticos, mediante acciones concretas y efectivas, con un enfoque que considere todo el ciclo de vida de los plásticos.  Por ello, consideramos esencial usar el tiempo de forma eficiente, y evitar dilaciones. Agradecemos, Sr. Presidente, su liderazgo en este proceso y su constante esfuerzo por guiar a este Comité Intergubernamental de Negociación en su ambición de terminar este Acuerdo durante estos días en Busan.  Apoyamos el modo de trabajo que ha propuesto para esta sesión, esperando que ello contribuya a acercar posiciones e identificar espacios de convergencia. Sabemos que serán días intensos, y Chile, tal como lo ha hecho desde el inicio de esta negociación y en las reuniones sucesivas del Comité Intergubernamental, está dispuesto a asumir el desafío para que este instrumento sea una real respuesta del multilateralismo a un problema urgente. Esta crisis es un problema transfronterizo global, que requiere de soluciones colectivas y a su vez implementables. Para ello, será indispensable que los países en desarrollo podamos contar con medios de implementación que nos permitan dar cumplimiento a las disposiciones del Acuerdo, de una forma flexible y de acuerdo con nuestras diferentes circunstancias nacionales. Para hacer frente a este problema debemos ser innovadores: no basta con las fuentes de financiamiento tradicionales, sino que debemos incorporar financiamiento público, privado, y herramientas de gestión como los sistemas de Responsabilidad Extendida del Productor.  Una fuente por sí sola no será suficiente, y debemos considerar necesidades tanto de prevención y manejo como de remediación, teniendo siempre en cuenta el principio de quien contamina paga.  Sr. Presidente, La relación entre la producción de plástico y la contaminación es clara.  La evidencia científica en este sentido nos indica que mantener el escenario actual de crecimiento de la producción es insostenible.  La definición de niveles de producción sostenibles es esencial, y para ello, el compromiso de las Partes de hacer un trabajo que permita definir líneas de base y determinar metas globales de reducción. Es por ello que la ciencia debe estar al centro de este Acuerdo. La evidencia científica robusta debe guiar la toma de decisiones. Ello, acompañado de disposiciones de trazabilidad y transparencia que nos permitan garantizar el derecho a la información, monitorear el progreso de las Partes, promover el cumplimiento, la efectividad y la confianza en la implementación del Acuerdo. Además, no debemos olvidar la importancia de mejorar las disposiciones asociadas al diseño de los productos. Extender la vida útil de éstos, y potenciar el reúso y el reciclaje son importantes medidas para reducir la contaminación por plásticos. Una vez más, Sr. Presidente, recordamos la importancia del medio marino en este Acuerdo.  Chile tiene una larga costa y territorios insulares, y por ello conocemos bien el impacto de la contaminación por plásticos en el océano y en las comunidades costeras.  No basta con medidas de reducción sino también de remediación para hacer frente a la contaminación existente en el medio marino, reconociendo que es un problema que afecta directamente a países costeros, a nuestras comunidades y a sus formas de vida.   Chile reconoce el impacto de la contaminación por plásticos en la salud humana, y la importancia de incorporar disposiciones en el Acuerdo para identificar y proteger a las poblaciones en riesgo. La contaminación por plásticos nos afecta a todos, pero no de la misma forma. Por ello, es fundamental que se tome en consideración a las poblaciones en condiciones de vulnerabilidad y sus realidades.  De igual manera instamos para que exista una trazabilidad de género, a través de datos desagregados, que permita abordar adecuadamente este problema desde esa perspectiva.  Finalmente, Sr. Presidente, no podemos olvidar el rol que los trabajadores informales, en particular los recicladores de base, han cumplido y siguen cumpliendo en esta materia que nos convoca.  Desde que se negoció la Resolución 5/14 Chile ha reconocido su contribución para hacer frente a la contaminación por plásticos hasta la fecha y lo importante que es incluirlos en las soluciones e innovaciones que deriven de este Acuerdo.  Necesitamos una transición justa, que no deje a nadie atrás.

Title: China
file_content: 1中国代表团在塑料污染国际文书政府间谈判委员会 第五次会议上的一般性发言 中国代表团感谢东道主韩国政府为召开本次会议所提供的周到 安排，并向大会主席、秘书处以及联合国环境规划署为会议筹备工 作所付出的不懈努力表示衷心的感谢。 中国高度重视塑料污染治理的全球合作，并对国际社会在这一 领域展现的共同努力深表赞赏。 经过INC前四次会议及闭会期间专家组会议上各成员国的积 极参与，以及主席团及秘书处的共同努力，各方开展了富有成效的 讨论，形成的主席文件和汇编案文为INC-5谈判奠定了较好的基础。 但应该看到，各方在一些关键议题仍存较大分歧。此次会议作为联 合国环境大会5/14决议授权召开的最后一次会议，各方能否展现足 够包容性，弥合分歧，推动在核心议题上取得实质性突破，将对是 否能按时达成具有法律约束力的塑料污染国际文书具有决定性意义。 在此，中国代表团提出以下建议： 一是聚焦文书初衷，推动实质性共识。塑料污染治理的核心 是如何避免塑料废弃物泄漏对环境的影响。我们呼吁各方秉持多边 主义精神，本着合作与共赢、携手应对塑料污染的初衷，严格按照 联合国环境大会授权，集中精力围绕如何避免塑料废弃物泄漏进入 环境造成污染这一核心内容进行谈判，以增强文书的针对性。 二是尊重国家差异，体现公平与包容。各国在塑料污染治理 能力、技术水平及资源可及性方面存在显著差异。国际文书应尊重2各国国情与发展阶段，全面考虑其普遍接受性和实施效果，并通过 资金、技术与能力建设支持，为全球塑料污染治理注入新的动力， 帮助发展中国家逐步实现治理目标。 三是坚持务实灵活，达成可操作性成果。针对技术复杂、实 施难度高的问题，我们建议探索阶段性解决方案，为各国预留灵活 空间，以确保文书既具有雄心，又切实可行，并为最终全面实现全 球塑料污染治理目标打下坚实基础。 INC-5期间，中国代表团将与各方密切合作，聚焦于增进理解， 弥合分歧，通过开放真诚的沟通，为达成兼具雄心和务实的塑料污 染国际文书共同努力。中方也将一如既往积极配合主席和秘书处的 工作，加强与各方交流，为文书的最终达成贡献力量。 谢谢大家！3Translation.Incaseofanydiscrepancy,theChineseversionshallprevail. NationalStatement TheChinesedelegationexpressesitssinceregratitudetothehost,theGovernment oftheRepublicofKorea,forthemeticulousarrangementsforthisconference.We wouldalsoliketoextendourheartfeltthankstotheINCChair,H.EMr.Luis VayasValdivieso,theINCSecretariat,andtheUnitedNationsEnvironment Programme(UNEP)fortheirdedicationinpreparingforthismeeting. Chinahighlyvaluesglobalcooperationtoaddressplasticpollutionandappreciates theongoingcollectiveeffortsoftheinternationalcommunityinthisregard. ThroughtheactiveparticipationofMembersinthepreviousfourINCsessionsand theintersessionalexpertgroupmeetings,coupledwithconcertedeffortsfromthe BureauandtheSecretariat,wehavehadfruitfuldiscussions.Thecompilationtext, togetherwithChair’sNon-paperservesasafacilitatingfoundationfortheINC-5 negotiations.However,itisimportanttorecognizethatsignificantdivergences remainonsomekeyissues.Giventhatthissessionisthelastformalmeetingunder themandateofUNEAResolution5/14,itisofdecisivesignificancethatallsides demonstratesufficientinclusiveness,bridgedivergences,andachievesubstantive breakthroughsoncoreissues,inordertoreachaninternationallegallybinding instrumentonplasticpollution.Inthiscontext,theChinesedelegationproposesthe following:4First,focusonwhywestartedandfostersubstantiveconsensus.Theessenceof tacklingplasticpollutionliesinpreventingtheenvironmentalimpactscausedby plasticwasteleakage.Wecallforallmemberstoactinthespiritofmultilateralism, andfollowourprimaryintention,namelyaddressingplasticpollutionwith cooperationandjointefforts.Weshouldstrictlyfollowthemandategrantedbythe UNEA,andconcentrateonthecriticalissueofpreventingplasticwasteleakage intotheenvironment,sothattheinstrumentcouldbemoreorientedtowardsits purpose. Second,respectnationalcircumstancesandreflectequityandinclusiveness. Capabilities,technologicallevels,andresourceavailabilityforaddressingplastic pollutionvaryfromcountrytocountry.Theinstrumentshouldrespecteach country'suniqueconditionsanddevelopmentstages,fullyconsiderwhetheritis appropriatetouniversallyapplysomeactionsandimplementationeffectiveness. Additionally,sufficientsupportthroughfunding,technology,andcapacitybuilding shouldbeprovidedfordevelopingcountriesintheirphasedeffortstotackleplastic pollution,injectingnewmomentumintoglobalplasticpollutioncontrol. Third,movetowardpracticalresultswithflexibility.Referringtoissuesthatare technicallycomplexandchallengingtotackle,weproposeexploringstaged solutionstoprovidecountrieswiththeflexibilityneededtoensurethatthe instrumentisbothambitiousandfeasible.Thisapproachwilllayasolidfoundation5fortheultimate,comprehensiveachievementofglobalgoalofaddressingplastic pollution. DuringINC-5thisweek,theChinesedelegationwillworkcloselywithall Memberstoenhancemutualunderstandingandnarrowdifferencesthroughopen andsincerecommunication,strivingtoachieveabothambitiousandpractical instrument.ChinaremainscommittedtocooperatingwiththeChairandthe Secretariat,enhancingexchangeswithallMembers,contributingsignificantlyto thesuccessfulconclusionoftheinstrument. Thankyou.

Title: Colombia
file_content: Intervención de Colombia en la Plenaria de Apertura del Comité  Intergubernamental de Negociación sobre plásticos (INC-5)  Gracias señor Presidente,   Primero que todo me gustaría agradecer al Gobierno de la República de Corea  por su  hospitalidad y  por albergar esta importante reunión, así como a usted, su equipo, y a  la Secretaria  por la organización de esta importante y última sesión del INC .   Señor Presidente, distinguid os Delegados,   Como ya fue mencionado por Uruguay en nombre d el GRULAC, Colombia también  agradece y reconoce su liderazgo al presentar el Non -Paper 3. Consideramos que este  documento representa un avance significativo y ofrece una base razonable para  nuestras negociaciones . Si bien a ún persisten elementos clave que deben ser  abordados de una mejor manera . Sobre los cual es nos referiremos en detalle en los  respectivos grupos de contacto , creemos firmemente en la importancia de contar con  una base común que facilite acuerdos concretos y ambiciosos . Apoyamos el uso de  este documento como base para el debate  e invitamos a los demás países a que  apoyen esta iniciativa .   La crisis de la contaminación por plásticos nos exige a todos actuar con urgencia,  ambición y responsabilidad colectiva. Al respecto, quisiera destacar nuestro mandato  para finalizar un acuerdo en este INC 5, para el cual solo contamos con una semana .  No alcanzar un acuerdo sobre este asunto, sería una oportunidad perdida inaceptable .    Hacemos un llamado a las delegaciones a mostrar la ambición requerida para  responder al mandato de la resolución 5/14 de la UNEA, y a construir un instrumento  verdaderamente transformador que elimine las fallas sistémicas que han permitido la  contaminación  plástica.   Colombia resalta la importancia de llevar un proceso con transparencia , en el que  todas la s distintas posiciones se vean reflejadas. Sin embargo, v emos con  preocupación las propuestas que posponen el inicio de las negociaciones  sobre  asuntos sustantivos.  Nuestra invitación es  iniciar las negociaciones  en los grupos de  contacto sin dilación , sin perjuicio de que los asuntos pendientes a ser incluidos o las  propuestas alternat ivas puedan ser abordados  en el respe ctivo grupo.   Colombia reafirma su compromiso de trabajar de manera constructiva y colaborativa  para asegurar que este proceso culmine en un tratado robusto, equitativo y eficaz.  Señor Presidente, contamos con su liderazgo y con la voluntad de todos los presentes  para lograr este objetivo.  Muchas gracias  señor Presidente .

Title: Cook Island (Delegate specialised agencies)
file_content: Cook  Islands  Government     STATEMENT  BY COOK  ISLANDS  DURING  THE OPENING  PLENARY   OF INC-5 ON 25TH NOVEMBER,  2024,  BUSAN,  SOUTH  KOREA       1. Thank  you, Mr Chair.  As this is the first time the Cook  Islands  is taking  the floor -  may I take this opportunity  to thank  the Republic  of Korea  for hosting  our  gathering  this week  for INC-5 here in Busan.      2. We would  also like to congratulate  the secretariate  for the organization  of the  INC-5 this week.     3. The Cook  Islands  aligns  with the statement  from AOSIS,  PSIDS,  and support   Rwanda,  Uruguay  and many  other  members  to use your third non-paper  as our  basis  for negotiations  at INC-5 to ensure  we progress  this week’s  program  of  work.      4. Members  expressed  their initial  views  of elements  to be included  or discussed,   which  suggestions  can be made  through  the non-paper.      5. The non-paper  is a good  starting  point  for negotiations,  and we urge you Chair   that we waste  no time and move  to the Contact  Groups  as soon  as possible.     6. Thank  you Chair.

Title: Guatemala
file_content: DISCURSO DE APERTURA Comité Intergubernamental de Negociación para desarrollar un instrumento internacional jurídicamente vinculante sobre la contaminación plástica, incluido el medio marino Busan, República de Corea 25 de noviembre de 2024 Señor Presidente, Distinguidos delegados Deseo expresar el más sincero agradecimiento, en nombre de la República de Guatemala, a la secretaría del INC y al Gobierno de la República de Corea por hospedar está Quinta Sesión. Hoy me presento ante ustedes en nombre de Guatemala, un país de vasta riqueza natural, de selvas que albergan una biodiversidad única, de montañas, ríos y costas que reflejan la majestuosidad de nuestro planeta y que nos cataloga como uno de los diecisiete países megadiversos del mundo. Pero también me presento con una voz de preocupación, porque esta riqueza, este patrimonio que pertenece a los guatemaltecos y a toda la humanidad, está bajo amenaza. La contaminación por plásticos se ha convertido en uno de los retos ambientales más graves de nuestro tiempo, no discrimina, no distingue entre naciones, ni entre ecosistemas terrestres, acuáticos o marinos. Desde los desechos visibles en nuestros ríos y playas hasta los microplásticos que circulan de manera imperceptible en el agua que consumimos, esta crisis afecta a todos por igual. Estamos aquí con esperanza y con la firme determinación de unirnos en torno a una causa común en este proceso que representa una oportunidad para que juntos tracemos un camino hacia un futuro más limpio, más verde y más equitativo para todos. Guatemala ha sido impactada por los efectos devastadores de la contaminación por plástico en su entorno y sus habitantes resienten el impacto de este problema. Tomando en consideración en todo momento las circunstancias y capacidades nacionales especialmente de los países en desarrollo, no deberían existir excusas para la inacción, ni mucho menos un impedimento para alcanzar nuestro objetivo; en esesentido reiteramos nuestra firme voluntad para actuar ante el llamado de la Resolución 5/14. Este espacio representa una oportunidad para mejorar la producción y consumo sostenible del plástico, lo cual beneficiará la calidad de nuestro ambiente y a su vez, contribuirá a sobrellevar otros desafíos globales como el cambio climático. Necesitamos un marco que sea justo. La transferencia de tecnología, el financiamiento adecuado y el fortalecimiento de capacidades son esenciales para garantizar que todos los países puedan cumplir con los compromisos. Distinguidos delegados, el tiempo apremia. No podemos darnos el lujo de seguir postergando decisiones. No podemos seguir negociando mientras nuestros océanos se llenan de plástico, mientras nuestras comunidades enfrentan crisis de salud relacionadas con la contaminación, especialmente en las poblaciones más vulnerables, los pueblos indígenas y los trabajadores del sector informal durante todo el ciclo de vida del plástico. Quiero también hacer un llamado a reconocer el trabajo de los recolectores de base, personas que trabajan arduamente en condiciones difíciles y, muchas veces, en el anonimato. Su labor debe ser reconocida e integrada en las soluciones que diseñemos. Distinguidos delegados, este es el momento de demostrar que, como humanidad, somos capaces de priorizar el bienestar de nuestro planeta actuando con determinación, con ambición y con un sentido de responsabilidad histórica. La Quinta Sesión de este Comité debe marcar un antes y un después; una diferencia entre el “puede” y el “debe”. Necesitamos darle al mundo un tratado que no solo sea ambicioso, sino también efectivo y aplicable. Un tratado que establezca claramente las líneas de acción para alcanzar un objetivo en común. Hoy reafirmamos nuestro compromiso de implementar las acciones necesarias para cumplir con este tratado. Pedimos a este Comité que trabajemos juntos y no dejemos a nadie atrás. Porque al final, esta lucha no es solo por nosotros, sino por las generaciones futuras.Hagamos de esta Quinta Sesión un hito histórico. Un punto de inflexión que marque el inicio de un mundo más limpio, más verde y más equitativo para todos. Consideramos que la propuesta del Presidente es una herramienta sujeta a mejora que permitirá facilitar las reuniones de trabajo, las cuales alentamos a iniciar a la brevedad posible. Muchas gracias.

Title: Honduras
file_content: Intervención de Honduras en apoyo a Non -paper .    Excelentísimos miembros de la Asamblea de las Naciones Unidas para el Medio  Ambiente, distinguido Comité de Negociación del Tratado sobre la Contaminación por  Plásticos, señoras y señores:     Como representante de Honduras quisiera expresar mi más sincero agradecimiento  por la oportunidad de dirigirme a este foro de tanta relevancia global y agradecer al  Corea del Sur por su grata bienvenida.     Es un honor representar a un país profundamente comprometido con la protección  de la naturaleza, la conservación de nuestros recursos naturales y la mejora continua  de la calidad de vida de nuestras comunidades. Reconocemos que estos ideales  requieren esfu erzo constante, particularmente en el contexto de las limitaciones  económicas y sociales que enfrentamos como nación en desarrollo.     Valoramos el trabajo dedicado que ha dado forma al documento que hoy orienta  nuestras negociaciones. Lo acogemos con esperanza, pero también con una mirada  crítica, ya que consideramos que aún persisten vacíos importantes que deben ser  atendidos. Estos no son meros detalles, sino aspectos fundamentales para garantizar  el éxito del tratado.     En primer lugar, creemos firmemente que los objetivos y principios fundamentales del  acuerdo deben constituir un marco sólido y vinculante. No podemos permitir que  estos pilares sean relegados a simples declaraciones de intención; deben ser la brújula  que guíe nuestras acciones hacia un cambio significativo y duradero.     Del mismo modo, resulta crucial reforzar el principio de responsabilidad extendida del  productor. No es ético ni sostenible que las cargas derivadas de la contaminación  recaigan desproporcionadamente sobre los gobiernos y, en especial, sobre las  comunidade s más afectadas, mientras los principales generadores de residuos  plásticos eluden su responsabilidad. Quienes obtienen beneficios de la producción de  plástico tienen el deber de asumir un papel proactivo en la solución de este problema.     Finalmente, insistimos en la necesidad de que el tratado contemple explícitamente a  las comunidades y poblaciones más vulnerables. Estas son las primeras en sufrir los  efectos devastadores de la contaminación plástica y, por tanto, deben ocupar un  lugar ce ntral en nuestras estrategias. Sus perspectivas y necesidades no pueden ser  ignoradas; deben integrarse plenamente en la implementación del acuerdo,        garantizando que nuestras acciones promuevan la equidad y no perpetúen  desigualdades existentes.     Señoras y señores, este tratado tiene el potencial de convertirse en un referente  histórico de cooperación internacional y acción colectiva. Sin embargo, su éxito  dependerá de nuestra voluntad de abordar con valentía y visión las deficiencias  actuales. Mi país está comprometido a contribuir constructivamente a este proceso,  trabajando con determinación para fortalecer el acuerdo y garantizar que nuestras  comunidades encuentren en él esperanza, justicia y una oportunidad para prosperar.     Les invito a todos ustedes a no perder de vista el objetivo más elevado de este  esfuerzo: construir un futuro sostenible y equitativo para todas las naciones. No  dejemos este legado en palabras; transformémoslo en acciones concretas y efectivas.     Muchas gracias.

Title: India
file_content: Intervention on Rules of Procedure   INDIA       Thank you Chair .      As this is the first time Indian delegation is formally taking the floor , we  would like to thank the Government of South Korea for their warm  hospitality and organization of INC 5 in Busan. We would thank INC Chair  for hard work put in to have  successful  outcome of INC 5 . We would also  thank INC Secretariat for preparation of relevant documents and  organization of INC 5.     As you are aware, India has always been committed to the principle of  consensus in decision making in respect of substantive matters under  multilateral environmental agreements as this reiterates collective  decision -making and reflects shared responsibilities and commitment .    Our delegation would like to reiterate that all the decisions on substantive  issues shall be taken by consensus and that Rule 38 (1) shall not be  invoked till the final adoption of Rules of procedure by INC.     We may recall the  interpretive statement relating to Rule 38.1 which was  adopted at the second session of INC in Paris .
