In this regard, our delegation, would like to seek assurance from INC Chair  that the Rule 38  para 1  shall not be invoked during the INC 5 meeting, in  the spirit of moving ahead with the deliberations on substantive issues.    We would like to reiterate that consensus -based  decision making is an  indispensable tool to ensure fairness , equity, inclusiveness, shared  responsibility and collective commitments and actions, in all multilateral  processe s. Consensus -based decisions foster a shared  sense of  ownership for outcomes, leading to sustainable and effective  solutions   ensuring an end to plastic pollution.     I thank you.   ***

Title: India
file_content: Intervention on Organization of Work   INDIA     • The deliberations at INC 5 are very important  and are expected to  achieve agreement on the proposed International Legally Binding  Instrument.   • This requires organization of work to be done which is inclusive and  efficient.   • For constructive engagement amongst all member states , we need  to have transparent and inclusive deliberations where no one is left  behind.   • In terms of process, the non -paper prepared by INC chair is a  valuable document .  • India  is willing to engage  regarding the contents of non paper , while  noting that compilation text had been agreed as a starting point in  INC 4.   • While the non-paper is envisaged as bridge to reach a consensus  based agreement at INC 5 , the compilation text continues to remain  an important document as it encompasses the views of all members,  even if it is extensive.   • In order to increase the acceptance of non -paper, the articles in the  Compilation Text at INC 4 should be reflected in the non -paper.   • All articles of the compilation text should  be given equal treatment  in the non paper otherwise this would put give those important  articles  an unequal treatment to begin with itself.   • Articles on Principles and Scope which are part of Compilation Text  but they are not included in the non -paper.  • There should be separate articles  on Principle s as well as  Scope in  the Non paper  and these articles need to be given equal treatment  as given to other articles in the non -paper .   • India may consider to work with non paper provided the articles on  objectives and scope are agreed to as part of the non paper even  orally by INC Chair and get recorded accordingly in the proceedings  of the opening plenary.   • This should  be followed by adjustments in the organization of work  of the contact groups in order to give adequate time for discussions  on these issues.    • Further, there should be “No text” option related to primary plastic  polymers. Presently, this is covered under section on “Supply” in the  Non Paper.

Title: Indonesia
file_content: REPUBLIC OF INDONESIA  NATIONAL STATEMENT The 5th Session Of The Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee To Develop an International Legally Binding Instrument on Plastic Pollution,  including in the Marine Environment  Busan, 25 November 2024   Thank you Mr. Chair, Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen,  It is indeed an honour for me to be at this important event, specially as today’s topic cannot be more timely.  I would like to seize this opportunity to convey our heartfelt gratitude to the Republic of Korea for their generous hospitality and excellent facilities they have provided in hosting this important meeting.   We would also like to extend our sincere appreciation to the dedication of the INC Chair, INC Secretariat and all Members and parties in advancing the negotiation process of the international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environments.   Indonesia would like to reaffirm its steadfast commitment to maintain constructive and productive discussions. Our objective remains to build a robust, enabling and balanced framework that encompasses clear obligations and means of implementation to stand up to the global challenges of plastic pollution, and enabling effective actions that will be strengthened over time.   Recognizing the important role plastics play in society is a must, while harmonizing environmental goals with economic and social realities in a sustainable manner is a priority.  In this regard, we need to utilize our time efficiently here in Busan to reach convergence on key elements that would drive meaningful progress toward conclusion of the negotiation of a future legally binding instrument that will lead all us to end global plastic pollution and its related risks to human health and adverse effects on human well-being and the environment.    It is thus essential to ensure that the text resulted in an instrument that guides Parties for necessary and feasible actions while maintaining room for improvement in delivery and adaptability which will help the global community to achieve the objective of this undertaking.  We believe that with good will, political commitment, and utmost flexibility, we can arrive to a good result here in Busan.  Gamsahabnida.

Title: Indonesia
file_content: REPUBLIC OF INDONESIA  OPENING PLENARY The 5th Session of The Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to Develop an International Legally Binding Instrument on Plastic Pollution,  including in the Marine Environment  Busan, 25 November 2024   Thank you Mr. Chair, Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen,  It is indeed an honour for me to be at this important event, specially as today’s topic cannot be more timely.  I would like to seize this opportunity to convey our heartfelt gratitude to the Republic of Korea for their generous hospitality and excellent facilities they have provided in hosting this important meeting.   We would also like to extend our sincere appreciation to the dedication of the INC Chair, INC Secretariat and all parties in advancing the negotiation process of the international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environments.   Mr. Chair,  We understand the legal standing of the Compilation Text, as well as your intention in preparing your Non Paper.  We need to start the negotiation, and we need a starting point. We are of the view that your Non Paper can serve that purpose, with the understanding that nothing prevents us as Member States to submit our proposals in any parts of the document, with the view that every ambition should be in parallel by adequate means of implementations.  We need to maximize the remaining hours of negotiation time available here. We are confident that with goodwill, determination, and compromise, we can arrive to a safe landing in Busan.  Gamsahabnida.       Word count: 215

Title: Iran (Islamic Republic of)
file_content: Iran Statement    to Opening Session of INC-5 in Busan   25 November 2024     Esteemed INC Chair,   Executive Secretary   Distinguished colleagues ,   At the outset, and o n behalf of the Iranian delegation , I would like to express our  gratitude and sincere appreciation to the Government of Korea as well as the City  of Busan for their gracious ly hosting this p aramount  meeting . We also wish to  extend our special thanks to the INC Secretariat for the  excellent preparation of  this event.   We also wish to associate ourselves  with the statement s of Kuwait on behalf of  the Like- Minded Countries  and Japan on behalf of the Asian group .  Mr. chairman   having a pragmatic , transparent  and inclusive approach  is a must  and the views,  concerns and suggestions of all countries should be heard and taken into  account in an equal manner . We should not forget that this is country driven  process and  any biased or imbalanced approach in our work will result only in a  one sided and failed process. We could not ignore the countries views and  concerns and then blame and accuse them to blocking the negotiations.   in order to achieve a constructive atmosphere and  consensus , focusing on areas   of convergence is critical . We strongly  believe that, moving towards distinctions  and framing our dialogues  in terms of consumer versus producer would risk  polarizing the conversation and detracting from our shared objectives , and  therefore , we should focus  on identifying common ground and joint solutions that  benefit all parties equitably in address ing plastic pollution.   On the Scenario n ote, third iteration of the non -paper  and the organization  of work , we also wish to appreciate your goodwill the proposal s. Efficiency ,  inclusiveness and transparency in our processes are essential to ensur e a  meaningful progress. It is unfortunate that t he current proposal does not include  issues such as principles, objectives, and scope , which makes it difficult to  achieve a meaningful international legally binding instrument . This requires the  need for significant adjustments that allow for a fair and b alanced negotiation .   Accordingly, we could not support the non -paper proposals  on supply, health,  and C hemicals of Concern  which are irrelevant and beyond our mandate.  On  Legal Drafting Group,  We do not support initiating work, first we do need to  reach agreement on some relevant areas of discussions and then initiate its  work.   Having said th at, we believe that the Chair’s non-paper as a contribution to our  discussions needs to be “amended” even in an orally manner  and the Terms of  Reference for the C ontact Groups  should clearly state that there is flexibility to  bring in text from the compilation document. This should seek clear, written  mandate for co -chairs of the CGs, and should be displayed on the screen during  the plenary (prior to moving into the CGs), a nd member states should approve it .  In conclusion, the Ottawa Compilation text would continue to be as the resource  document for textual negotiations, especially for articles where the non -paper  doesn’t offer any language.   Friends   On developing some working details after the diplomatic to the first COP meeting,   we also need to limit such discussions to a very limited number of procedural  issues and to avoid any  substantial negotiations . Certainly, making important  decisions by a small group of countries  and in the absence of other countries  would be totally against transparency and inclusiveness .   We should not distort, mishandle  or affect the agenda and the work of the COP of  the Instrument  through a non -transparent and non-inclusive a rrangement . We are  not allowed to deprive countries of the ir right and the opportunity to actively  participate in the negotiations which needs to be looked at by the first meeting of  the COP in its proper time.   Thank you, Chair.

Title: Japan
file_content: Japan Statement , 25 November  2024  under agenda item 4   The Fifth session of Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop  an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including  in the marine environment       Mr. Chair,      Japan expresses its sincere gratitude to the government of  the  Republic of K orea for kindly hosting the Fifth session of INC here in Busan .    We support the statements made by Kingdom of Thailand  on behalf  of the Asia Pacific Group, and Republic of Fiji  on behalf of HAC .    Japan a ppreciate s continuous leadership and hard work by the Chair ,  including through holding intensive informal Head s of Delegations  meetings in a transparent and inclusive manner. We also thank  the  Secretariat for their diligent  prepar ation  for the sessions and meetings so  far.    Japan also thanks the Chair for providing his Non-Paper 3, which  was drafted based on the compilation text and the discussions at the  informal Head s of Delegation s meetings . We strongly support starting our  negotiations based  on this Chair’s  non-paper , so that we can conclude  our  work during INC5 .           We would like to underscore the following key points regarding the  international legally binding instrument .     Firstly, we emphasize the importance of addressing the full life  cycle of plastic s in the instrument so as  to advanc e the circularity of plastics  and preventing its leaka ge into the environment.     Second, the instrument should have a clear time -bound collective  target so that all countries are encouraged to implement coordinated actions  to attain the shared target and further scale up their efforts to end plastic  pollution. For this reason, we reiterate that a clear milestone to reduce  additional plastic pollution to zero by 2040 should be referred  to, along  with reference that further efforts thereafter are also required .   Third, regarding core obligations , effective control measures  are  needed to further prevent plastic pollution . These should include  making  ambitious efforts for  reducing single -use plastics, promoting  environme ntally -friendly product design to generate changes in demand  and people’s behaviour, enhancing reuse, recycling and sound waste  management , taking into account necessary sectoral approac h to ensure  practical and effective implementation . We believe that requirements for   such various efforts , provided u nder the instrument , will significantly  contribute to the reduction in volume of plastic s use and promote a  sustainable production and consumption of plastics.     Fourth , the instrument need s to have a built -in-system for a “plan  do check action ” cycle for National  Action Plan s, Reporting and  Monitoring and Effectiveness Evaluation. These cycles  will enable  promoting actions through out the  value chain covering the full life  cycle  of  plastics , in line with the scientific and technological  development, and  ensure progressive nature of the instrument .     On m eans of implementation , we strongly believe that resource s  should be mobilized from all sources and financial support should be  provided to countries  most in need . It is essential to recognize that a  financial mechanism should encompass  a broad landscape of existing  financial and technical assistance.      Spirit of international cooperation is indispensable .    Lastly, w e aim for an effective and progressive instrument with the  participation of as many countries as possible, including large consumers  and emitters of plastics.     As we work towards completing our work by the end of 2024, we  have spent countless hours together. Our primary goal is to end plastic  pollution , and Japan stands ready to take a lead ing role in addressing this  critical issue. For the sake of a better future  for all , we are determined to  bring these negotiations to a successful conclusion.     Thank you.

Title: Kazakhstan
file_content: Speech	by	the	Vice	Minister	of	Ecology	and	Natural	Resources	of	Kazakhstan,		Mr.	Zhomart	Aliyev	INC-5,	Busan,	Korea,	November	25,	2024			Ladies	and	gentlemen,		On	 behalf	 of	 Kazakhstan,	 I	 would	 like	 to	 express	 my	 gratitude	 to	 the	INC	Secretariat	for	their	significant	contribution	to	organizing	and	conducting	negotiations	on	the	development	of	an	international	legally	binding	instrument	on	plastic	pollution,	including	in	the	marine	environment.	I	 also	 thank	 the	 Government	 of	South	Korea	 for	 their	 hospitality	 and	 warm	welcome	in	the	wonderful	city	of	Busan.	We	highly	value	the	host	country's	efforts	in	organizing	this	important	intergovernmental	dialogue.	Kazakhstan	recognizes	 the	 need	 to	 regulate	 the	 environmentally	 sound	management	 of	 plastics,	 considering	 the	 current	 volume	 of	 plastic	 waste	 generated	worldwide	 and	 its	 potential	 entry	 into	 the	 environment,	 including	 the	 marine	environment.	Kazakhstan	 supports	 the	 development	 of	 an	 internationally	 legally	 binding	document	 to	 combat	 plastic	 pollution,	 based	 on	 the	 principles	 of	 the	 Rio	 Declaration,	national	capacities,	and	priorities.	We	would	like	to	highlight	the	following	key	positions	of	Kazakhstan:	1. Kazakhstan	believes	that	reducing	the	production	of	primary	polymers	will	unequivocally	lead	to	economic	and	social	tensions	in	several	developing	countries.	Such	restrictions	could	negatively	impact	the	sustainability	of	key	sectors,	including	healthcare	and	 construction.	 It	 is	 essential	 to	 focus	 on	 waste	 management,	 promoting	 a	 circular	economy,	and	working	on	sustainable	product	design	for	plastic	materials	to	ensure	their	safety.	2. It	is	important	to	emphasize	that	complying	with	numerous	international	obligations,	 such	as	 the	 Basel,	 Rotterdam,	 and	 Stockholm	 Conventions,	 as	 well	 as	 the	future	legally	binding	instrument,	may	pose	challenges	for	management	and	coordination	at	 both	 the	 international	 and	 national	 levels.	 The	 country	 advocates	 for	 synergy	 with	existing	agreements	to	avoid	duplication,	minimize	costs,	and	simplify	the	integration	of	new	requirements	into	national	systems.	3. Kazakhstan	acknowledges	the	need	to	ensure	the	safety	of	plastic	products	to	 protect	 the	 environment	 and	 human	 health.	 At	 the	 same	 time,	 we	 believe	 that	 any	restrictions	on	the	use	of	chemicals,	including	bans,	should	avoid	duplication	with	other	existing	international	agreements	on	chemicals,	be	scientifically	and	technically	justified,	and	be	adopted	based	on	consensus.	4. Kazakhstan	expresses	concern	about	the	establishment	of	a	special	fund	with	 mandatory	 contributions	 for	 developing	 countries,	 as	 this	 may	 complicate	 their	financial	 situation.	 The	 country	 emphasizes	 the	 importance	 of	 developed	 nations	continuing	to	play	a	leading	role	in	providing	necessary	funding	and	technical	assistance.	Kazakhstan	 proposes	 adapting	 financial	 mechanisms	 to	 the	 capabilities	 and	 needs	 of	developing	countries	to	ensure	resource	availability	for	implementing	sustainable	plastic	management	practices.	5. We	stress	that	the	document	development	process	should	be	based	on	the	principle	 of	 consensus	 in	 decision-making.	 This	 will	 provide	 equal	 conditions	 for	 all	countries	and	avoid	decisions	that	could	harm	individual	economies.	6. Based	 on	 the	 experience	 of	 negotiations	 in	 Canada	 during	 INC-4,	Kazakhstan	 suggests	 limiting	 parallel	 consultations	 to	 two	 groups	 to	 ensure	 higher-quality	participation	and	effective	coordination	of	all	parties.	Kazakhstan	welcomes	the	program	proposed	by	the	Secretariat	before	the	start	of	these	negotiations.	Furthermore,	we	are	ready	to	support	measures	to	restrict	the	production	and	sale	of	single-use	plastics,	develop	waste	recycling	infrastructure,	stimulate	innovation,	and	adopt	international	standards	for	labeling	plastic	products.	However,	we	emphasize	the	importance	 of	 considering	 national	 conditions,	 including	 the	 economic	 and	 technical	capabilities	of	developing	countries.	Kazakhstan	 is	 committed	 to	 constructive	 dialogue	 and	 cooperation	 to	 create	balanced	solutions	that	will	contribute	to	environmental	protection	and	global	economic	development.		Thank	you	for	your	attention!																																		Выступление		Вице-министра	экологии	и	природных	ресурсов	Казахстана		Ж.	Алиева		МПК-5,	Пусан,	Корея,	25	ноября	2024	года			Уважаемые	дамы	и	господа,		От	 имени	 Казахстана	 хочу	 выразить	 признательность	Межправительственному	 секретариату	 за	 их	 значимый	 вклад	 в	организацию	и	проведение	переговоров	по	созданию	международно-правового	инструмента	для	борьбы	с	загрязнением	пластиком.	Также	 благодарю	 правительство	 Кореи	 за	гостеприимство	 и	теплый	 прием	 в	 замечательном	 городе	 Пусане.	Мы	 высоко	 ценим	усилия	 принимающей	 стороны	 по	 организации	 этого	 важного	межправительственного	диалога.	Казахстан	 признает	 необходимость	 регулирования	 вопроса	 по	экологически	 обоснованному	 управлению	 пластиком	 с	 учетом	текущих	объемов	образования	отходов	пластика	в	мире	и	допущению	их	попадания	в	окружающую	среду,	в	том	числе	в	морскую	среду.	Казахстан	поддерживает	разработку	международного	юридически	 обязывающего	 документа	 по	 борьбе	 с	 пластиковым	загрязнением,	 основанный	 на	 принципах	Рио-де-Жанейрской	декларации,	национальных	возможностей	и	приоритетов.	Мы	 хотели	 бы	 отметить	 следующие	 ключевые	 позиции	Казахстана:	1. Казахстан	 считает,	 что	 сокращение	 производства	первичных	 полимеров	вызовут	 однозначные	 экономические	 и	социальные	 напряжения	 в	 ряде	 развивающихся	 стран.	 Ограничения	могут	негативно	повлиять	на	устойчивость	важных	отраслей,	включая	здравоохранение	 и	 строительство.	 Необходимо	 акцентировать	внимание	 на	 управлении	 отходами	 и	 внедрении	 циркулярной	экономики,	работой	над	устойчивым	проектированием	продукции	из	пластика	для	обеспечения	безопасности	таковой	продукции.	2. Важно	 подчеркнуть,	 что	 соблюдение	 многочисленных	международных	обязательств,	таких	как	Базельская,	Роттердамская	и	Стокгольмская	 конвенции,	 а	 также	 будущего	 юридически	обязывающего	инструмента,	может	создать	сложности	в	управлении	и	координации,	как	на	международном,	так	и	на	национальном	уровне.	Страна	 выступает	 за	 синергию	 с	 существующими	 соглашениями,	чтобы	 избежать	 дублирования,	 минимизировать	 издержки	 и	упростить	интеграцию	новых	требований	в	национальную	систему.	3. Казахстан	 признает,	 что	 необходимо	 обеспечить	безопасность	продукции	из	пластмасс	для	защиты	окружающей	среды	и	здоровья	человека.	Вместе	с	тем,	считаем,	что	любые	ограничения	использования	 химических	 веществ,	 в	 том	 числе	 запрет,	 должны	исключить	дублирование	с	другими	действующими	международными	соглашениями	по	химическим	веществам,	быть	обоснованы	с	научной	и	 технической	 точки	 зрения,	 и	 должны	 приниматься	 с	 учетом	консенсуса.	4. Казахстан	 выражает	 обеспокоенность	 созданием	специального	 фонда	 с	 обязательными	 взносами	 для	 развивающихся	стран,	так	как	это	может	усложнить	их	финансовую	ситуацию.	Страна	считает	важным,	чтобы	развитые	страны	продолжали	играть	ведущую	роль,	 предоставляя	 необходимое	 финансирование	 и	 техническую	помощь.	Казахстан	предлагает	адаптировать	финансовые	механизмы	к	 возможностям	 и	 потребностям	 развивающихся	 стран,	 чтобы	обеспечить	доступность	ресурсов	для	внедрения	устойчивых	методов	управления	пластиком.	5. Мы	 подчеркиваем,	 что	 процесс	 разработки	 документа	должен	 базироваться	 на	 принципе	 консенсуса	в	 процессе	 принятия	решений.	 Это	 обеспечит	 равные	 условия	 для	 всех	 стран	 и	 исключит	принятие	 решений,	 которые	 могут	 нанести	 ущерб	 отдельным	экономикам.	6. Учитывая	опыт	переговоров	в	Канаде	на	МПК-4,	Казахстан	предлагает	ограничить	параллельные	консультации	двумя	группами,	чтобы	 обеспечить	 более	 качественное	 участие	 и	 эффективную	координацию	всех	 сторон.	То	 есть	 Казахстаном	 приветствуется	программа	предложенная	Секретариатом	до	начала	этих	переговоров.	Кроме	 того,	 мы	 готовы	 поддерживать	 меры	 по	ограничению	производства	 и	 реализации	 одноразового	 пластика,	развитию	инфраструктуры	 переработки	 отходов,	 стимулировать	 инновации	 и	внедрять	 международные	 стандарты	 маркировки	 пластиковых	изделий.	 Однако	 подчеркиваем	 важность	 учета	 национальных	условий,	 включая	 экономические	 и	 технические	 возможности	развивающихся	стран.	Казахстан	 готов	 к	 конструктивному	 диалогу	 и	 сотрудничеству	для	 создания	 сбалансированных	 решений,	 которые	 будут	способствовать	 защите	 окружающей	 среды	 и	 развитию	 мировой	экономики.	Благодарю	за	внимание!

Title: Kazakhstan
file_content: Kazakhstan’s	 Position	 on	 the	 Preliminary	 Draft	 of	 an	 International	Legally	Binding	Instrument	on	Plastic	Pollution	Kazakhstan	 recognizes	 the	 importance	 of	 addressing	 plastic	 pollution	through	environmentally	sound	management,	acknowledging	its	significant	impacts	 on	 ecosystems,	 including	 the	 marine	 environment.	 The	 country	supports	 global	 efforts	 to	 develop	 a	 comprehensive,	 science-based	international	legally	binding	instrument	that	addresses	the	entire	lifecycle	of	 plastic	 products	considering	 the	 principles	 of	 the	 Rio	 Declaration	and	underlining	 the	 need	 to	common	 but	 differentiated	 responsibility	for	countries	depending	on	their	different	socio-economic	factors,	conditions,	national	circumstances	and	capabilities,	as	well	as	taking	into	consideration	states’	contribution	 to	 plastic	 pollution,	 including	 on	 the	 marine	environment,	while	 introducing	 sound	finance	 and	 technology-transfer	mechanisms.	Importantly,	Kazakhstan,	 as	 a	 landlocked	 country,	 does	 not	 contribute	directly	 to	 marine	plastic	pollution.	 Therefore,	 its	 contribution	 to	 global	plastic	pollution	is	limited.			Kazakhstan’s	economy	in	 transition	relies	 on	 the	 development	 of	 various	sectors,	which	 involves	 the	 use	of	primary	 polymers,	 particularly	 in	healthcare,	construction,	petrochemistry,	 mining	 and	 others.	Thus,	Kazakhstan	 does	 not	 support	 restricting	 or	 regulating	 primary	 polymer	production	 within	 the	 framework	 of	 the	 proposed	 treaty.	For	 instance,	plastics	 play	 a	 vital	 role	 in	 ensuring	sterility	 and	 safety	 in	 medical	applications	and	providing	durability	in	infrastructure	projects.	Restricting	their	production	could	hinder	the	development	of	key	sectors	of	economy	and	 impose	 significant	 socio-economic	 costs.	 As	 Kazakhstan	develops	petrochemical	 industry	 to	 reduce	 reliance	 on	 raw	 material	 exports,	 it	stresses	the	need	for	a	balanced	approach	that	does	not	hinder	its	economic	development.	Regarding	chemical	regulations	in	plastics,	Kazakhstan	supports	ensuring	environmental	and	human	safety	but	believes	that	restrictions	should	avoid	duplication	 with	 existing	 international	legally	 binding	 instruments,	 be	scientifically	 justified,	 and	 require	 consensus	 among	 all	 parties.	 On	 micro	and	 nanoparticles,	 the	 country	 highlights	 the	 limited	 research	 and	technology	for	studying	their	impact	and	managing	them	safely,	advocating	for	 a	 focus	 on	 advancing	 scientific	 research	 rather	 than	 immediate	regulation.	Kazakhstan	underlines	the	 need	 to	 manage	 plastic	 waste	 effectively,	prioritizing	 single-use	 plastics,	 improving	 waste	 management	infrastructure,	and	designing	products	to	support	a	circular	economy.	We	support	the	development	of	safe	plastic	alternatives,	recycling	innovations,	and	a	phased	reduction	in	single-use	plastics,	contingent	on	the	availability	of	 financial	 mechanisms,	 technology	 transfer,	 and	 technical	 support	 to	facilitate	adaptation.	In	 promoting	 global	 standards,	 Kazakhstan	 endorses	the	 introduction	 of	improved	certification	and	labeling	standards	aimed	at	enhancing	product	safety	 and	 reduce	 environmental	 risks.	 However,	 it	 acknowledges	 the	challenges	faced	by	developing	countries,	including	high	adaptation	costs,	increased	 consumer	 prices,	 and	 institutional	 burdens.	Furthermore,	trade	regulations	related	to	plastics	should	adhere	to	WTO	and	EAEU	principles,	ensuring	 transparency,	 non-discrimination,	 and	 alignment	 with	 existing	trade	agreements.	Kazakhstan	 opposes	 the	 establishment	 of	 a	 mandatory	 special	 fund	 for	developing	 countries,	 as	 such	 contributions	 would	 impose	 an	 undue	financial	 burden.	 Instead,	 the	 country	 advocates	 for	 developed	 nations	 to	take	the	lead	in	providing	financial	and	technical	assistance.	It	emphasizes	the	 need	 for	 coordination	 with	 existing	 mechanisms,	 such	 as	 the	 Global	Environment	 Facility	 (GEF)	 and	 Green	 Climate	 Fund	 (GCF),	 to	 optimize	resources	and	avoid	duplication.	Kazakhstan	also	proposes	the	creation	of	competence	centers	in	developing	countries	to	build	technological	capacity	and	 develop	 localized	 waste	 management	 solutions.	The	 country	 calls	 for	advisory	rather	than	mandatory	supranational	guidelines	for	implementing	extended	producer	responsibility	(EPR),	tailored	to	national	contexts.	Kazakhstan	underlines	the	need	to	adapt	flexible	solutions,	acceptable	for	all,	ensuring	 that	 developing	 nations	 can	 adapt	 to	 new	 global	 plastics	regulations	without	compromising	economic	stability	or	development	goals.	Consensus-based	 decision-making	 is	 fundamental	 to	 achieving	 equitable	agreements	 and	 avoiding	 adverse	 impacts	 on	 individual	 participants.	Kazakhstan	 remains	 committed	 to	 contributing	 to	 the	 development	 of	 a	balanced	and	effective	international	treaty	that	reflects	national	priorities	and	 capabilities	 while	 fostering	 global	 cooperation	 to	 combat	 plastic	pollution.

Title: Kenya
file_content: 1 | P a g e      REPUBLIC OF KENYA   STATEMENT BY KENYA DURING THE OPENING  PLENARY OF INC -5 ON  2 5TH  NOVEMBER , 2024, BUSAN , SOUTH KOREA   1. I thank you Chair for giving me the floor.  Distinguished Chair, esteemed colleagues,  ladies and gentlemen, Good morning     2. At the outset, I would like to relay my profound gratitude on behalf of the Kenya  delegation to the people and government of the Republic of South Korea for being  such gracious hosts, Busan is indeed a beautiful city to host the fifth and final session  of the INC.     3. Secondly, I would like to commend  the Secretar iat that has been of utmost assistance  and efficiency in organizing for all previous INCs culminating in INC -5 in which we  are gathered here in today.     4. Kenya aligns with the African statement as deliv ered by the distinguished delegate  of Ghana. The R epublic of Kenya has demonstrated its unwavering support for the  delivery of a legally binding instrument that reflects the aspiration of high ambition  commensurate with the detrimental challenge of plastic  pollution that the planet is  currently facing.     5. Over and above opening INC -3, H.E. President William Ruto, the President of the  Republic of Kenya, hosted a side event during the 79th Session of the United Nations  General Assembly (UNGA) in New York to ga lvanize momentum for the global  plastics instrument that we are expected to deliver in 6 days’ time and I implore  you distinguished delegates , let us not fail.   Ladies and Gentlemen   6. The distress ing data has been shared regarding the reality and scale of glo bal plastic  pollution, the effects on human health and the environment cannot be understated  and Kenya underpins that the need to protect human health and the environment  is the basis for which this upcoming treaty gains its justification.      7. The projection that by the year 2060 the generation of plastic waste will double  per person presents a worrying trend for policy makers especially for countries such  2 | P a g e    as Africa with growing populations and this imperative is prime motivator for Kenya  in thi s process. Kenya envisions the delivery of a treaty that shall not only provide  a roadmap for the ending of plastic pollution within a realistic timeline but one that  is implementable by Member States.     8. Kenya therefore joins Ghana, Rwanda and all others in support of the Non paper  as a basis for negotiations with input of text as proposed by the African Group.  Further Kenya implores the Member States to deeply reflect and fulfill this mandate  of ending plastic pollution for present and future generations.     9. The treaty aims to tackle cross -cutting challenges of plastic pollution; from  chemicals, waste and Kenya is also keen on biodiversity and nature. The current  non-paper  provision lacks commensurate provisions for biodiversity. Kenya  therefore will be propo sing text on the same.     10. Finally, Kenya reiterates its full support for the AMCEN Position that the Secretariat  of this treaty should be domiciled at UNEP HQs, in line with strengthening and  consolidating UNEP functions as mandated in paragraph 88 of the Rio Outcome  Document , the Future We Want .     11. Kenya requests for guidance from the Chair as to how to fill in the gaps in the Chair’s  Non-paper .    12. Distinguished delegates, let us make the 6 days ahead of us count.     I thank you Chair.

Title: Madagascar
file_content: DECLARATION DE MADAGASCAR   A L’INC -5 A BUSAN - REPUBLIQUE DE COREE   25 novembre au 01 décembre 2024     Nos remerciements s ’adressent à la Ré publique de Corée pour son hospitalité  et nous remercions le Secrétariat  pour l’organisation de la cinquième se ssion  de l’INC.  Nous soutenons la déclaration de Ghana au nom d e la Région Afrique pour  l’utilisation du  document officieux du président de l ’INC comme un document de base.  Nous sommes co nvaincus que cet instrument sera un outil important pour mettre fin à  la pollution plastique, notamment  dans le milieu marin, contribuant ainsi à la  préservation de notre planète et de notre biodiversité pour la génération future.    Madagascar avec sa biodiversité unique et ses écosystèmes  marins fragiles est  vulnérable  à la pollution plastique.  Nos côtes , qui abritent une richesse marine  inestimable , subissent des conséquences  de cette pollution , mett ant en péril non  seulem ent la faune et la flore mais également  les moyens de subsist ance de nos  communautés côtières .   A cet effet, nous tenons à souligner l a nécessité d ’une approche équit able qui  prend en compte les vu lnérabilités de la population les plus touchées par la pollution  plastique.   En t ant qu’état insulaire , Mada gascar est prêt à s ’enga ger da ns cette  négociation  et à apporter notre contribution  et appelle à un accord international  ambitieux et juste.

Title: Malawi
file_content: MALAWI ’S STATEMENT  ON THE 5TH INTERGOVERNMENTAL NEGOTIATING  COMMITTEE (INC  5) TO END PLASTIC POLLUTION   Chairperson ,  Secretariat,   Excellences and Distinguished D elegates,   Malawi would like to extend her sincere appreciation to the G overnment of   Republic of  Korea  for their k ind hospitality and thank UNEP S ecretariat for  organising the 5th Session of the  Intergovernmental Negotiation Committee (INC - 5) here in Busan, Korea .  This gathering is very timely and crucial for us all as a global community that  strives to join efforts to address the challenges of plastic pollution. As we are at a  pivotal moment in the negotiations here, let us all reflect on the impacts of  plastic pollution and human health , and brainstorm on lasting solutions to the  problems we are facing. This can be achieved if we prioritise measures that will  have the greatest impact in addressing the harmful effects of plastic pollution.   Malawi believes that these measures include, first and foremost, eliminating and  reducing  the most problematic, harmful and high -risk categories of plastic. In this  regard, we emphasise the necessity of common, global, legally binding rules,  acknowledging that purely voluntary measures have been and remain  inadequate for addressing the plastic pollution crisis.   Malawi remains committed to promoting a non -toxic circular economy , which  follows the waste hierarchy. We would like to highlight that legally binding rules,  alongside economic tools, serve the purpose of driving the private sector to  scale and speed up reliable environmentally sound investmen ts.  Furthermore, harmonised product design requirements,  disclosure on chemicals  used in plastic production,  bans on single -use plastics – in favour of scaling up  reuse – and mandatory extended producer responsibility (EPR) schemes are  crucial to achieving a circular economy. Such measures can create equal  opportunity across all markets and drive innovation on circular solutions.  It is incumbent upon us to establish an environmentally sound waste  management system,  considering the sobering reality that 62% of the world’s  waste is disposed of through open dumping. Minimum requirements on waste  management can reduce the level of plastic leakage into the environment,  bringing us closer to the goal of addressing this planetary crisis.   Moreover, in addition to ensuring strong control measures, we must ensure that  our treaty is effective. Means of implementation , with an emphasis on  a  dedicated stand -alone  fund,  capacity building, robust technology transfer and  financial support, especially for developing countries is therefore another critical  area for deliberation.   To sum it all, Malawi advocates for a highly ambitious treaty that will drive parties  to solve the plastic planetary crisis effectively, a treaty that will give mandatory  obligations while embracing the principle of commo n but differentiated  responsibil ities and the polluter pays principle . Malawi reaffirms its commitment  to the UNEA 5/14 resolution to protect human health and the environment by  addressing the full life cycle of plastics.  As we deliberate, we urge all members  to recall this mutual resolve and mobilise greater support around these key  areas that will help us to deliver on our mandate.
