Title: Pakistan
file_content: Country Statement of Pakistan      First of all, Pakistan would like to thank the  Government of the Republic of Korea  for hosting  the fifth session of Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee at the beautiful city of  Busan . We would also like to appreciate the  UNEP and INC Secretariat for organizing the  meeting  in a befitting manner .  Pakistan would like to associate itself with the  statement made by the Asia Pacific Group.  We would also like to appreciate the INC Chair  for developing the Non-Paper 3 to facilitate  negotiations on plastic treaty .  Pakistan would like to suggest that ‘scope’ and  ‘principles ’ should also be part of the text  since  use of plastic s is unavoidable in many  sector s  including  medical, textile, packaging,   electronics, aviation, home appliances, consumer  products, industrial machinery, agriculture etc.  However,  plastic pollution including in the  marine environment has become a global menace   owing  to mismanagement by Governments, producers and other stakeholders.  It has broader   health and environmental implications due to  increased consumption and lack of capacity to  manage plastic waste.    Mr. Chair ,  Pakistan would like to recommend ban on the use  of the most harmful chemicals as additives in   plastic products  and to encourage non -toxic  circular economy through recycling of plastics.   We understand  that time is limited for concluding  the INC negotiations for a legally binding  instrument , therefore, we would urge all Member States that in the spirit of cooperation and  compromise, let us finalize the text of plastic  treaty  during  the INC -5 in a meaningful manner.     Finally , I would like to assure  that Pakistan is  fully committed to supporting the global efforts  to end plastic pollution  exponentially.    Thank you, Mr. Chair

Title: Philippines
file_content: INC-4 PH statement [SHORT VERSION] MR. PRESIDENT, YOUR EXCELLENCIES, AND DISTINGUISHED DELEGATES  In the interest of time, highlight the following observations, as a longer version of this statement will be uploaded: 1) We support global aggregate reduction in primary plastic polymer that can effectively  curtail the projected tripling of plastic wastes by 2060; 2) We urge the adoption of a globally harmonized approach to develop criteria that will  identify problematic and avoidable plastic products; 3) We urge the adoption of measures to avoid health risks through the elimination of  chemicals of concern in plastics through the establishment of clear criteria; 4) We urge flexibility by applying the concept of “essential use”, and consider the  availability of safe and sustainable alternatives or substitutes alongside phaseouts or  bans and timetables; 5) We urge respect for human rights, and socio-economic opportunities lie in ensuring a  just transition for the informal sector; 6) We urge the provision of means and tools of implementation is important for developing  countries, particularly environmentally and ecologically vulnerable developing countries  like the Philippines, affected as it is by its archipelagic setting, high marine biodiversity,  and climate change vulnerability; 7) We stress that the financing mechanism can take a two-step approach, designed for  both early action support and synergies, and long-term availability of adequate, timely  support from a dedicated fund. 8) We stress these specific obligations should be set against the Rio Declaration Principles,  particularly common but differentiated responsibilities, precaution, prevention of  transboundary harm, and non-restriction of trade, and meaningful public participation. 9) We recognize the actions of the private sector and civil society that should be further  strengthened by the democratization of the best available scientific knowledge, including  socio-economic assessments, through the establishment of a Science-Policy body. We thank the Chair for the non-paper, and suggestions to distill areas of significant convergence from the compilation text. We can welcome the non-paper in guiding and structuring the discussion. We need to ensure that this instrument is equitable, inclusive, and science-based. The Philippines is ready to work constructively with all member states to ensure that this session will be our last, as we had aimed for at UNEA 5.

Title: Republic of Korea
file_content: INC-5 national statement - Republic of Korea    We would like to extend deep appreciation to the Chair and the Secretariat for their hard work for advancing the negotiation process. Our warm welcome goes to all participants to the fifth INC meeting here in Busan.  Over the two years of the negotiating process, we have developed and shared constructive ideas to tackle plastic pollution. We believe that those ideas are well reflected in the Chair's non-paper. This non-paper also allows us to focus on essential elements for the instrument and to identify more detailed implementing arrangements to be considered by the COP later. This approach enables us to make the best use of the limited negotiating time. Korea believes that the Chair's non-paper can serve as a solid basis for effectively furthering our negotiations and supports using it as the starting point.  Addressing global plastic pollution is a shared task that we can no longer afford to delay. The instrument should evolve over time through decisions made by the COP. What we need is a foundational instrument that we can build upon and that reflects the latest advancements and developments in scientific evidence. Korea reiterates the importance of concluding the negotiation at INC-5. We hope all delegates demonstrate flexibility and solidarity so that we can achieve a historic outcome here in Busan.  Thank you.  /END/

Title: Rwanda
file_content: In-Session Non-Paper to the INC Rwanda and Peru Oﬀer to Host Joint Diplomatic Conference of Plenipotentiaries in Kigali, Rwanda United Nations Environment Assembly (UNEA) Resolution 5/14 requests the Executive Director to convene a Diplomatic Conference of Plenipotentiaries upon completion of negotiations by the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee, for the purpose of adopting the instrument and opening it for signature. At the ﬁrst session, Rwanda and Peru presented their respective candidatures to host the Diplomatic Conference and, subsequently, at the third session, their joint candidature to co-host the Diplomatic Conference. This joint candidature reﬂects the spirit of collaboration and cross-regional cooperation that not only contributed to the adoption of UNEA Resolution 5/14, but that will be needed to ensure the eﬀective implementation of the new instrument. Based on informal consultations with Committee Members, we are conﬁdent our joint candidature has broad support. At INC-5, we reaﬃrm our oﬀer to co-host the Diplomatic Conference, and request the valuable support of esteemed Committee Members for the INC to recommend to the Executive Director to convene the Diplomatic Conference in Kigali, Rwanda. Rwanda would be honoured to join Senegal, Peru and Ecuador, which have either hosted sessions or chaired the INC, to contribute to the instrument development process.

Title: Sri Lanka
file_content: Sri Lanka Country Statement for the 5th Session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic Pollution Mr. Chair, Excellencies, and Distinguished Delegates, Sri Lanka extends its appreciation to the Republic of Korea and the INC Secretariat for their continued dedication towards developing a legally binding instrument on plastic pollution. As an island nation that has experienced firsthand the devastating impacts of plastic pollution, including the unprecedented X-Press Pearl disaster in 2021 that released approximately 1,600 MT of plastic pellets into our waters, Sri Lanka remains firmly committed to developing a robust international legally binding instrument that addresses plastic pollution.  We emphasize the critical importance of establishing mandatory Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) schemes as a key element of the international instrument. Our experience has shown that voluntary measures alone are insufficient. Mandatory EPR schemes, with clear accountability mechanisms and financial obligations for producers and all other stakeholders in the value chain are essential to drive systemic change in plastic production, design, Consumption and waste management. These schemes must extend beyond national borders to address the global nature of plastic pollution and ensure that producers take full responsibility for their products throughout the entire lifecycle, including in export markets. The continuous inflow of plastic waste through maritime routes and ocean currents poses an urgent challenge to our nation, highlighting the critical need for stronger controls on transboundary movements of plastic waste. We strongly advocate for the inclusion of specific provisions within the instrument to regulate and monitor international plastic waste trade and address marine plastic pollution from shipping activities as also highlighted in other maritime-related conventions such as the Basel Convention, London Dumping Convention, and MARPOL. Furthermore, Sri Lanka reiterates the urgent need for establishing a dedicated mechanism to address accidental plastic spills and their devastating environmental and economic impacts. Such a mechanism should include rapid response protocols, technical assistance, and financial support for affected nations. Our experience with the X-Press Pearl disaster highlights the critical importance of having international support systems in place for such emergencies. Sri Lanka strongly emphasizes the need to address significant data gaps across the plastics lifecycle, which currently hinder effective policy implementation and monitoring. As a developing nation, we recognize that the lack of systematic plastics data and national accounting frameworks poses significant challenges in establishing realistic targets, monitoring implementation progress, ensuring transparent reporting, and contributing meaningfully to global assessments. On reporting requirements, we advocate for a framework that is both robust and flexible - one that acknowledges varying national capacities while maintaining data consistency. Such a phased approach, aligned with the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities, will allow countries to gradually improve their national databases while ensuring meaningful participation in the global monitoring system. We continue to implement our National Action Plan on Plastic Waste Management 2021-2030 and have made progress in banning several single-use plastic items. However, we recognize that without proper data systems and implementation support, measuring the effectiveness of such interventions remains challenging. The success of our national efforts is intrinsically linked to global action, particularly in addressing transboundary plastic pollution and establishing effective EPR schemes. The establishment of a robust support mechanism that integrates technology transfer, human resource development, and capacity building is essential for developing countries like Sri Lanka to implement comprehensive plastic pollution measures. This mechanism must provide sustained assistance for establishing and maintaining monitoring and reporting systems, implementing Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) schemes, and developing infrastructure for proper waste management. The financial mechanism must also be designed to reflect the urgency of addressing the plastic pollution. Ensuring predictable Accessible, new and additional sources of finance will be crucial for developing countries to meet their obligations under this instrument effectively. In conclusion, Sri Lanka calls for an ambitious instrument that mandates EPR schemes, effectively addresses transboundary plastic pollution and plastics waste trade, ensures robust data and monitoring systems, and provides adequate means of implementation for all nations. We believe that if the production of plastics continues globally as it seems to be under the convention, it is imperative to strengthen plastic waste management practices at every level if we want to effectively address plastic pollution worldwide. Only through such comprehensive and well-supported measures can we collectively tackle the global plastic pollution crisis. Thank you, Mr. Chair.

Title: Viet Nam
file_content: Statement  of Viet Nam   The 5th Session Of The Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee  to  Develop an International Legally Binding Instrument on Plastic  Pollution, including in the Marine Environment   Busan, 25th November 2024     Thank you Mr. Chair,   Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen,     Since this is the first time Viet Nam speaks, my Delegation would like to  express our thanks to the Republic of Korea and the City of Busan for their  hospitality.   My delegation appreciates Mr. Chair for proposing the Non -paper which is  an important reference document for negotiation s. We, however, believe that  the compilation text is what delegations have introduced and discussed many  rounds of negotiations and should be always the basis for negotiations. This  is also what we have done with many other negotiations at the United  Nation s. The streamlined text, if any, must reflect the views of all countries.   We would also like to move forward with discussions in Contact Groups,  and also request the Contact Group cover such important issues as  principles, objectives and scopes of the Agreement.     I thank you.

Title: Zambia
file_content: 1 Mr Chair,   The Zambian  delegation  wishes  to express  its profound   gratitude  to the Korean  Government  and its people  for the  warm  hospitality  accorded  to us since  our arrival.  Special   thanks  to the Intergovernmental  Negotiating  Committee  (INC)   Secretariat  for the excellent  organisation  of the sessions  we  have had this far.     Mr Chair,   On the non-paper  of the Chair , Zambia  believe s, like the rest  of Africa  through  the statement  given  by Ghana  on behalf  of  the African  group  that it provides  a workable  basis  for  productive  negotiations  at INC-5 necessary  to ensure   constructive  progress  is made  in this final negotiation   meeting .      We are committed  to ensuring  that the future  treaty  remains   ambiti ous. In addition , we are resolved as part of the African   group  to filling  in the gaps left open by the Chair .    We believe  the envisio ned future  treaty  is our beacon  of hope.   We look forward  to a treaty  that will enable  mankind  to deal  with this pressing  global  environmental  challenge  urgently  as  there is no time to waste .   Chair it is our hope that we can soon conclude  this plenary  and move  into the most  crucial  part of this session  which  are  the contact  groups .     Mr Chair,  I thank  you for your kind attention .   2

Title: Egypt
file_content: Mr.  Ambassador Luis Vayas Valdivieso, INC Chair   Ms. Joyti Filipe   Your excellences   Distinguished colleagues.     Egypt would like to express its appreciation to  the Government of the Republic of South  Korea for hosting the Fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee  (INC) , and thanks the INC Chair and secretariat, for the efforts exerted towards reaching  a balanced Legally Binding Instrument to e nd Plastic Pollution.         Having said that, Egypt   welcomes the third iteration as a starting point for negotiations,  with out prejudice the fact that  the compilation text is  a base reference  for negotiation ,  when needed,  while coordinating different proposals for reaching a compromise to tackle  plastic pollution in one coherent document . Egypt  believes that prioritizing the discussion  of the scope , principles,  and definitions, which are of a paramount impo rtance for  establishing a new ILBI , will pave the path for balanced negotiations.     Finally, Egypt seeks more clarification f rom the secretariat  about the way forward and  the planned milestones after  INC-5 until the Diplomatic Conference.     Thank you  very much Chair .

Title: Fiji
file_content: Fiji Country Statement for the 5th Session of the Intergovernmental  Negotiating   Distinguished Chair, esteemed delegates, fellow colleagues, ladies and gentlemen,   Ni sa bula vinaka  from Fiji. I bring warm Pacific greetings from our Government and our  People. Fiji stands before you today at a pivotal moment, as we gather for the fifth and final  meeting of the INC on a legally binding instrument to combat plastics pollution —a challeng e  that transcends borders and generations. This is our last opportunity to meet the ambitions  being called for by our peoples, our communities, and indeed, for our planet. We have the  rare chance to lay down a treaty that is not only fit for purpose but on e that will serve as a  robust foundation for our collective future to end plastic pollution. Fiji’s call and drive for an  ambitious treaty has been consistent with the High Ambition Coalition, and we are pleased to  join them as its newest member before INC -5.  We acknowledge and appreciate the Chair’s third iteration of the non -paper as a possible  starting point for our negotiations. However, while it has great potential, we are not distracted  from our goal —significant improvements are necessary to ensure th e treaty meets our  collective aspirations. We must embed the fundamental principles of human rights, health of  people and the environment, alongside the recognition of Indigenous peoples and local  communities, directly into the text. This is not just a mor al call; it is essential for the treaty's  legitimacy and efficacy.   Fiji has long advocated for the reduction of the production and consumption of primary  plastics. This commitment must align with our shared goal of maintaining the 1.5 °C climate  target set  in the Paris Agreement. We call for the elimination of problematic plastics and  hazardous chemicals that pose risks to human health and our environment and demand a  system of harmonized, mandatory, and transparent reporting across the entire life cycle of   plastics. In solidarity with the Pacific SIDS, we urge the inclusion of provisions that  specifically address the unique challenges faced by our region —recognizing our special  circumstances.   As we consider solutions for plastic pollution, we must adopt a comprehensive life cycle  approach. Addressing plastic waste in isolation from its production and inherent  characteristics will yield inconsequential outcomes. Therefore, let us prioritize and sequence  our efforts, knowing that our next steps from this INC session to the Diplomatic Conference  of Plenipotentiaries must be deliberate and impactful.   Mr Chair, our message remains clear: we left Ottawa with a resolute call to break free from  brackets, and we now extend that resolve to fully engage with the Chair’ s non -paper as our  roadmap forward. Yet, we must acknowledge the reality that —in its current framing —this  document represents a starting point of low ambition. As mentioned by AOSIS we recognize  the time left for negotiations —yet critical parts of the non -paper are not developed — including some sections without proposed text by the Chair.   To meet the challenges we face, Fiji is prepared to work cooperatively to strengthen and  elaborate upon it, ensuring we forge an ambitious, comprehensive, and binding agre ement capable of protecting our environment for all people, and we hope that our colleagues will do  the same   History shows us that amending treaty text is a long and arduous process. We cannot afford  to start with weak provisions; therefore, our emphasis s hould be on an ‘ambitious start and  strengthen’ approach. Transparency, monitoring, reporting, implementation, and compliance  must be built into this treaty from the outset, ensuring that we can hold ourselves  accountable as we move forward.   The financial mechanisms integral to this treaty must be equitable, accessible, and fair.   Success hinges on at least two critical factors: our ability to establish a clear vision for  reducing plastic production over time —and ensuring that adequate, sustainable resource   mobilisation strategy, financing , and means of implementation, commensurate with the  ambition and goals of the treaty are in place to support all nations in implementing our  agreed measures. A comprehensive finance package that leverages all available sou rces,  aligning public and private financial flows with the treaty’s core obligations that mobilize and  direct financial resources for treaty implementation is necessary. Without these foundation  stones, our efforts risk falling short of transformative chan ge.  Over recent months, we have consistently raised our concerns regarding the absence of key  provisions that address the specific needs of Pacific SIDS. These are 'must -haves' for our  communities, and we will not waver in advocating for their inclusion. I f this process  concludes at INC -5, it must do so with a treaty that serves the interests of all regions and all  peoples. A failure to do so would constitute an injustice to both our communities and the  global ecosystem we are striving to protect.   We believ e that a weak start will not yield a strengthened treaty text. Where consensus is  lacking, we must incorporate language to adopt decisions by a majority  vote that facilitates a  target -setting process, allowing us to set and exceed our ambitions over time.   Finally, we must remain responsive to the evolving science surrounding plastics pollution,  incorporating not only the most recent findings but also recognizing and learning on  traditional knowledge systems that provide invaluable context and solutions to o ur efforts.   So, with this message, Mr Chair, I would like to end by saying, " Let us use this meeting to  craft a treaty that reflects our highest aspirations. Let us commit to an agreement that  is ambitious, inclusive, and fit for purpose - because our secu rity and wellbeing  hinges on a future where our oceans, lands, and communities thrive in harmony ."  I Thank you.

Title: India
file_content: ARTICLE 8 PLASTIC WASTE MANAGEMENT  My suggested text is: [1. Each Party, as per their national plans and based upon national circumstances and capabilities and relevant national regulations, shall take measures, including, where relevant, through a sectoral approach, to ensure that plastic waste including abandoned, lost or otherwise discarded ﬁshing gear containing plastic, is managed in a safe and environmentally sound manner, taking into account the waste hierarchy and relevant guidelines developed under the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, and in accordance with any guidelines that may be adopted by the Conference of the Parties to this Convention. In developing such guidelines, the Conference of the Parties shall may take into account arrangements in relevant international agreements, if applicable. There shall be provision of ﬁnancial and technical assistance including technology transfer  to developing countries in line with the principle of common but diQerentiated responsibilities assessed through a subsidiary body under this instrument.   2. Each Party, as per their national plan and based upon national circumstances and capabilities, is encouraged to take additional measures which could include, inter alia: (a) Promoting investment in, and mobilising resources from all sources for, waste management systems and infrastructure that enables environmentally sound management of plastic waste and enhances waste management capacity; (b) Establishing systems at national and local levels for handling, sorting, collection, transportation, storage, recycling and treatment of plastic wastes; (c) Encouraging behavioural changes throughout the value chain and raising public awareness about plastic waste prevention and minimization, taking into account he critical roles of all stakeholders in reducing plastic litter and supporting recycling; (d) Incentivizing increased recyclability, promoting higher recycling rates, and enhancing the accountability of producers and importers for environmentally sound management of plastics and plastic products throughout their life cycle, including by the adoption and implementation of approaches such as extended producer responsibility (EPR) schemes; (e) Promoting, developing and strengthening markets for secondary plastics.  3. Each Party shall take measures to ensure that export of plastic waste is only allowed: (a) For the purpose of safe and environmentally sound recovery, reuse, recycling, or disposal in a manner consistent with this Article; and (b) With the written consent of the importing Party or non-Party.  4. Where export of plastic waste is allowed under paragraph 3, the exporting Party shall: (a) Provide to the importing Party or non-Party complete information about the composition of the waste proposed to be exported, including its contents in polymers, chemicals and plastics, and any associated hazards to human health or the environment, including safety data sheets, as relevant; (b) Require exporters to comply with generally accepted and recognized international rules, standards and practices for packaging, labelling and transport.  5. The Conference of the Parties shall, at its ﬁrst meeting, adopt guidance to assist Parties in their implementation of paragraphs 3 and 4 of this Article, including a format for certiﬁcation to demonstrate that the importing Party or non-Party has measures in place to ensure consistency with the requirements under subparagraph (b) of paragraph 3. In developing such guidance, the Conference of the Parties shall take into account arrangements in relevant international agreements.]

Title: Ethiopia
file_content: Statement  made by F ederal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia During the Opening Plenary of  Inc-5 On 25th November , 2024, Busan, South Korea .  As this is the first time we are taking the floor; on behalf of my country the Federal  Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, I would like to express my sincere gratitude to the  Republic of Korea and the people of Busan for their warm welcome and gracious  hospitality in hosting INC -5.     Ethiopia aligns with the submission made by the African Group as presented by Ghana . It  is important for us to have a consolidated start point that we can shape and develop with  our thoughts.     This document shall be improved in the negotiations in the contact groups, we shall strive  to move forward by valuing the time and efforts of all participants, bridging any gaps, and  achieving a consensus.     With a population of more than 120 million, there is no widespread awareness of the  harmful health and environmental impacts of plastic pollution. My country has already  launched initiatives to address plastic pollution and is committed to making significant  contributions to this cause.      As a result, the scale of the issue is substantial. Therefore, our government is determined  to ensure that this negotiation be the final step in ending the damage as quickly as  possible.     Thank you, Chair and the secretariate, for your invaluable contribution in ensuring the  timely finalization of this treaty through amicable and thoughtful decisions.                     I thank you

Title: Thailand
file_content: pg. 1  Thailand’s statement   at the fifth session of Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee   to develop an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution,   including in the marine environment (INC -5)  25 November 2024 ,   Busan Exhibition and Convention Center (BEXCO) , Busan, Republic of Korea            Mr. Chair and all distinguished colleagues,   At the outset, Thailand would like to express our sincere appreciation to the government  and people of the Republic of Korea for their warm hospitality  in welcoming all  of us  to Busan .  Our profound gratitude is also extended to Mr. Chair and your team for your leadership and  dedications, as well as to the Executive Secretary  of the Secretariat of INC on plastic pollution ,  and her team , and all bureau members for their tireless efforts and intensive works in preparing  this crucial fifth session of INC.   Thailand aligns itself with the statement delivered on behalf of the Asia-Pacific Group.   Since Thailand has actively participated in the negotiation of the UNEA resolution 5/14  from the beginning, Thailand therefore fully supports the ma ndate of the resolution to end  plastic pollution: towards an international legally binding instrument, address ing plastic  pollution , including in the marine environment,  throughout the full life cycle of plastics, align  with the concepts of waste management hierarchy and circular economy. Thailand welcomes  the non -paper  3 proposed by INC Chair, and consider s the compilation text  and the report s  from  the intersessional work as reference document s to complete the objectives of INC-5.   Thailand also welcomes the scenario note for INC -5, in particular the proposal on the  establishment of the  four contact groups , including their proposed subgroups, and  the legal  drafting group . However, we share  the same concern with other delegations  that, with limited   number of delegates, no more than two meetings of any groups should be convened at the same  time.    Regarding the non -paper  3 proposed by INC Chair,  Thailand  appreciates t he inclusion   of full life cycle approach, as well as  the importance of manag ing the production and  consumption  of plastics  at sustainable levels . Thailand wishes to  emphasiz e that circular design    pg. 2  for plastic products , the integration o f circularity in  either sectoral or product -specific  approaches and the obligation for parties to collaborate on addressing  existing and  legacy   plastic  pollution  should be  part of core provisions . Thailand  also supports  the engagement of   local communities, civil society, the private sector s, as well as  workers in informal and  cooperative settings  in promoting and facilitating  a just transition . The provision on just  transition should be accompanied by a timeline for its implementation. We also appreciate the  inclusion of health -related issues in non -paper 3 of the INC Chair, which addresses the health  impacts of plastic polluti on. Therefore, we invite Member States to consider this issue in the  final draft of the instrument.   Nevertheless, based on the obvious divergent views among Member States on some  Articles reflected in the non -paper  3, Thailand  proposes that the following concerns should be  included in the instrument to complete the objectives  of INC-5:  1. To manage the production and consumption  of plastics at sustainable levels , the  reduction of over-supply of unnecessary plastic products should  be taken as the priority. The  possibility to enter exemptions would  be necessary if the global capping of plastic production  is included in the instrument.   2. To avoid  chemicals of concern  in plastic products , we agree that necessary measures  should be considered to control and limit the use of hazardous chemicals in plastic polymers  and plastic products  production. We also  support  the establishment of international standards  to identify chemicals of concern. Such standard  should be considered and implemented in a  coherent manner and does not duplicate  other  relevant M ultilateral Environment Agreement s.  3. To reduce plastic waste effectively , the provision to ensure  reuse and refill systems  is indispensable .  4. The management of abandoned, lost, or discarded fishing gear (ALDFG) is a critical  global issue. ALDFG presents substantial threats to marine ecosystems, particularly  pronounced in coral reefs and marine endangered species. To mitigate these risks, effective  measures such as gear marking, tracking, and reporting systems should be implemented in  accordance with international standards and best practices.   5. A strong provision of labeling standard  to identify  materials and chemical s of  concern s used in plastic products should be included to provide  the necessary data and  information with respect  to the principles of transparency and traceability .  6. The financial mechanism , capacity -building  and technical assistance  to developing  countries  should come along with the timeline to support the  implementation  of the instrument .    pg. 3  7. Thailand emphasizes the importance of addressing the release of microplastics across   the life cycle of plastic product s, through enhanced  product design, production, transportation,  usage practices, and end of life management  of plastic products .  In addition, Thailand would like to support  the identification  of potential  work  that  could be undertaken in the  interim  period between  the Diplomatic Conference and th e first  session of the C onference of the Parties  to facilitate the implementation of the instrument.  Thailand’s preferable option is the in-person  meeting format  if funding support be provided for  delegates from developing countries. However, online workshop s or webinar series can be  considered as possible alternatives as well . The timing of workshops or webinar series  should  be flexible and taken into consideration the different time zones of Member Countries to   facilitate  participat ion.  Last but not least,  Thailand remains committed to actively addressing the plastic  pollution problem by collaborating with all stakeholders. Recognizing the importance of  environmentally sound management of plastic pollution at the national, regional, and global  levels, Thaila nd underscores the significance of an inclusive and transparent negotiation  process. We remain hopeful that these efforts will lead to a successful conclusion within the  established timeframe.   Thank you.

Title: Türkiye
file_content: National Statement of Türkiye   25 November 2024 under agenda item 4 The Fifth  session of Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee  to develop an international legally binding instrument  on plastic pollution, including in the marine  environment     Distinguished  Chair,   Since this is the first time we take the floor, I would like  to express our profound gratitude to the UN Environment  Programme and INC Secretariat for their exceptional  efforts in organizing the Fifth Session of the International  Negotiation Commit tee on Plastic Pollution, and to the  Government of Korean Republic for their warm  hospitality.   Allow me also to express our sincere appreciation to you  and your team for your tireless efforts in guiding us  through this process and for the comprehensive  documents you have provided. We greatly appreciate the  support they offer as we collectively work toward a  legally binding instrument on plastic pollution.   We recognize the significant complexity of this  undertaking. The negotiations leading up to INC -5 have  shown just how challenging it is to find common ground, as we strive to address the many dimensions of plastic  pollution.   We welcome the Chair ’s efforts to simplify the structure  and content of the draft text. We believe that the non - paper version 3 provid es a good  basis for discussion and  moving forward.   Looking ahead, we see the importance of identifying the  key elements of the agreement that can be addressed now,  while recognizing that some issues may require further  deliberation during post -DipCon and COP meetings. We  also believe that the compiled text can also be a good  guide for our further studies in line with missing articles  in Non Paper Version 3.   Given that we have limited time we should first focus on  the items that has convergence on key topi cs.  Under your leadership, we have no doubt that we can  conclude the process in a transparent, fair, inclusive and  equitable way.   Before concluding, I would like to reiterate Türkiye ’s  unwavering support for this process and our shared  commitment to achiev ing the goals outlined in UNEA  resolution 5/14.    Thank  you.

Title: Somalia
file_content: Statement of the Federal Republic of Somalia At the Fifth Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to Develop an International Legally Binding Instrument on Plastic Pollution  December 2024, Busan, South Korea  Mr. Chair, Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen, On behalf of the Federal Republic of Somalia, we extend our profound gratitude to UNEP, the INC Secretariat, and the Government of South Korea for hosting this critical meeting. We align with the positions of both the African Group and the Arab Group, reaffirming our shared commitment to the development of a bold, equitable, and legally binding instrument to combat plastic pollution. Somalia commends the ambition demonstrated in Non-Paper 3, particularly its comprehensive approach to addressing the full lifecycle of plastics. We welcome its emphasis on robust financial mechanisms, capacity building, and inclusive governance as essential pillars for achieving our shared goals. As the nation with the longest coastline in continental Africa, Somalia faces disproportionate challenges due to plastic pollution. This issue poses significant risks to our marine ecosystems and the livelihoods of coastal communities. In response, Somalia has taken decisive action, including implementing a nationwide ban on single-use plastics under the leadership of the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change. However, tackling plastic pollution requires a unified global effort. We strongly believe this treaty must reflect equity and ambition, particularly by addressing the unique challenges faced by vulnerable nations like Somalia. To this end, we urge the committee to: 1. Establish robust financial mechanisms to ensure grant-based support for least developed and vulnerable nations. 2. Enhance international cooperation to address transboundary and legacy plastic pollution that exacerbates the challenges for nations like Somalia. 3. Provide scaled financial and technical assistance to support national efforts, such as Somalia’s ban on single-use plastics and other innovative solutions. 4. Prioritize inclusive governance, capacity building, and technology transfer to empower all nations with sustainable, long-term solutions to plastic pollution. This treaty presents a historic opportunity to protect our planet, safeguard marine ecosystems, and support vulnerable communities. Somalia stands ready to collaborate constructively with all parties to deliver an ambitious and implementable framework that ensures a sustainable, plastic-free future for generations to come. Thank you.

Title: Zambia
file_content: 1 Mr Chair,   I thank  you sincerely  for granting  the Zambian delegation  this  opportunity  to have the floor.   We wish to thank  you and your co-chairs  for the hard work  you have done this far and we re-affirm our commitment  as  a country  to this process .    Mr Chair,   Regarding  the slow progress  we have made  this far, we  appreciate  the time allocated  by the co-chairs  to deleg ates for  us to share  ideas  and present  proposals  towards  formulating   the treaty  text.   Mr Chair,  these initial  consul tations  have given us an  opportuni ty to reflect,  see areas  of convergence , divergenc e  and alignment s prior to textual  negotiations.  However  as  stated  by my delegation  in the opening  plenary  and  considering  the limited  time we are left with, Zambia suppor ts  the move  for the co- chairs  to proposing  streamlined  text in  the respective  contact  groups . We need to get to the actual   negotiations  sooner than later.  we remain  committed  to engage  with others  constructively .   We further  remain  committed  to ensuring  that the future   treaty  remains  ambiti ous, implement able and effective   with a robust  financing  mechanism  to see the UNEA  decision   achieve  its objectives.        Mr Chair,  I thank  you.

Title: Australia
file_content: Intergovernmental Negotiating Session – fifth session   AUSTRALIA  – OPENING STATEMENT   Australia thanks the Republic  of Korea for their gracious hospitality in hosting the fifth  Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee  (INC-5) meeting.  We also thank the INC Chair,  Ambassador Luis Vayas Valdivieso, and the Secretariat for their hard work preparing for this INC.   Australia remains committed to negotiating an ambitious legally binding instrument by the end  of 2024. At UNEA 5.2 in 2022, all Members collectively agreed to a compressed timeframe to  finalise the instrument’s text because we recognise that plastic pollut ion is a crisis needing a  global solution now. We do not have any time to waste.   We encourage delegates to reflect on the constructive and optimistic spirit that brought us to  this point and draw on that same spirit to guide our progress this week , with the goal of finalising  ambitious instrument text .  We thank the Chair for providing Non -Paper 3 and we look forward to negotiating in good faith ,  using this non-paper to guide our discussions .   Australia  considers the following elements are essential to ensure the instrument is robust,  effective and provides the necessary foundation to end plastic pollution :  • Global obligations  to phase out problematic plastic products and problematic  chemicals in plastic products.     • Global obligations for harmonised design standards for plastic products, supported by  life-cycle analyses, and labelling and transparency requirements.     • Global obligations to restrain and reduce primary plastic production to sustainable  levels, to be achieved through sector -based approaches.     • Global obligations for countries to remediate existing plastic pollution, both individually  and in cooperation with others.     • A financial mechanism that mobilises finances from all sources to support the  instrument’s successful implementation.   We seek an agreement that meets the needs of our region, particularly Pacific Island countries  who are disproportionately impacted by the adverse impacts of plastic pollution .   We look forward to working with all INC Members at INC-5 to achieve the goal of finalising an  ambitious legally binding instrument to end plastic pollution .

Title: Guinea
file_content: Fifth Session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on     Plastic Pollution 25 November - 01December 2024     Busan, Korea   Item 4   GUINEA, STATEMENT    On behalf of Mrs Djami DIALLO, Minister of Environment and  Sustainable Developme nt, t he Guinea n delegation appreciates  the warm welcome of the Republic of Korea. We are working with  other  countries, businesses, stakeholde rs and civil  societies towards  development  of the internationa l legally binding instrument on  plastic pollution. The fifth and final negotiations  are being  concluded in Busan .  Excellencies   As the world grapples with the escalating crisis of plastic pollution,  the INC has been at the forefront of crafting a historic legally  binding international instrument to address this global challenge.   The high and the rapidly increasing levels of plastic pollution  represent a serious environmental problem at a global scale,  negatively impacting the environment, human health, social  and  economic dimensions of sustainable development.   Furthermore , microplastics, tiny particles less than 5 mm in size are  a growing threat to planetary health. These plastics have infiltrated  the oceans , soil, and even the air , making them nearly impossible  to avoid.   Distingu ished delegates ,  Studies show that humans now absorb microplastics not only   through the sea food but also, through tap water, bottled water ,  and everyday products such as beer and salts. Removing these  plastics is difficult and costly, and almost impossible with regards to  microplastics in deep ocean.   The OECD Global Plastic Outlook projects leakage of plastics to  increase up to 2060 in a scenario where new policy measures  are  not taken.   For these reasons , the final INC meeting in Busan, South Korea  today is viewed as a critical opportunity to combat plastic  pollution.   The instrument will be based on a comprehensive approach that  addresses the full life cycle of plastic, including its production,  design and the disposal.   It is obvious that poor waste management is the primary driver of  plastic pollution , indicating that negotiations should  prioritize   effective waste management strategies. Recycling plastics alone  cannot solve the issue because the pollution has reached a  critical stage.  There is need to establish specific cuts in primary plastic polymer  production. This approach arises from the necessity to regulate  production and consumption at sustainable level.   Distingu ished delegates ,  Ending plastic pollution worldwide will require robust support from  developed to developing countries, including technical  assistance, and  technology transfer , as well as  mult ilateral fund s,.  This dedicated fund must be sustainable and vibrant to enable the  developing countries to implement the treaty ’s obligations and  show commitment to the instrument.   Without substantial progress on these key issues , the effectiveness  of the plastic treaty will be in doubt.   While the efforts of businesses and markets are important,  fundamental societal changes in lifestyle are essential for  meaningful progress.   We need to deliver on our collective promise for an effective and  just global treaty to end plastic pollution, that protects human  health , ecosystem s and serves our societies while facilitating   sustainability to our economies.   If this instrument is obtained, it will be a milestone as the world’s first  legally binding agreement to prevent plastic pollution.   Distingu ished delegates ,  The Guinean  authorities at t he highest levels ha ve supported  the  fight against plastic pollution . This is w hy, the Minister of Environment has started the following activities since October  2024  :  1-development of the national inventory of sources of plastic  pollutio n ; and  2-develop ment of a strategy and a national plan    Finally , the Guinean delegation wishes to commend the INC for  their unwavering effort and commitment to ensuring that  the  legally binding instrument is realised   Thank you

Title: India
file_content: Page 1 of 4   National Statement - INDIA   Fifth Session of Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop international  legally binding instrument  on plastic pollution   25th November 2024        Thank you chair.    At the outset, we thank the Government of South Korea for their warm  hospitality and organization of INC 5 in Busan. We thank INC Chair for  hard work put in the development the non -paper. We also thank INC  Secretariat for preparation of relevant documents and organization of  INC 5.    We have covered significant journey since the adoption of UNEA 5/14   resolution. The four meetings of Intergovernmental Negotiating  Committee have provided a platform to member states to deliberate  different elements of the proposed International Legally Binding  Instrument.    The deliberations at INC 5 very important and are expected to achieve  agreement on the proposed International Legally Binding Instrument .    For constr uctive engagement amongst all member states we need to  have transparent and inclusive deliberation s where no one is left  behind.    In terms of process, t he non -paper prepared by INC chair is a valuable  document .   India  is willing to engage with its content s, while noting that compilation  text had been agreed as a starting point in INC 4.    While the non-paper is envisaged as bridge to reach a consensus  based agreement at INC 5 , the compilation text continues to remain Page 2 of 4   an important document as it encompasses the  views of all members,  even if it is extensive.    In order to increase the acceptance of non -paper, the options included  by member states in the Compilation Text at INC 4 needs to be  reflected in the non -paper. For example, the Principles and Scope  Articles which were part of Compilation Text but they were not included  in the non -paper.    There should be separate section on Principle and Scope in the Non  paper  and these articles needs to be given equal treatment as given  to other articles in the non -paper .    The Rio principles including Common but Differentiated Responsibility  as well as national circumstances and capabilities need to be followed .    The s cope of international legally binding instrument should as per  United Nations Environment Assembly r esolution 5/14 and should not  overlap with existing MEAs or multilateral bodies such as WTO.    We reiterate that all substantive decisions with respect to proposed  International Legally Binding Instrument on plastic pollution should be  taken by consensus. In case any  party wants to invoke rule 38.1,  finalization of draft Rule of Procedure will have to be done before such  voting.    India believes that we are negotiating a document of immense  importance, with significant environmental and economic implications  for all cou ntries. Therefore, it is vital that every country is included in  this process, leaving no one behind.  All the points and concerns  should be duly considered.  In doing so, we must consider each  country’s varying levels of responsibility for historical and current  plastic pollution, and the proposed International  Legally Binding  Instrument  must recognize the need for support to developing Page 3 of 4   countries through financ ial resources and technology transfer, in a  manner that is affordable, accessible, and adequate .   We do not support the section “Supply”, as we are not clear  about  the  scope of the article. It is not clear “production” covers products or  polymers or chemicals. Sustainable level of production at global level  or national level is not a well -defined or quantified concept and may  well become another method for imposing a cap on production of  products, chemicals or primary polymers.    The importance of plastics in fulfilment of SDGs by developing  countries cannot be overlooked.     As per UNEA resolution 5/14 the issue/ problem of plastic pollution  needs to be primarily addressed by the instrument. The production of  primary polymers is not directly related  to plastic pollution. There  should be no targets with respect to polymer or plastic production and  focus should be on reduction of plastic pollution.    Provision of m eans of implementation (technical and financial  assistance ) must be linked with compliance of substantive obligation s.   The International Legally Binding Instrument should establish a  dedicated multilateral fund which is fit for purpose follow s the model of  the Multilateral Fund for the Montreal Protocol . The dedicated  multilateral fund should specifically support incremental cost of  transition to meet specific compli ance obligations.    Dedicated multilateral fund should have the flexibility to receive funds  from additional sources.  The rules of the new dedicated fund need to  be made fit for purpose in order to respond to the compliance  obligations based upon the principles of transparency and inclusivity.    In addition, we do not support l evy of plastic pollution fee on production  of primary plastic polymers.  We also do not support utilization of funds Page 4 of 4   generated from national EPR schemes to fulfil international  comp liance obligations.    Most importantly, country  driven approach should be followed based  upon national circumstances and capabilities for any compliance  obligations  under the instrument .   As a committed member of this process, we look forward to successful  outcome at this fifth session of INC to end the global environmental  challenge of plastic pollution in a country driven manner.    Thank you.   *****

Title: Malawi
file_content: Article 24 (CG4) 28 November 2024 The African Group, as submitted by Malawi, has one edit to the Chairs non- paper text For Article 24 on Adoption And Amendment Of Annexes. In Paragraph 2 we would like to add “or amendments to annexes” after “Any additional annexes.” So it would read: “2. Any additional annexes or amendments to annexes adopted after the entry into force of this Convention shall be restricted to procedural, scientiﬁc, technical or administrative matters.” Thank you for your attention.

Title: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
file_content: UK submission on Article 10 Just Transition   1. In the implementation of this Convention, each Party shall promote and facilitate a just  transition, with particular consideration for waste pickers and other workers in informal  and cooperative settings, Indigenous Peoples, local communities embodying tra ditional  lifestyles, artisanal and small -scale fishers, women and children.       2. Each Party  should support policies aimed at creating decent work and quality jobs  throughout the entire value chain of plastics, supporting adequate income, opportunities  and livelihoods and the enhancement and development of skills, as well as facilitating  inclusiv e engagement with relevant stakeholders.      3. Parties are encouraged to cooperate with each other and with relevant intergovernmental  organizations and other entities, as appropriate.     4. Each Party shall report measures taken to implement this Article in its national report  pursuant to [Article 15].       5. The Conference of the Parties shall adopt guidance to assist Parties in the  implementation of this Article, taking into account relevant guidelines under other  international organizations, including the International Labour Organization.

Title: Venezuela, Bolivarian Republic of
file_content: INTERVENCIÓN   DELEGACIÓN  DE LA REPÚBLICA  BOLIVARIANA  DE VENEZUELA   QUINTO PERÍODO DE SESIONES DEL COMITÉ  INTERGUBERNAMENTAL DE NEGOCIACIÓN ENCARGADO DE  ELABORAR  UN INSTRUMENTO  INTERNACIONAL  JURÍDICAMENTE  VINCULANTE SOBRE LA CONTAMINACIÓN POR PLÁSTICOS,  INCLUSO EN EL MEDIO MARINO (INC -5)  BUSAN,  COREA DEL SUR,  DEL 25 DE NOVIEMBRE AL 1° DE  DICIEMBRE  DE 2024.     En Nombre del Gobierno y del Pueblo de Venezuela queremos agradecer  al Gobierno de C orea del Sur  por su hospitalidad, así como a la Secretaría  por la preparación de esta reunión. Para Ud. señor  Presidente  Luis Vayas   Valdivieso  nuestro  especial  reconocimiento  por su esfuerzo en llevar a  adelante los trabajos de este Comité.     En primer lugar, Venezuela se asocia  a la declaración pronunciada por  Uruguay en nombre del GRULAC, y la declaración pronunciada por Kuwait  en nombre de los países de pensamientos afines (LMDC)      El INC5 tiene ante sí  el reto de completar el texto de un Instrumento  Internacional Jurídicamente vinculante conciso y viable para todos, sobre  la base del principio básico de las responsabilidades comunes pero  diferenciadas,  el uso  soberano de los recursos naturales y el desarrollo  sostenible . Es imperativo que cualquier marco de políticas reconozca las  circunstancias nacionales y las capacidades y circunstancias dispares de  los países en desarrollo, en particular asegurando que no se les imponga una carga que no se pueda cumplir .    La Resolución 5/14 de la ANUMA establece claramente que el objetivo  que nos reúne es poner fin a la contaminación plástica y para ello el  instrumento promoverá la producción y el consumo sostenibles de  plásticos mediante, entre otras cosas, el diseño de pr oductos y la gestión  ambientalmente  racional  de residuos,  incluso  a través de  enfoques  de  eficiencia  de recursos,  con el fin último  de proteger  la salud humana  y el  ambiente de los efectos adversos de la contaminación por plásticos  incluido el medio marino.     Para nuestro país el objetivo final del instrumento debería ser mantener  los desechos plásticos fuera del medio ambiente, manteniendo al mismo  tiempo el papel crucial del plástico en el avance del desarrollo sostenible  y la erradicación de la pobreza.     Sr. Presidente     Entre los temas que consideramos vitales en el futuro acuerdo destacan l as  alternativas y sustitutos  como  uno de los grand es desafíos que debemos  enfrentar , principalmente los países en desarrollo, tomando en cuenta que  el plástico es un material barato, duradero y versátil que ha demostrado ser  vital para diferentes aplicaciones .    Asimismo, la gestión de residuos constituye una de las principales causas    de la contaminación debido a  la ge stión inadecuada, motivo  por el cual se  requiere contar con tecnología e infraestructura adecuada .    En cuanto a los m edios de implementación  es necesario que se definan de  forma clara y precisa, incluida la financiación, transferencia de tecnología y  desarrollo de capacidades, tomando en cuenta que la implementación  efectiva del futuro acuerdo dependerá en mayor medida de la creación de  capacid ad y de recursos técnicos y financieros adecuados, especialmente  para los países en desarrollo, teniendo en cuenta las responsabilidades  comunes pero diferenciadas y las capacidades nacionales.     Es fundamental establecer un Mecanismo financiero robusto, que permita  recursos adicionales, accesibles  y predecible s que facilite  la  Implementación del Acuerdo que se alcance, así como la necesidad de  asegurar la transferencia de tecnología y desarrollo de capacidades,  tomando en cuenta que la implementación efectiva del futuro acuerdo  dependerá  en mayor  medida  de capacidad  y de recursos  técnicos  y  financieros adecuados.     Hemos llegado hasta aquí empujados por una realidad que cada día es  más visible, los costos ambientales, sociales y económicos de la  contaminación por plásticos son enorme s, y se requiere de un mayor  compromiso de los sectores involucrados para lograr los cambios  necesarios en las políticas, actitudes y prácticas, sin dejar de reconocer la  importancia del plástico en la sociedad.     El camino es largo, pero el cambio es posible, con voluntad política,  colaboración ciudadana, aunando esfuerzos y desarrollando estrategias  comunes podemos enfrentar el reto de reducir la contaminación por plásticos lo que permitirá construir un futuro más sostenible para nuestro  planeta.      Gracias Sr. Presidente

Title: Eritrea
file_content: Eritrea National Opening Statement  to The 5th Session Of The Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee To Develop an International Legally Binding Instrument on  Plastic Pollution, including in the Marine Environment   Busan,  South Korea,  25 November  to 01 December, 2024     Thank you Mr. Chair,     Excellencies, Distinguished Delegates, Ladies and Gentlemen,     On behalf of the Government of Eritrea,  I would like to seize this opportunity to convey our  heartfelt gratitude to the Republic of Korea for their generous hospitality and excellent facilities  they have provided in hosting this important meeting.   We would also like to extend our sincere apprecia tion to the dedication of the INC Chair, INC  Secretariat and all Members and parties in advancing the negotiation process of the international  legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environments.  It is indeed  an honour for us  to be at this important event, especially  as today’s topic cannot be more   timely   Eritrea would like to rea ffirm its steadfast commitment , as it took the initiative to control plastic  pollution and banned single -use plastic twenty years ago. However, the experiences learned  from , affirm  that national efforts can only get effectively realized through consolidate d global  efforts . Controlling upstream production is principal for successfully reducing and eliminating  plastic pollution.  to maintain constructive and productive discussions.     As we gather here today, we are reminded of the urge ncy and importance of our mission. The  proliferation of plastic pollution poses significant threats to our ecosystems, human health, and  sustainable development. It is imperative that we work collaboratively to establish a  comprehensive framework that not only addresses the current crisis but also fosters innovation  and encourages sustainable practices across all sectors.     Our objective remains to build a robust, enabling and balanced framework that e ncompasses  clear obligations and means of implementation to stand up to the global challenges of plastic  pollution, and enabling effective actions that will be strengthened over time. Recognizing the  important role plastics play in society is a must, while  harmonizing environmental goals with  economic and social realities in a sustainable manner is a priority. In this regard, we need to  utilize our time efficiently here in Busan to reach convergence on key elements that would drive  meaningful progress towar d conclusion of the negotiation of a future legally binding instrument  that will lead all us to end global plastic pollution and its related risks to human health and  adverse effects on human well -being and the environment. It is thus essential to ensure t hat the  text resulted in an instrument that guides Parties for necessary and feasible actions while  maintaining room for improvement in delivery and adaptability which will help the global  community to achieve the objective of this undertaking. We believe that with good will, political  commitment, and utmost flexibility, we can arrive to a good result here in Busan.   I thank you!

Title: Lao People’s Democratic Republic
file_content: Fifth Session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee on Plastic  Pollution  including in the marine environment   25 November - 1 December 2024, Busan, Republic of Korea   Lao People’s Democratic Republic STATEMENT S     Mr. Chair, Excellencies, Distinguished Colleagues, Heads of Delegation and Members,      On behalf of the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), we extend our heartfelt greetings  and express profound gratitude to the Republic of Korea for its exceptional hospitalit y and  unwavering commitment as our gracious host. We convene here with the resolute intention of  finalizing the textual negotiations in Busan. We commend the Chair of the Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee (INC) for their exemplary leadership and expr ess our appreciation to the  Secretariat for their invaluable support in ensuring the success of INC -5.  As a landlocked and developing country, Lao PDR is acutely aware of the pressing challenges  posed by plastic pollution, which has significant detrimental  impacts on our environment, public  health, tourism industry, and economy.   In recognition of these challenges, the Government of Lao PDR has undertaken significant efforts  to address plastic pollution. This is reflected in our national policies and develop ment strategies,  notably the National Green Growth Strategy 2030, Lao National Plastic Action Plan, and our  recent joining  of the World Economic Forum’s Global Plastic Action Partnership (GPAP). It is  important to note that Lao PDR is a major importer of p lastic products, primarily from fast - moving consumer goods (FMCG) companies. This influx, coupled with limited waste  management infrastructure, has placed a significant burden on our country. As our economy  rapidly develops, plastic consumption continues t o rise, exacerbating the issue.   While we acknowledge the economic benefits associated with plastic, we are deeply concerned  about its short -term and long -term environmental consequences. We believe that a comprehensive  and binding Global Plastic Treaty is crucial to address the entire life cycle of plastic, from  production to disposal.   As a consumer country, Lao PDR alone cannot prevent the entry of unrecyclable single -use plastic  goods. Therefore, we seek collaboration with neighboring  and regional countries to regulate plastic  products. We urge producers to assume greater responsibility for the environmental impacts of  their products, particularly in terms of plastic pollution .   We advocate for a concise approach that prioritizes the life -cycle pers pective. The instrument  should comprehensively address plastic pollution across the entire lifecycle of plastics, from  inception to disposal, ensuring a balanced approach. This necessitates reducing the discharge of  mismanaged plastic waste through enhance d waste management infrastructure and innovative  solutions, including the integration of local knowledge and wisdom. Simultaneously, we  acknowledge the indispensable role of plastics in society. It is imperative that we strive for a fair  and seamless trans ition towards a circular and sustainable plastic economy.  We call for to balance environmental goals with socio -economic development. To achieve this,  additional requirements,  and technical guidelines for systems like reuse and extended producer  responsibi lity (EPR) will be necessary after the treaty's adoption.   As a developing country , we acknowledge the indispensable requirement for capacity -building,  technical assistance, technology transfer under mutually agreed terms, and financial assistance,  particul arly for developing countries and countries with economies in transition. In this regard, we  underscore the distinctive challenges encountered by developing states and least -developed  countries.   we believe that the collective endeavor of the international community, through the establishment  of common, binding core obligations and control measures across the entire lifecycle of plastics,  will facilitate a fair and equitable transition.   Conclusion   We wish to reaffirm that the Lao PDR is dedicated to contributing to this global effort in addressing  plastic pollution and aligning our national strategies with international goals. The Lao PDR is  committed to work collaboratively with regional and global p artners to achieve a comprehensive  approach that addresses the full life cycle of plastic,  including its production, design, and disposal.     Once again , Lao PDR  is unwavering in its commitment to collaborating  with all Parties to craft an  effective and equitable Global Plastic Treaty. Together, let us seize this opportunity to protect our  planet, promote sustainable development, and secure a healthier future for generations to come.   Thank you.

Title: Cuba
file_content: Intervención  de Cuba en plenaria final   1 de diciembre de 2024     Distinguido Presidente,     Agradecemos la labor y esfuerzo realizado por usted  y su equipo. Todos  hemos  trabajado  con dedicación  y debe mos seguir con el mismo espíritu   hasta lograr el resultado final de nuestro mandato  que emana de la  Resolución 5/14 de la UNEA . Mandato que en el párrafo 3 de esta resolución  reconoce que se tendr án en cuenta los principios de la Declaración de Río  y las circunstancias y capacidades nacionales.     Cuba comparte las distintas preocupaciones expresadas en las  intervenciones de los grupos de países presentadas por Uruguay, Kuwait  y  la que realizará Samoa. A pesar de estas preocupaciones se reconoce  también que el  documento que usted ha pre sentado en el día de hoy puede  ser punto de partida para cuando reanudemos el INC 5 , en el entendido de  que todo el documento completo está abierto a la negociac ión.     Esto es importante, Señor Presidente, y solicitamos que quede recogido en  el reporte de la reunión  que el documento debe continuar bajo la revisión de  línea por línea para todos los artículos, incluso aquellos que se presentan  como textos “limpios” , pues se puede pensar que al no tener corchetes es  porque existe convergencia en ellos y no es así. Todos esos artículos limpios  deberían estar entre corchetes también.      A pesar de todos los esfuerzos, el texto de hoy no refleja todas las  propuestas presentadas durante las discusiones de los grupos de contacto  y las informales.  Algunas posiciones y propuestas se han incluido y otras se  han dejado de lado.     No obstante, reconocemos que ahora contamos con un texto completo y  más corto para seguir trabajando, bajo el principio de que nada está  acordado hasta que todo esté acordado.     Señor Presidente ,    Cuba enfatiza  que un instrumento sólido para eliminar la contaminación por  plásticos tiene que incluir disposiciones robustas sobre la provisión de  Financiamiento  y Medios de Implementación  a los países en desarrollo. Sin este componente no será posible  el instrumento. Rechazamos además el  intento de imponer términos no acordados intergubernamentalmente , que  desvirtúa el proceso,  y reiteramos nuestro llamado por una renovada  voluntad política  de los paí ses desarrollados bajo los  Artículos 11 y 12.     En es e sentido, apoyamos la solicitud del GRULAC de que las  negociaciones sobre los artículos 11 y 12 comiencen desde el inicio de  nuestra próxima sesión.     Para los Pequeños E stados Insulares en Desarrollo resulta además vital una  ambiciosa disposición sobre un mecanismo de cooperación en  Remediación.     Sin dudas, estamos en una compleja negociación  y pareciera como si  estuviéramos todavía en el INC 1. Llevamos 2 años negociando y es hora  de buscar soluciones de convergencia para solucionar un grave probl ema  ambiental  y al mismo tiempo salvaguardar el derecho al desarrollo de  nuestros países.     Nuestro instrumento legalmente vinculante sobre contaminació n por  plásticos se negocia en un  contexto más amplio de la Agenda 2030  de la  ONU . En tal sentido, e s importa nte que trabajemos con la suficiente visión  de promover sinergias con las acciones de todos nuestros países dirigidas  al cumplimiento de los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible  y la  implementación de otros Acuerdos Multilaterales Medioambientales .     Continuemos con la voluntad y confianza de que podremos  lograr un tratado  que pueda ser ratificado por todos los países.     Nuestra s últimas palabras son en agradecimiento a los a nfitriones, la  República de Corea por su esmero y hospitalidad durante nuestra estancia  en Busan.     Muchas gracias Señor Presidente.

Title: Eritrea
file_content: Closing Remarks of the State of Eritrea at the Fourth Intergovernmental  Negotiating Committee to Develop an International Legally Binding  Instrument on plastic pollution, including in the Marine Environment                      25 November to 01 December 2024, Busan, South Korea     Thank you, Mr. Chair for giving me the floor. As this is our first time to take the floor in the  plenary, we would like to thank the people and government of the republic of Korea for the  warm hospitalit y and excellent arrangement of this important meeting. We also appreciate the  work of the Chair, the Bureau and the INC Secretariat.     Mr.Chair   Eritrea stands in solidarity with the African group expressing both our aspirations and  disappointments. Eritrea  is committed to a robust treaty that addresses the full life cycle of  plastics, from production to disposal. We are disappointed that consensus could not be reached  but we remain resolute in pursuit of a treaty that addresses our environmental concerns an d the  health of our communities.     Eritrea has demonstrated leadership in enacting a legislation banning single use plastics bags.  However, the challenges persist as plastic waste continuous to flood our ecosystems and shores,  exacerbated by global producer s. We call for a treaty that reduces plastic production while  ensuring the support for implementation and a just transition.     The fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee has negotiated substantive  matters extensively. The Session has e nhanced areas of convergence and narrowed areas of  divergence. We acknowledge that we still have to work to further identify areas of convergence  while consolidating the identified ones. Eritrea urges all parties to understand the urgency of this  crisis an d work towards a solution that reflects the needs and realities of all nations, especially  those which are vulnerable.     I thank you,

Title: Jamaica
file_content: Jamaica al igns its statement  with that of Ur uguay  on behalf of GRULA C and Sa moa on behalf   of the A lliance of the  Small I sland Dev eloping S tates.   We would  like to take this opportunity  to express our appreciation to the Governme nt and   People of the Republ ic of Korea for  hostin g this meeting in  Busan. Additio nally, we appreciate   your lead ership over these past  days  on this very complex and sensitive issue of ending  plastic  pollution , including in the  mar ine envi ronment .   While we  are willing to  utilize your  Non -Paper  as the basis for the negotiations at the  next  meeting of the INC , we  are very concerned that some  of our proposals present ed in contact  groups as well as informal s have not been reﬂected  in your  Non -Pap er. This is of great  concern to this delegation as this means that  some  of these  proposa ls will not be in cluded  in the document which will be available  for fu rther consultations at the  national , sub - regional  and regi onal level s. Therefore, Jama ica will have no ch oice but to reintroduce our  proposals , as oppo sed to receiving feed back from other  delegations  on these  proposals at  our next meeting. In this regard, Jamaica calls again for  the establishment  of a Subsidiary  Body on Implementation (SBI) which will addr ess the myriad of implementation  issues under   this instrument . The membership of this Body would  be u nive rsal  allowing  all Parties to  partic ipate in an inclusive and t ransp arent manner in the  effec tive implementation  of the  instrument . As Parties deal with the  scientiﬁc, tech nical and socio-econom ic issues  under  the instrument , we must  also sim ultaneously deal in a serious way with matters related to  imp lement ation – we believe that these elements  are two sides of the  same co in. We wo uld  like to  reiterate that  the SBI is not the  Implem entation and Com pliance Committee outli ned  in Article 13 of  the text  which is primarily concerned with  addressing issues of individual  party non -compliance.   It is also important that  the INC sends a clear  and coherent message to all stakeholders ,  including the privat e sector , on the policy direction that will be pursu ed in the development  and implementation  of the trea ty. Theref ore, we must ha ve str ong mandatory p rovisio ns  under  Article 3 and 6, inclusive of initial lists , which must  be underpinned by robust  provisi ons on means of implementation . It is not possible to effectively ad dress p lastic  pollution  without addressing issues related to p roduction.   The provi sions of the treaty are  not words on paper . It wi ll have signiﬁcant  implicatio ns for  the lives and livelihoods of vulnerable  populations, including those  SIDS , as well as our  continued growth  and development  which is dependen t in large part on the marine  environment .  Jamaica remains committed to the  process  and will continue to work constructively  with you  and the other member s of the INC in ensuring that we achieve  a successful outcome of a legal ly binding instrument on plastic pollution , including the marine environment  as per  UNEA Resolution 5/14.
