Title: Ukraine
file_content: Closing remarks  of the Delegation of Ukraine  at the Fifth session of the Intergovernmental  Negotiation Committ ee to develop an international legally binding instrument on plastic  pollutions, including in the marine environment (INC -5)  (01.12.202 4, Busan, Republic of Korea )    Mr. C hairperson,   Madam Executive Director,   Excellencies,   Distinguished colleagues,     I am honored to deliver this statement on behalf of the Government of Ukraine.     As we have successfully approached the accomplishment of the meeting , let me express my  deepest gratitude to INC and UNEP teams for the excellent  organization of the 5th session of the  INC, as well as to the Government  and people of the Republic of Korea  for their hospitality.   The Delegation of Ukraine welcomes the progress achieved during the INC -5 and believes that  we are now one more step closer to the ambitious and vital common goal - to end plastic pollutions  and to preserve our nature for future generations.   We would  also like to express our sincere appreciation to all the like -minded countries from  High Ambition Coalition to End Plastic Pollution (HAC) and to HAC Secretariat team for their tireless   efforts  and strong commitment to have effective  and ambitious document.   With sincere appreciation we would also like to recognize and support the generous offer of  the Governments  of the Republic of Peru and the Republic of Rwanda to host a Diplomatic  Conference in 2025.     Dear colleague s,  Unfortunately, this Delegation cannot full y share the satisfaction  of the successful conclusion  of yet another milestone towards the achieving  of plastic -free environment.   As UNEP Executive Director Inger Andersen rightly mentioned  at the beginning of th is session,  1000 days since the establishment of INC  during UNEA 5.1  have already passed . For 1000 days g lobal  community is fighting for better, safer, and healthier future .  However,  for Ukraine these 1000  days are also about another fight – the fight for the right to  be independent, free and peaceful country. As we are  discussing the important provisions of future  treaty, millions of Ukrainians are hiding in the shelters  and surviving daily insane attacks . That is  our  reality now. The horrible  reality of 1000 days of war.   The neocolonial and imperialistic ambitions of the Russian Federation , representative of which  are shamelessly  present i n this room, has led to tremendous  human casualties, destruction s,  uncontrolled pollution s, and emissions of pollutants.  The toxic legacy of barb arian and inhuman  actions of the invader s poses  a cross -border threat for people's health, their well -being, and the  economic potential of both Ukraine and neighboring countries.   Ukrainian experts have already recorded more than 5, 900 cases of direct damage to the  environment, which, according to preliminary estimates alone, caused losses of about USD 60  billion.  We are now facing a tremendous increase in the number  of war -related wastes, including  plastic one. Russian was of aggression has generate d substantial plastic debris, including packaging  materials, single -use items, and remnants of military supplies, which are contaminat ing local  environments. The destruction of infrastructure also result ed in the release of plastics into the  environment, where they accumulated  in soil and waterways, harming ecosystems and wildlife.  Additionally,  in many regions of Ukraine  the war fare disrupt ed waste management systems,  exacerbating plastic waste issues .  It will take decades for Ukraine to fully recover the affected ecosystems and  to eliminate the  wastes, produced by the warfare.   That is why the issue of environmental security is among the important priorities that we are   considering as part of the implementation of the Peace Formula of President of Ukraine Volodymyr  Zelenskyy. We call on all countries that respect and adhere to the norms and principles of  international law and the UN Charter, as well as care about the env ironment, to join the  implementation of the Peace Formula , and particularly  its point 8, dedicated to environmental  security.   The Peace Formula of President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelenskyy, is the only non -alternative  peace plan that will guarantee the restoration of a comprehensive, just and sustainable peace for  Ukraine and security for the world as a whole in all spheres, including ecology.     Excellencies ,  Ukraine , as a country severely affected by the armed aggression, understands what a n impact   the war leaves behind. Emissions into the atmosphere, pollution of lands and rivers, irreparable  damage to biodiversity are just a few examples of such impacts  of wars .   The Government  of Ukraine  has prioritized ecological issues by integrating environmental  concerns into our national policies, particularly in the wake of the 2014  illegal temporarily  occupation of Ukrainian Crimea by the Russian Federation  as well as its full -scale invasion of Ukraine  in 2022. Ukraine has engaged in efforts to rehabilitate areas affected by the aggression , focusing on  restoring ecosystems and promoting sustainable development. Civil society organizations and  grassroots movements have also played a crucial role in a dvocating for environmental protection,  raising awareness about pollution, deforestation, and the impacts of war on natural resources.  Despite facing significant challenges, Ukraine’s leadership in environmental protection reflects a  growing recognition of  the importance of sustainability and resilience in ensuring a healthy  environment for future generations.   Ukraine  strive s to not only overcome the negative consequences  of aggression on the  environment of our own country , but also actively work on strengthening international  environmental protection mechanisms.    That’s why our country has initiated a number of  globally recognized initiatives, in particular,  within UNEA  as well as always supported the most ambitious intentions of world community, aimed  at combating global environmental challenges .   Since the very first days o f our work within INC process , Ukraine has been reiterat ing its  position regarding the need to  ensure  that our work will lead to  legally binding and globally  harmonized requirements for transparency  of information on chemicals and polymers in plastic  materials and products as well as traceability of  this information in individual plastic materials and  products across the entire lifecycle of plastics in the value chain.   We are glad that today we are much closer towards this goal.     Dear colleagues,   To sum up, we would like once again to express our appreciation to all those, who is  supporting us in combating global environmental challenges. We are looking forward to the  successful accomplishment of the ongoing process within INC and hope that soon we will be able to  start the practical implementation of the future treaty on plastic pollutions.      Thank you!     ___________________________________________

Title: Egypt
file_content: السيد الرئيس     أود أولا  أن أطلب بتسجيل كلمة بالدى فى  التقرير  الرسمى للجلسة     السيد الرئيس، السادة ا عضاء الوفود المحترمين   أود فى البداية   أن  أ تقدم بالشكر للرئيس  وفريق العمل والسكرتارية، وكذلك   أتقدم   بالشكر للرؤساء المشتركين للمجموعات المختلفة على الجهود التى بذلوها جميعا  للوصول الى هذه النقطة.     كما  أود  أن  أتقدم بالشكر الى   شعب و حكومة  جمهورية   كوريا على استضافة هذه   المفاوضات، ان بوسان مدينة جميلة تشهد على ما حققته بالدكم من تطور واذهار لم   يقتصر على التطور التكنولو جى والصناعى العلمى بل اتسع ليشمل الفن والثقافة،  انى   اعتزم استخدام جانب من الساعات المتبقية لى فى بوسان فى شراء البومات   لفرق   غنائية كورية   لطفلة مصرية   تعيش على بعد الف الميال هى  ابنتى الصغرى المحبة   لل  k-pop.      السيد الرئيس، أن وفد   بالدى يود أن يشيد بالجهد الذى بذلته المجموعات  المختلفة  وخاصة تلك التى تنتمى اليها بالدى خالل األيام والليالى الماضية لتحقيق تقدم، على    الرغم من ضبابية  القواعد و الجراءات و  امتداد  جدول  المفاوضات   حتى الساعات األولى   من الصباح.   السيد الرئيس، اذ نؤكد على تقديرنا للجهود التى بذلتها وفريق عملك  وصولا   للورقة محل النقاش   و ما نتج عن ذلك من ت حقيق بعض التقدم،  ال اننا ل نتوافق  على  استخدامها كاساس للتفاوض  في صورتها الحالية ، حيث  إننا نرى   أنها  مازالت   تفتقد   التوزان ،  و ل  تتضمن العديد من المداخالت التى قدمها وفد بالدى  خالل مجموعات  التصال وعبر المنصة  الخاصة بوثائق المفاوضات  و الجلسات غير الرسمية ،   على   الرغم من  تأكيد الرئيس بورقته المشار اليها إن النص يعكس ما دار خالل  تلك   الجلسات. كما لم تتضمن الورقة مداخالت واراء   من المجموعة الفريقية والمجموعة  العربية التى تنتمى اليهما بالدى ،  وبناء على ما تقدم فأننا  نؤكد على  استخدام الورقة   كأساس للنقاش، وليس المفاوضات، خالل الجولة القادمة.   السيد الرئيس،  اسمح لى ان ابداء  تعليقاتى بالعتراض   على اختفاء بند "النطاق"   بورقة الرئيس ،  وهو موضوع ل يمكن قبول ع دم   تناوله  فى  اية اتفاقية دولية،  و افتقد   النص ما طالبت به بالدى من تضمين لغة انشاء " آلية مستقلة للتعويض" عن اية    خسائر تتعرض لها الدول النامية من تطبيق  اللتزامات   التى قد   ينص عليها الصك   الدولى الملزم قانوناا ،  و نؤكد على  خالفية المواد  2  -3  -6  -9   ونطالب ببقائها قيد القواس الى حين التواصل لتوافق بشأنها.    كما  يطالب وفد بالدى بوضع   الفقرات التالية  بين اقواس،  والتى اعتبرت ورقة الرئيس   انها توافقية، على الرغم من استمرار التباين حولها وهى كما يلى:       الفقرة 5 ببند المقدمة- الفقرة D  بالبند1  من المادة1-  المالحق الخاصة بالمادة  3  الخاصة بالمنتج البالستيكي-  الفقرة األولى البندين  a ,b      من المادة الخامسة المعنونة تصميم المنتج-  الفقرة األولى ، بندين  a ,b  من المادة السابعة المعنونة التسربات -     الفقرة  1    بالمادة12  الخاصة ببناء  القدرات -  المادة  22  الخاصة بتسوية المنازعات   الفقرة  2-    المادة10  بخصوص التحول العادل-  المادة  29  الخاصة بالتحفظ-  المادة   25  الحق فى التصويت  الفقرة  2-    المادة21    الخاصة بالسكرتارية الفقرة 3-   المادة 15  الخاصة بالتقارير الفقرة 1-  المادة20   الخاصة بمؤتمر الطراف الفقرة 3 .    ونطالب الرئيس بتسجيل ما تقدم  رسميا ،  مع اعتزامنا موافاتكم  كتابة بما تقدم    تجاه الفقرات السابق ذكرها ،  ونقترح اعادة  بالسماح بارسال المساهمات على منصة   السكرتارية.       السيد الرئيس أو د  التاكيد على أن تحقيق الطموح هو هدف يسعى اليه الجميع وان   تحقيقه يجب  أن يكون واقعيا وقابل للتنفيذ  ، وذلك لن يتسنى دون توفير وسائل التنفيذ   من تمويل  ونقل للتكنولوجيا وبناء القدرات،  وال تحول الطموح الى أمل بعيد المنال،    إن تحقيق التنمية المستدامة والقضاء على الفقر   يعتمد على تحقيق التوازن ما بين   النمو القتصادي واإلدماج الجتماعي وحماية البيئة، دون تفرقة.   ويجد وفد بالدى  أ نه   من الغريب ان تسعى أطراف الى التأكيد على "الطموح" وايمانها به والمطالبة بتحقيقه   فى الجلسات العامة وامام الحضور من اعالم ومنظمات مدنية، ال  أن ذلك   اليمان   ينتهى  على ابواب  الغرف المغلقة وبدء ال نقاش حول المسؤوليات التاريخية و  احتياجات  الدول النامية وتوفير وس ائل التنفيذ من تمويل ونقل تكنولوجيا....، وندعو الجميع الى   اتساق المطالب برفع سقف الطموح وتذليل صعوبات التنفيذ للدول النامية .  السيد الرئيس ان بالدى تتمتع بسواحل ممتدة على البحرين البيض والحمر،   وتحظى بمساحة من الشعاب المرجانية الكثر تميزا في العالم ،  وهي مهدده بخطر    التلوث البالستيكي، وهنا اؤكد ان بالدى تنفذ مشروع وطن  يا  طموح ا  لمكافحة تلوث  البالستيك احادى الستخدام، ويضطلع المجتمع المدنى بدوراا هاماا فى تنفيذه من خالل  حمالت جمع واعادة تدوير المخلفات ودعم التوعية وتوفير خيارات اكثر استدامة،   واقتراح التعديالت التشريعية الداعمة للحد من التلوث البالستيكى فى اطار الظروف  الوطنية.  السيد الرئيس إن ما دار من اجتماعات وجلسات رسمية وغير رسمية خالل   اليام الماضية أثبت حجم الهتمام العالمى بالتعاطى وتلوث البالستيك، وأننا اذ نقدر  أن الجتماعات لم تنتهى الى النتيجة المرجوة هذه المرة ال اننا نتطلع  للبناء على ما    تم تحقيقه والعمل بشكل بناء فى المرحلة القادمة ،  بهدف الوصول الى نص توافقى   حول صك دولى ملزم قانوناا للحد من تلوث البالستيك.  وشكرا

Title: Ethiopia
file_content: Statement made by Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia During the closing Plenary of Inc 5  On 1st December, 2024, Busan, South Korea.   Thank you chair, Distinguished delegates   On behalf of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, I align with the statement delivered by  Ghana on behalf of the African Group.   The escalating plastic pollution crisis necessitates urgent and decisive action. Despite progress  made during this fifth session, significant challenges persist, particularly regarding the scope of  the treaty and the inclusion of the full life cycle of pla stic.  Ethiopia remains committed to an ambitious treaty that addresses the full life cycle of plastic,  including the reduction /elimination  of toxic and hazardous chemicals. We support the proposal  to suspend INC5 and schedule INC5.2  in the near future to allow for further discussion and  decision -making on these critical issues.   We also call for a treaty that prioritizes a just transition for frontline communities, particularly  waste pickers, who bear the brunt of the plastic pollution crisis. We must ensure that any  solutions we adopt do not exacerbate existing inequalities and e nvironmental injustices."   We express our gratitude to the Chair, the Secretariat, UNEP , and the host country, the Republic  of Korea, for their invaluable contributions and dedication to this important process.   As we conclude this session, let us carry the momentum forward and work together to achieve a  robust and effective global plastics treaty.   Thank you.

Title: India
file_content: Page 1 of 4   INTERVENTION   INDIA   FINAL PLENARY   01122024      Thank you Chair,     As we are nearing the completion of INC 5 deliberations, India would like  to thank the Chair and Secretariat for all the efforts made to achieve a  consensus based  outcome at INC 5.  We would also like to thank Republic  of Korea for hosting all of us, here in the beautiful city of Busa n. Our thanks  also go out to the co -chairs of contact groups a nd co-facilitators of informal   sessions  for taking forward the INC process.     Chair, we all acknowledge that addressing plastic pollution is extremely  important  to all and that is the reason why we all are here. The enormity  of the problem is such that no nation alone can completely resolve this  challenge. That is why,  2 years back, at UNEA 5, we all resolved to come  together and work towards the international legally binding instrument.     India being home to 1.4 billion people understands its responsibility in  tackling the challenge of plastic pollution. While we all are working to  develop the instrument, India has already taken a series of measures  including  bann ing some of short lived plastic  products and putting in place   an ambitious and robust EPR regime  on plastic packaging . We are moving  towards sustainable plastic packaging, reducing the use of virgin material.     At the same time,  Chair, we cannot deny the important role plastic plays  in development of our societies and in varied sectors of econom y.    Page 2 of 4   Therefore, the instrument  we finalise, needs to strike a critical balance  between preventing the leakage of plastic in the environment and, at the  same time,  not affecting sustainable development , particularly of,  developing economies. We understand that this is a difficult ask which  requires mutual trust and understanding of each other’s circumstances. In  this context, our approach to finalise the draft instrument should be based  on mutual trust,  cooperation and the spirit of consensus.     Therefore, Chair, c onsensus must be  the basis of all our decisions,   including Amendments in the instrument  and its  Annexures .    Chair , we  thank you once again for bringing out updated version of Chair's  non paper. Though  India has some observations on the paper , we will be  happy to further engage on it.  I would like to highlight some of our  observations here:      We note that some  recommendations made by Member States are not  reflected in this version. Hence, we seek reassurance from you chair, that  Member States will get an opportunity to get their views reflected during  further negotiations.     Abiding by the principle that nothing is agreed until everything is agreed,  we look forward to develop a package agreed to by all ,in a fair, inclusive  and transparent manner.     Any instrument  including ours , has to have clearly defined scope. This has  been left out from the new version. India would request to reinsert it.      Page 3 of 4   We also would like to convey that the scope of the instrument should be  limited to addressing plastic pollution only without overlapping with the  mandate of other multilateral environmental agreements and other  relevant instruments and bodies.     India would like to state its inability to  support any measures to regulate  the  production of primary plastic polymers as it has larger implications in  respect of  the right to development of Member States.     Inclusion of a n article on Reservations on Annexures, as the shape and  form of some articles can have trade implications , may be considered.     We also d id not support inclusion of any list with phase out dates, at this  stage. This has not been reflected in the Chair’s text.     Taking into account that the instrument has to be implemented by Member  States, in a nationally driven manner, due consideration to national  circumstances and capabilities should be given.     Provision, of technical and financial assistance including technology  transfer to developing countries, is the key for effective implementation of  the new instrument. Therefore, a stand -alone dedicated multilateral fund  providing financial resources  to developing countries for meeting  incremental costs for their compliance obligations  is required .           Page 4 of 4   Chair, as you are aware, India has always been committed to the principle  of consensus in decision making in respect of substantive matters under  multilateral environmental agreements . This  principle reiterates collective  decision -making and reflects shared responsibilities and commitment.   Therefore, we would reiterate our position in the forthcoming negotiations  as well.     Let me assure you, Chair, that India remain s committed to engage in the  forthcoming negotiations  at time and place that may be decided  in positive  and constructive spirit.     We would request you to include this statement in the meeting report of  INC-5.    I thank you Chair

Title: Kazakhstan
file_content: 1    Statement	by	Kazakhstan	INC-5,	Busan,	Korea,		December	1,	2024			Уважаемый	господин	Председатель,			Позвольте	выразить	благодарность	Вам,	Секретариату	за	вашу	плодотворную,	непростую	 и	 ответственную	 работу	 и	 Правительству	Республики	Корея	за	открытость	и	гостеприимство.	На	протяжении	недели,	практически	круглосуточно	стороны	активно	работали	над	формированием	документа,	направленного	на	борьбу	с	загрязнением	пластмассами,	в	том	числе	и	в	морскоиD	среде.	Проблема	 загрязнения	 пластиком	 чрезвычайно	 актуальна.	 Безусловно,	необходимо	 объединить	 усилия	 в	 разработке	 глобальных	 рекомендаций,	направленных	на	обеспечение	экологически	рационального	управления	пластиком,	учитывая	 нарастающие	 риски,	 связанные	 с	 увеличением	 численности	 населения,	потребления	 пластиковых	 изделий	 и	 растущих	 объемов	 образования	 пластиковых	отходов.		Важно,	что	устойчивое	экономическое	развитие	и	повышение	благосостояния	граждан	должны	 идти	 рука	 об	 руку	 с	принципами	 экологической	 устойчивости,	отражая	12	Цель	устойчивого	развития	-	устойчивое	производство	и	потребления.	В	 этой	 связи	особое	 внимание	 стоит	 уделить	 	продвижению	циркулярной	экономике,	управлению	отходами,	 внедрению	 современных	 технологий	 и	регулированию	одноразового	 пластика	с	 учетом	 национальных	 особенностей	 и	принципа	общей,	но	дифференцированной	ответственности.		Хотел	бы	отметить,	что	для	достижения	наиболее	эффективных	результатов	в	борьбе	с	загрязнением	пластиком,	важно	учитывать	мнение	без	исключения	каждого.	Таким	образом,	как	я	отмечал	в	своем	первом	выступлении	в	понедельник,	итоговый	документ	 должен	 быть	 принят	 консенсусом.	 Это	 очень	 важно,	 так	 как	 это	единственный	способ	обеспечения	равных	условий	для	всех	стран.	Казахстан	–	это	страна	с	активно	развивающейся	экономикой,	населением	в	20	миллионов	 человек	 и	 не	 имеющая	 выхода	 к	 морю.	 Наше	 влияние	 на	 загрязнение	окружающей	среды	и	тем	более	морской	среды	в	глобальных	масштабах	минимально.	При	 этом	 предлагаемые	 Соглашением	 положения	 ставят	 риск	 для	 развития	ключевых	 отраслей	 промышленности	 в	 Казахстане,	 в	 частности	-	производство	первичных	полимеров.	Любые	ограничения,	связанные	с	производством	первичной	полимерной	 продукции,	 ставят	 под	 угрозу	 развитие	 экономики,	 создание	 рабочих	мест	и	имеют	риск	создания	социально-экономической	нестабильности	в	стране,	что	является	красной	чертой.	И	я	уверен,	что	такую	позицию	разделяют	многие	стороны.		Отмечаю,	что	Казахстан	как	и	другие	страны	не	должны	нести	ответственность	за	страны,	которые	внесли	значительно	больший	исторический	вклад	в	загрязнение	пластиком,	в	частности	морской	среды.		2    Таким	 образом,	 мы	 считаем	 важным	 учесть	 исключение	 упоминания	 о	первичной	полимерной	продукции	в	тексте	всего	соглашения	и	указать	положения	об	 исключении	 первичных	 полимеров	 из	 предмета	 документа	 в	 первых	 статьях	Соглашения	–	целях	и	принципах.	Наша	позиция	проста	–	сокращение	загрязнения	пластиком	не	должно	идти	во	вред	развития	экономики,	национальным	интересам	и	благополучию	граждан.	Мы	 также	 обеспокоены	 тем,	 что	 эти	 ключевые	 принципы	 недостаточно	отражены	 в	 Статье	 11	 «Финансирование».	 Крайне	 важно,	 чтобы	 развитые	 страны	оказали	 значительную	 поддержку	 развивающимся	 государствам,	 создавая	необходимые	 условия	 для	 достижения	 наилучших	 результатов	 в	 глобальном	достижении	сокращения	загрязнения	пластиком.	Как	 показывает	 жизненная	 практика	 философия	 жесткого	 запрета	 не	 дает	должного	эффекта	 и	 влечет	 за	 собой	 формирование	 непрозрачных	 механизмов	 и	теневых	схем,	что	в	конечном	итоге	приведет	к	неконтролируемым	процессам.	Так,	вместо	 установления	 ограничений	 нужен	 поиск	 конструктивных	 и	взаимоприемлемых	решений	для	всех.	Сформированные	на	основе	консенсуса	международные	рекомендации	должны	стимулировать	 страны	 к	 формированию	 национальных	 программ,	 нацеленных	 на	регулирование	 оборота,	 импорта	 и	 экспорта	 пластиковой	 продукции	 и	 отходов,	направленных	на	снижение	загрязнения	окружающей	среды.	Именно	 поэтапность	 и	 установление	 переходного	 периода	 обеспечат	возможность	усовершенствования	научных	и	технологических	решений	переработки	и	утилизации,	а	также	поиска	альтернативы	пластику.	Мы	 готовы	 работать	 над	 представленным	 документом	с	 учетом	 отражения	 в	 нем	 ключевых	 для	 Казахстана	 положений,	 отражающих	сбалансированный	 подход	 защиты	 окружающей	 среды,	 здоровья	 человека	 и	недопущения	 создания	 ограничений	 для	 устойчивого	 экономического	 развития	 и	повышения	 благосостояния	 граждан.	 Мы	 готовы	 их	 представить	 официально	и	просим	отразить	нашу	позицию	в	финальном	протоколе	заседания.	Спасибо	за	внимание.	    Unofficial	translation	Dear	Mr.	Chair,	3    	I	 would	 like	 to	 express	 my	 gratitude	 to	 you,	 the	 Secretariat,	 for	 your	 dedicated,	challenging,	and	vital	work,	and	to	the	Government	of	the	Republic	of	Korea	for	its	openness	and	generous	hospitality.	Over	the	past	week,	the	parties	have	worked	tirelessly	to	develop	a	document	aimed	at	addressing	plastic	pollution,	including	in	the	marine	environment.	The challenge of plastic pollution is more urgent than ever. It is imperative to unite efforts in crafting global guidelines to promote environmentally responsible plastic management. This must take into account the escalating risks posed by population growth, rising consumption of plastic products, and the expanding volume of plastic waste.	Sustainable	economic	development	and	improved	well-being	of	citizens	must	go	hand	in	 hand	 with	 environmental	 sustainability	 principles,	 particularly	 in	 alignment	 with	Sustainable	Development	Goal	12	–	responsible	consumption	and	production.	In	this	context,	it	is	crucial	to	emphasize	the	promotion	of	a	circular	economy,	effective	waste	management,	adoption	of	modern	technologies,	and	regulation	of	single-use	plastics,	all	 while	 accounting	 for	 national	 circumstances	 and	 the	 principle	 of	 common	 but	differentiated	responsibilities.	To	achieve	the	best	results	in	combating	plastic	pollution,	it	is	vital	to	consider	the	perspectives	of	all	participants	without	exception.	As	I	highlighted	in	my	opening	remarks	on	Monday,	the	final	document	must	be	adopted	by	consensus.	This	is	critical	to	ensure	equal	and	fair	conditions	for	all	countries.	Kazakhstan,	 as	 a	 landlocked	 country	 with	 a	 population	 of	 20	 million	 and	 a	 rapidly	growing	 economy,	 has	 a	 minimal	 global	 impact	 on	 environmental	 pollution,	 particularly	marine	pollution.	However,	the	provisions	proposed	in	the	Agreement	pose	significant	risks	to	the	development	of	key	industrial	sectors	in	Kazakhstan,	particularly	the	production	of	primary	 polymers.	 Restrictions	 on	 the	 production	 of	 primary	 polymer	 products	 could	undermine	economic	growth,	jeopardize	job	creation,	and	risk	socio-economic	instability—this	is	a	clear	red	line	for	us.	I	am	confident	that	many	other	countries	share	this	perspective.	It	is	also	important	to	recognize	that	Kazakhstan,	like	other	nations,	should	not	bear	responsibility	for	countries	with	a	far	greater	historical	contribution	to	plastic	pollution,	particularly	in	the	marine	environment.	We,	therefore,	strongly	advocate	for	the	exclusion	of	primary	polymer	products	from	the	scope	of	the	Agreement.	This	should	be	explicitly	reflected	in	the	early	articles	of	the	Agreement—its	goals	and	principles.	Our	position	is	clear:	efforts	to	reduce	plastic	pollution	must	not	come	at	the	expense	of	economic	development,	national	interests,	or	the	well-being	of	our	citizens.	Additionally,	we	are	concerned	that	these	key	principles	are	not	sufficiently	addressed	in	Article	11,	"Financing."	It	is	imperative	for	developed	countries	to	provide	substantial	support	to	developing	nations,	creating	the	necessary	conditions	to	achieve	optimal	results	in	the	global	effort	to	combat	plastic	pollution.	Experience	shows	that	strict	bans	often	fail	to	produce	the	desired	outcomes.	Instead,	they	can	lead	to	non-transparent	mechanisms	and	shadow	practices,	ultimately	resulting	in	unregulated	processes.	Rather	than	imposing	rigid	restrictions,	we	must	seek	constructive	and	mutually	acceptable	solutions.	Consensus-driven	 international	 recommendations	 should	 encourage	 nations	 to	develop	national	programs	that	regulate	the	production,	circulation,	import,	and	export	of	plastic	products	and	waste,	with	a	clear	focus	on	reducing	environmental	pollution.	A	phased	approach	and	well-defined	transition	periods	will	enable	advancements	in	scientific	 and	 technological	 solutions	 for	 recycling	 and	 disposal	 while	 fostering	 the	development	of	viable	plastic	alternatives.	4    We	 are	 ready	 to	 work	 on	 the	 proposed	 document,	 taking	 into	 account	 the	inclusion	 of	 key	 provisions	 for	 Kazakhstan	that	 reflect	 a	 balanced	 approach	 to	environmental	protection,	human	health,	and	the	prevention	of	restrictions	on	sustainable	economic	 development	 and	 the	 well-being	 of	 citizens.	 We	 are	 prepared	 to	 present	 them	officially,	and	we request that our position be duly reflected in the final meeting protocol.		Thank	you	for	your	attention.	                          Kazakhstan’s comments on the Non-Paper containing the draft text of the Chair of the Committee (01 December, 2024)  CHAIR’S TEXT1   [PREAMBLE  5    The Parties to this Convention,  Noting with concern that the high and rapidly increasing levels of plastic pollution, including in the marine environment, represent a serious environmental and human health problem, negatively impacting the environmental, social and economic dimensions of sustainable development,  Acknowledging the important role played by plastics in human society, and stressing the importance of establishing effective mechanisms throughout the plastic lifecycle to promote plastic circularity and prevent leakage of plastics in the environment,  Recognizing the significant contribution made by all workers in the plastics sector, especially those that are in informal and cooperative settings and small and medium-sized enterprises, to the collection, sorting and recycling of plastics in many countries,  [Recognizing the special circumstances of developing countries, small island developing States and of least developed countries, Landlocked Developing Countries and the disproportionate impacts of plastic pollution on small island developing states and other lower riparian developing countries,]  Underlining the importance of science-based decision-making and the contributions of scientific, economic, social, and technical information, including traditional knowledge and indigenous knowledge systems, for the implementation of measures to reduce plastic pollution and to improve the understanding of the full life cycle of plastics and of the global impact of plastic pollution and measures to address them,  Reaffirming the principles of the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, adopted in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 1992, including, inter alia, the principle of common but differentiated responsibility and respective capabilities, sustainable development and the sovereign right of states to exploit their own resources pursuant to their own environmental and developmental policies,  Recognizing that this Convention and other international agreements in the field of the environment are mutually supportive,  Emphasizing that nothing in this Convention is intended to affect the rights and obligations of any Party deriving from any existing international agreement,  Understanding that the above recital is not intended to create a hierarchy between this Convention and other international instruments,  Noting the importance of taking into account national circumstances and capabilities in the implementation of relevant provisions of this Convention.  Noting that nothing in this Convention prevents a Party from taking additional domestic measures consistent with the provisions of this Convention in an effort to address plastic pollution in accordance with that Party’s other obligations under applicable international law,  Have agreed as follows:       1 This draft text was developed building on the outcomes of the informal consultations on 30 November and contributions from the Co-Chairs of the Contact Groups and facilitators of the informal consultations. 6     ARTICLE 1 OBJECTIVE  1. The objective of this Convention is to protect human health and the environment from plastic pollution, including in the marine environment [based on a comprehensive approach that address the [circular economy] full life cycle of plastics]. [2. The mandate of this Convention excludes2: (a) Feedstock such as hydrocarbons and their derivatives, which have to be further processed for serving end uses, and any dual-use items, including among others, monomers and polymers in primary forms made thereof; (b) Plastics use in healthcare; (c) Plastics use in scientific research; (d) Plastics use in experimental research;]   ARTICLE 1bis PRINCIPLES AND APPROACHES  Option 0  No Article  Option 1  1. In their actions to achieve the objective of this Convention and to implement its provisions, the Parties shall be guided, inter alia, by the following:  (a) The Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, adopted in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 1992, including, inter alia, the principle of common but differentiated responsibility and respective capabilities, sustainable development and the sovereign right of states to exploit their own resources pursuant to their own environmental and developmental policies,  (b) Right of development is inherent to human right, all peoples have an equal right to matters relating to safe living means. Economic development is the prerequisite for adopting measures to address plastic pollution. Developing countries have a right to grow sustainable consumption to meet social and economic development needs.  (c) Principle of sovereignty of States in international cooperation to address the issue of plastics pollution in a facilitative, non-intrusive and non-punitive manner, and avoiding any undue burden being placed on Parties.  (d) In accordance with the Charter of the United Nations and the principles of international law, the sovereign right to exploit their own resources pursuant to their own environmental and developmental policies, and the responsibility to ensure that activities within their jurisdiction or control do not cause damage to the environment of other States or of areas beyond the limits of national jurisdiction.  (e) Protect the environmental system for the benefit of present and future generations of humankind, on the basis of historical responsibility, equity and in accordance with their common but differentiated responsibilities between developed and developing countries, taking into account developed countries’ historical contribution to plastic pollution due to high production and consumption levels, industrial activities, and waste management practices.  (f) Ensure that measures taken to combat plastic pollution, including unilateral ones, do not introduce trade distortions and constitute a means of arbitrary or unjustifiable discrimination or a disguised restriction on international trade.  7    (g) Just and equitable transitions should respect nationally defined development priorities and ensure social and economic protections. This approach aims to mitigate impacts of such transitions, recognizing the diverse pathways needed to address plastic pollution and the differing financial, technical and technological burdens [capabilities] between developed and developing countries.  (h) Precautionary approach must be in a cost-effective manner and aligned with national circumstances, capabilities and different socioeconomic context. 8     (i) In the implementation of the commitments in this Convention, the [developed country] Parties shall give full consideration of necessary actions under the Instrument, including actions related to funding, insurance and the transfer of technology, to meet the specific needs and concerns of developing country Parties arising from the adverse effects of plastic pollution and the impact of the implementation of response measures.  Option 2  1. In order to achieve the objectives of this Convention, Parties shall be guided by the following principles: (a) The polluter-pays principle; (b) The precautionary principle, as appropriate; (c) The principles of international law embodied in the Charter of the United Nations, such as the principles of equal rights and self-determination of peoples, of sovereign equality and independence of all States, of non-interference in the domestic affairs of States, and of universal respect for, and observance of, human rights and fundamental freedoms for all; (d) The special circumstances of small island developing States (SIDS) and of least developed countries, [land locked countries,] and the disproportionate impacts of plastic pollution on small island developing States. (e) The use of the best available science and scientific information. (f) The use of relevant traditional knowledge, knowledge of Indigenous Peoples, and local knowledge systems, where available.  Option 3  In their actions to achieve the objective of the Convention and to implement its articles, the Parties shall be guided, inter alia, by the principles of international law embodied in the Charter of the United Nations and the principles of the Rio Declaration on Environment and Development, including the sovereign right of States to exploit their own resources pursuant to their own environmental and developmental policies as set out in Principle 2, the right to development as set out in Principle 3, the principle of common but differentiated responsibilities as set out in Principle 7, the precautionary approach as set out in Principle 15, and the polluter pays principle as set out in Principle 16 thereof.  ARTICLE 2 DEFINITIONS2  For the purposes of this Convention:  (a) “Party” means a State or regional economic integration organization that has consented to be bound by this Convention and for which the Convention is in force.  (b)  “Plastic” means material(s) made wholly or partly of synthetic or semi-synthetic [of] polymers, including additives or other substances, that can be shaped during processing and serve as structural components of products.   (c) “Plastic pollution” means:  i. [pollution caused by or released throughout the life cycle of plastics [waste]] ii. [all emissions and releases resulting from plastic production, use, waste management and leakage from different sources and pathways]  (d) “Plastic product” means a product which contains or is partly or entirely made of any form of plastic.    2 Definitions alternatively, can be addressed in the annex to the Convention, providing for a more flexible approach to any future adjustments. 9     (e) “Plastic waste” means materials of substance consisting of plastic which are disposed of, intended to be disposed, or required to be disposed of by the provisions of national law.  (f) “Regional economic integration organization” means an organization constituted by sovereign States of a given region to which its member States have transferred competence in respect of matters governed by this Convention, and which has been duly authorized, in accordance with its internal procedures, to sign, ratify, accept, approve or accede to this Convention.  (g) [“Recycling” means the action or process of converting plastic waste into reusable materials while adhering to the principles of the waste hierarchy;]  - мы настаиваем, чтобы было это определение, тк перевод на русский их теста звучит как утилизация (recover)    [ARTICLE 3 PLASTIC PRODUCTS3   [1. The Secretariat shall make such reports publicly available.]  3. The [Review] Committee shall [, inter alia], as appropriate, develop [guidance][guidelines] and provide relevant information, [advice, and recommendations] [including development of a robust and scientific framework of criteria and the evaluation] to assist Parties in the implementation of the measures taken to implement [paragraph 1] [this article] [, as well as compile and review the information provided by the Parties 10    pursuant to paragraph 2]. Such guidance, [information,] [advice, or recommendations] shall be submitted to the COP for [consideration and] [adoption] [by consensus].    3 Pending further consultations. 11     4bis. The review Committee modalities and procedures shall be established by the Conference of the Parties at its first meeting.] [by consensus]. [Such Committee shall develop the criteria and the obligations of Parties to apply such criteria]  5. Such a proposal shall include:  (a) a detailed justification demonstrating how the product meets [any][one or more] [of] the criteria [set out in paragraph 1] [to be developed and adopted by the Conference of the Parties], [and (b) scientific or technical information on:]  [The [Review] Committee shall evaluate the proposal in a transparent [and on the basis of the best available science and relevant traditional knowledge, knowledge of Indigenous Peoples, and local knowledge systems] [and scientifically sound] manner. [If the [Review] Committee determines that the criteria are met, it shall recommend to the COP whether the product should be added to the [global] list]. At its first meeting, the Conference of the Parties shall adopt the format of report of information referred to in paragraph 2 of this Article.]  6. [Such recommendations shall take into account [the criteria listed in paragraph 1 and] [at least] [among other] the following factors:]]  (a) The necessity of the plastic product and its intended use; (b) The performance, safety, environmental impact, technical feasibility, affordability, availability, and accessibility of alternative products or methods; (c) The risk posed by chemicals of concern contained in the plastic product; (d) The socio-economic impacts of any proposed control measures; (e) [Where relevant,] the incorporation of [relevant] traditional knowledge, [knowledge of] Indigenous Peoples and local knowledge systems, [local practices], and scientific and technological advances]  7. [Each Party shall not allow the manufacture, import or export of plastic products as listed in Annex [Y] after the phase out date specified for that plastic product in Annex [Y], except [where an exclusion is specified in that Annex or] the Party has a registered exemption to this paragraph pursuant to Article [X on Exemptions).]  8bis. [Each Party shall require producers, importers and exporters of plastic products to ensure adequate and reliable information on chemicals used in plastic products along the various value chains, and take appropriate measures to ensure the traceability of chemicals, including in plastic products and wastes, based on globally harmonized guidelines to be adopted by the Conference of parties at its [second] meeting.”]  8ter. [Each Party shall, in accordance with the provisions of Article [X on Reporting], [provide the Secretariat with a report detailing] report on the measures adopted in implementing paragraph 1, 7 and 8 [the outcomes achieved, and any challenges encountered. The Secretariat shall make such reports publicly available].]  8quater. [Any measures established by a Party for the implementation of this Article shall be without prejudice to the rights and obligations of the Parties under the Marrakesh Agreement Establishing the World Trade Organization, including all its Annexes.]  8 quinquies. [Each Party shall endeavour to ensure the availability of information on plastic products and on prioritised chemicals in plastic products along the various value chains, and ensure the traceability of chemicals used in plastic products, based on guidelines to be adopted by the Conference of the Parties at its second meeting.]  8 sextiens. [A subsidiary body under this instrument to assess and facilitate the provision of financial and technical assistance including technology transfer to developing country Parties on voluntary and mutually agreed terms in line with the principles Rio Declaration on Environment and Development to support the implementation of the article.]   Annex Y4  Consensus  Plastic Products [Part I] Products [or product group] Phase out date Single use plastic sticks to be attached to and to support balloons [203X] Single use plastic straws [203X] Single use plastic beverage stirrers [203X] Single use plastic cutlery/ utensils (forks, knives, spoons, chopsticks) [203X] Single use plastic-stemmed cotton bud sticks [203X] Single use plastic carrier bags [203X] Rinse-off cosmetics and personal care products containing intentionally added microbeads [203X]   [Part II] Products [or product group] [containing chemicals]  Toys and children’s products and Food contact material containing: [203X]  14    4 To be included as Annexes at the end of the document subject to further consultations. 15     - DEHP (CAS number 117-81-7) - DBP (CAS number 84-74-2) - BBP (CAS number 85-68-7) - DIBP (CAS number 84-69-5)  Toys and children’s products and Food contact material containing: - Lead and lead compounds - Cadmium and cadmium compounds [203X] Toys and children’s products; Food contact material intended for children under 3 years of age containing: - BPA (CAS number 80-05-7) [203X]   Annex [X]  • Rinse-off cosmetic and personal care products containing intentionally added microbeads • Single-use plastic straws • Single use plastic beverage stirrers • Single-use plastic cutlery/utensils (forks, knives, spoons, chopsticks), • Single-use plastic food and beverage packaging made from EPS (expanded polystyrene), and XPS (extruded polystyrene) • Single-use plastic carrier bags • Oxo-degradable plastic products • Cigarette filters made with plastic]  ARTICLE 4 EXEMPTIONS5  Comment: According to para 1bis. of Article 3 “[In implementing paragraph 1, each Party shall [is encourage to] identify products based on the factors in paragraph 5b, as appropriate, and the products listed in Annex [X].]”. In this context, countries independently determine the list of products to be regulated and decide whether to limit the production of specific items based on their individual capabilities (at the national level).  For Kazakhstan, as for the entire Central Asian region, the issue of natural disasters is highly pressing. Projections of increasing average annual temperatures across Central Asia indicate that natural disasters will become more frequent and severe, further exacerbating the challenges we already face today.  This year, regrettably, our country experienced the largest floods in the past 80 years, and last year saw the most devastating wildfire, which destroyed over 60 hectares of forest. These events inflicted enormous damage on our economy and citizens.  As the ninth-largest country in the world, Kazakhstan is highly vulnerable to natural disasters driven by climatic and weather conditions. The diversity of these disasters across different regions complicates the development of preventative measures and demands significant resources to ensure that all citizens, organizations, and stakeholders are adequately covered by an effective early warning system.  During such emergencies, the use of disposable products has proven indispensable. 16     Currently, however, we lack sufficient alternatives to certain plastic products. Developing substitutes will require time. Given our geographical characteristics—4% forest coverage and 40% steppe—alternative materials, such as those derived from agricultural waste (e.g., starch, cellulose), are limited i

Title: Malaysia
file_content: MALAYSIA SUBMISSION FOR INC-5 Closing Plenary Statement Thank You Chair , Malaysia takes this opportunity to express our gratitude to the Chair and the secretariat for their hard work and efforts throughout the INC-5 negotiation. We believe that there have been productive rounds of discussions and significant progress. Despite some schedule and procedural inconsistencies that had stretched the delegates’ ability to accommodate the three parallel sessions of contact groups as well as sudden switch of mode of negotiation to informal sessions, we have continued to accommodate and engage in these sessions with a collaborative spirit. While we appreciate the Chair ’s dedicated effort in coming out with the Chair ’s Text, we fear that the Chair ’s text does not accurately reflect all the proposals submitted and the red lines highlighted by member states during the contact group discussions and the informal sessions. In this regard, Malaysia supports the statement delivered by Uruguay , Iran, Kuwait, China, Saudi Arabia, Russian Federation and Algeria. However , to demonstrate our commitment to end plastic pollution, Malaysia is flexible to accept the Chair ’s text as one of the documents that can be referred at further negotiation together with the Chair ’s non-paper issued on the 29th of November 2024 as well as the compilation text, with the understanding that the text remains bracketed and open for modification, addition or deletion by member states on the principle nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. We stand ready to work again with the Chair and other colleague in the spirit of inclusivity and consensus to conclude an instrument that is balance, practicable, realistic and can be implemented at national and global level with the ambition to end plastic pollution by addressing the full lifecycle of plastics through promotion of circularity of plastics as mandated by UNEA 5/14. Thank you, Chair .

Title: Mongolia
file_content: Statement of Mongolian Delegation on Closing plenary     Dear Chair,     The Mongolian delegation extends its sincere appreciation to the distinguished Bureau  members, the Secretariat, the Co -Chairs, the Co -facilitators, and all Members and  Observers for their tireless efforts this week  in seeking common ground to finalize the  draft text.     We would also like to express our gratitude to the Republic of Korea for their exceptional  hospitality .     As w e fully recognize the current situation and the necessity of convening another session  to achieve consensus on the entire text  in the spirit of global unity , we fully support  your  proposal text as the basis for further negotiation at the Resumed Session to advance our  INC 5 ambitions.      However, we kindly request your concise proposal for  the Resumed session , addressing   both organizational and substantive aspects . This could include  allocating additional time  to articles most frequently mentioned  during the plenary  and f ocusing on reducing  duplication, enhancing clarity, and ensuring alignment between articles and contact  groups  ensuring that critical and ambitious elements are adequately reflected in the text .     As a country reliant on traditional livelihoods and ecosystems vulnerable to pollution,  Mongolia remains committed to developing ambitious global treaty.     Furthermore, we request the inclusion of specific interim activities between the Diplomatic  Conference and COP1 in the Resumed Session agenda, as these were not discussed  during INC 5 due to time constraints.     We propose that interim activities include the development of preliminary guidance to  assist Parties in planning and implementing national actions during the transition period.     Additionally , tailored recommendations should be prepared as early as possible to  address sector -specific challenges and opportunities across key areas , enabling  alignment with our ambitious goals.     Thank you Chair.

Title: Norway
file_content: Norway closing plenary statement INC5       • Thank Mr. Chair, we would like to thank you, the co -chairs and the  secretariat for all your hard work to get us to this point. We also  express our appreciation to the Republic of Korea for hosting us  here in Busan.     • We support the statements delivered by Rwanda and Mexico on  behalf of the growing number of countries finding convergence in  this process.   • This week, we have sat through countless hours of discussions,  and we appreciate the commitment of colleagues seeking to find  common ground.     • Mr. Chair, my delegation has mixed feelings about the revised non - paper, seeing that several of our red lines have not been reflected.   • We cannot understand why the phrase “ending plastic pollution”  has been removed from the objective. This must be our guiding  star.   • The decision -making mechanisms to develop the treaty over time  is bracketed in Art. 23 and completely missing in Art. 20. Voting  must be an option when consensus has been exhausted – We  cannot accept a treaty locked in time.   • I could go on, but I recognize that this is surely the case for every  other delegation here.   • Mr. Chair, I recognize that we have run out of time.   • Therefore, we support your proposal, Mr. Chair, to use this text as  a starting point and basis for further negotiations at a resumed  session.   • It is crucial that we don’t throw out all the work we have done here.  This would be detrimental to the trust we have built, the  convergence we have heard, and not least the confidence, people  outside this conference center have in us, to find a path forwar d.   • We could not deliver a treaty as promised today. But for the first  time, we can see the contours of one in your text.

Title: Oman
file_content: Dear Mr. Chair ,   Oman  would like to appreciate the work carried out to accompl ish  our work in Busan. Moreover,  we would like to thank  Government of Republic of Korea for hosting this meeting in  Busan.   We would  like to align  our intervention s with that given by Saudi  Arabia on b ehalf of Ar ab group , Ir an , India , Kuwait.   We acknowledge a slight improvemen t on the drafting of some  articles, but the text still fails to reflect the ambition we aimed to  achieve, nor the views we have highlighted.   While we take note of the Chair’s  assurances that the text does  not prejudice  the ability of countries to propose  additions,  deletions or modifications to the text, we believe that in order for  us to move forward, we must prioritize productivity.   With that, Mr. Chair, we would like to note the following  language to be deleted:   1. Any global lists mentioned in the a nnexes of Article 3, which  relate to trade measures   2. Article 6 on supply measures   3. Article 19 on Health   Furthermore, articles 23 & 24 must be amended to focus on  consensus -building, and ensure that all voices are heard in an  inclusive and equitable man ner.   In closing, we wish to emphasize the importance of proceeding in  a manner that is based on party -driven consensus, and  nonetheless, we are looking forward to work on the Chairs Draft  moving forward.   Thanks Mr. Chair.

Title: Peru
file_content: Gracias Señor Presidente.   Agradecemos los incansables esfuerzos que ha realizado usted, la junta directiva, los co - facilitadores, su equipo y la secretaría  del INC , así como el denodado esfuerzo de los  delegados de los países comprometidos con esta causa para proponernos un borrador  de tratado que incluyera muchas posiciones intermedias, de convergencia, con la  esperanza de que pudiera concitar el apoyo universal.     Pero entendemos que, no hallando respuesta de un grupo de países, usted no haya  logrado  incluir en l as propuestas , todos los elementos de alta ambición que una mayoría  de g obiernos hemos venido impulsando , principalmente , la visión de que este tratado  abarque todo el ciclo de vida de los plásticos y no soluciones parciales que se centren ,  solamente , en el manejo de los residuos .     Señor Presidente , el Perú es un país nacido de un proceso evolutivo de civilizaciones   milenarias , que  alcanzar on un delicado balance entre el ciclo del agua, la topografía  montañosa, la aride z de sus costa s, la majestuosidad de sus  bosques amazónicos y la  mega diversidad  de su territorio .  Esta historia exitosa de convivencia entre el  hombre y su entorno natural, se ha visto  gravemente alterada en este  último siglo, a raíz de fenómenos climáticos extremos y  recurrentes, la pérdida acelerada de la biodiversidad y la contaminación ambiental ,  siendo la más preocupante  la contaminación por plásticos.   Al reflexionar sobre nuestra propia realidad , la interconexión que existe entre el clima y  los biomas planetarios y sobre el futuro que deseamos , el Perú ha optado por ser parte  comprometida en los regímenes multilaterales sobre  el cambio climático, la  biodiversidad y la desertificación ; así como de procesos regionales sobre el manejo  sostenible de la Amazonía.   Por esta  razón, el Perú y Ru anda, países comprometidos con el diálogo diplomático  multilateral , unieron sus esfuerzos desde el sur global para lanzar el proceso que dio  origen a la R esolución UNEA 5/14  y a estas negociaciones .    Sabemos  que si no  actuamos  en forma inmediata , los plásticos innecesarios que  seguimos consumiendo y las sustancias químicas que liberan, estarán presentes en el  planeta por otro milenio y, aun así, perdurarán en la forma de micro y nano plásticos,  que afectarán la salud humana y  la calidad  del medio ambiente.   Señor Presidente , ya pasó el momento para medidas voluntarias, como las muchos  gobiernos hemos venido implementando  desde hace más de una década;  sin apoyo de la comunidad internacional, sin asistencia técnica y sin disponibilidad adicional de  recursos financieros.   En tal sentido  Señor Presidente , concordamos que el documento que nos ha presentado  puede servir de base inicial para las negociaciones, precisando  la necesidad de fortalecer   los artículos 3, 5, 6, 10, 11, 19, y otros  para lograr un régimen global, ambicioso y  solidario .  En este momento crítico, todo s necesita mos  mostrar mayor apertura . La experiencia nos  muestra que,  si no reconocemos la s responsabilidad es comunes pero diferenciadas de  cada uno de los países participantes y, si no estamos dispuestos a apoyarnos  solidariamente unos y otros, no se lograrán implementar las acciones urgentes que el  mundo necesita.   Exhortamos  a las delegaciones aquí presentes, a  reflexi onar  y a mantener las consultas  entre las regiones que han mostrado afinidad en sus posiciones con miras a reconvenir  este proceso , desde un punto de mayor fortaleza y convicción.  Nuestra tare a es aprobar  un tratado que mar que un antes y un después en la lucha frontal contra la contaminación  por plásticos  a nivel global .  Muchas gracias.

Title: Trinidad and Tobago
file_content: The Republic of Trinidad and Tobago    The fifth session of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee to develop an international legally binding instrument on plastic pollution, including in the marine environment (INC-5) 25 November to 1 December 2024 Busan Exhibition and Convention Center, Busan, Republic of Korea.   Closing Statement Delivered 2 December, 2024  Thank you Mr. Chair, Good morning colleagues,  Trinidad and Tobago would like to thank the Government of the Republic of South Korea and the people of beautiful Busan for their hospitality. We align ourselves with the statements made by Uruguay on behalf of GRULAC and by Samoa on behalf of AOSIS. This INC-5 session is coming to an end, but our work is not. Trinidad and Tobago has been involved in this process since the INC’s first step in Dakar; we have had small wins and sometimes set-backs as we navigated our way through this undeniably complex crisis. We are not quite there yet.   However, Trinidad and Tobago takes this opportunity to express our support for the latest Chair’s text as the basis for further negotiations. We re-iterate Trinidad and Tobago’s position as stated at INC-1 in Punta del Este, action against plastic pollution is greater than a waste management issue and as clearly stated in our mother mandate, requires a full lifecycle approach; an approach that will requires of us, Small Island Developing States an impressive amount of transformation, innovation and collaboration to enable this transition; which will demand robust and creative means of implementation, and the critical support of relevant subsidiary bodies such as those presented repeatedly by AOSIS and GRULAC throughout our last few days of contact groups, informals and informal informals. As such, we will continue to advocate for strengthening of  text on substantive issues such as existing plastic pollution, fishing gear and on chemicals of concern and plastic products as indicated in our support of the statement made by the distinguished delegate of Mexico. We will also continue to call for robust Articles 11 and 12 which we all know will be the backbone of this instrument.   Trinidad and Tobago reiterates our commitment to not only this process but to finding solutions to this indisputable crisis. We look forward to a clear path towards continued collaboration and constructive engagement at the Resumed session of INC-5.   I thank you Chair.
